AN INTRODUCTION TO 
THE WORLD‚ÄôS LARGEST 
DUNGEON
HISTORY 
Millennia ago, the Celestials built a great dungeon. 
Within it, the celestials erected mammoth walls, 
locks, doors, and traps. It warded off those who 
would enter but also walled in those who would es-
cape: it was a dungeon larger than any ever known. 
Within it, the celestials imprisoned hellish undead, 
demonic beasts, and fiendish monstrosities.¬†
The prison was a perfect construction. Dizzying 
mazes and complex traps designed to confuse and 
keep the prisoners inside. Before the first dwarf was 
born to sculpt stone, angels, and celestials carved 
a work of art that no one would ever see. Perfect in 
every detail, it would stand inviolate for thousands of 
years. But none can say why the gods ordered de-
mons and liches to be entombed and not destroyed. 
The logic of their decision is beyond the intelligence 
of mortals, their plans an impenetrable fog of reason-
ing. In time, the gods would rue their mercy.¬†
Centuries passed, and the prison remained un-
changed. The champions who protected humanity 
from the liches and hezrou and pit fiends stood 
vigilant guard, ready to spend eternity in honor of the 
gods. But time passed over the celestials. The world 
forgot its heroes. Even the heavens turned a blind eye 
to the angels, inevitables, and guardians serving out 
their destiny entombed in the earth.
No one is sure how much time passed before an 
earthquake cracked the foundation of the dungeon. 
The rift spread for miles, nearly ripping the dungeon 
in two. Into the rift flowed lava, but it did not boil 
the occupants of the dungeon. The temperature rose 
beneath the earth, and the cold home of the unliv-
ing became capable of sustaining life.
It was not long before the derro came. They made 
their homes among the rocks and tombs. Many of 
the traps set throughout the dungeon had been 
triggered, and creatures that the celestials¬†had sworn 
to entomb eternally had escaped. In time, more 
subterranean creatures would make their homes in 
the rock. All the while, celestials stood guard over the 
truest evils.
¬†Then, another earthquake pushed jagged earth 
through the dungeon floor, destroying a large por-
tion of its foundation. Driders and drow dug beneath 
the rock and rubble to make their homes.¬†The same 
earthquake tore a hole in the ceiling, and flying beasts 
like the arrowhawk and belker perched on the highest 
plateaus of their underground sanctuary.
As the dungeon‚Äôs population grew, so did the ce-
lestials‚Äô fear that mankind would be destroyed¬†by its 
inhabitants. Two titans made the long journey to the 
mountain and stood guard at the entrance and exit to 
the tombs in eternal vigil.
Time passed. Few monsters made the climb down 
from the surface or pushed up from below. Only
 
the 
strongest made a home in the debris of the prison. 
Eventually, more derro came, bringing other diggers 
with them. When they required more room, the derro 
dug deeper.
The burrowing derro caused a massive landslide, 
bringing thousands of pounds of earth and millions 
of gallons of water crashing in. Hundreds of derro 
and duergar died, and the survivors moved deeper 
into the earth. Enlisting every manner of enslavable 
race, the derro crossed a giant chasm and started 
digging again.
Within the last hundred years, the dungeon has seen 
unprecedented activity. Every manner of creature lives 
in the dungeon. An elder treant and its elven entourage 
have made a refuge in the westernmost portion, while the 
undead have remained entombed at the northernmost 
point since the dungeon‚Äôs creation. The core of the dun-
geon (Regions F and G) show the greatest sign of conflict, 
with angels and devils waging a war that must end poorly. 
Lastly, the exit has seen a change of power that will stymie 
heroes who think they‚Äôre ‚Äúalmost done.‚Äù
The World‚Äôs Largest Dungeon represents years of 
adventuring. Do not tread lightly.

 4
FACTS ABOUT THE DUNGEON
The World‚Äôs Largest Dungeon is malleable. It has 
been designed to serve your needs as a gamemaster, 
but this book is peppered with advice. Unless you are 
starting a fresh game world with fresh characters, you 
will have to do some work to wedge the dungeon into 
your setting.
The plan is for the dungeon to be in a mountainous 
region. It has been buried for countless years, and 
no humans have found it until now. There is a plot in 
Region A for bringing the PCs into the dungeon, but 
there are also 20 options on a chart on page 8. Tailor 
the story to your needs. And if you don‚Äôt like a Region 
of the dungeon or want to start with a different area, 
skip what you don‚Äôt like.
The maps don‚Äôt even need to connect the way 
they are connected. You are welcome to move 
them around.
The dungeon has one entrance for our design 
purposes, but it can have any number of entrances 
you need. If you desire more entrances, they should 
be well hidden or even guarded by relevant creatures 
(kobolds near the front, winter wolves along the cold 
northeast section, and so on).¬†
Because the northern reaches of the World‚Äôs 
Largest Dungeon have access to the surface world, it 
should be in a remote area, lest adventurers know it is 
here all along.
A chasm filled with lava ‚Äî filled with mephits ‚Äî 
pushes through the earth beneath the Dungeon. It 
must have a beginning and end point, which you may 
need to explain for setting continuity, but you may 
simply decide it remains under the earth, pushing¬†up 
under a lake or sea bed, warming the currents.
The monsters in the Dungeon do not have children. 
There are no locations with baby ogres or yuan-ti 
eggs. If this does not mesh with your vision of a 
harmonious dungeon, we apologize. Killing children, 
whatever their species, faction, or identification, is 
not heroic.¬†
ECOLOGY 
Taken at face value, a dungeon housing over 1,000 
monsters is going to need a food source other than 
‚Äúthe titan just eats the elves.‚Äù In all honesty, we don‚Äôt 
expect this adventure to be run from beginning to 
end. While it has been designed to be just that ‚Äî the 
world‚Äôs largest dungeon ‚Äî and it has a reason for 
being here, such an undertaking would break even 
the bravest GM and players.
Therefore, it is our contention that lichen, rats, gob-
lins, and dire boars make for an excellent food chain. 
In the lower levels of the Dungeon, goblins hunt the 
rats and eat them, and someone eats the goblins. 
Who? That‚Äôs up to you. As for the higher levels of the 
Dungeon, drop in a farm of dire boars, and you‚Äôre all 
set. Like all pigs, they‚Äôll eat whatever slop you serve 
them, and chances are dire boars taste just as good as 
their real-world counterparts.
If your style of play requires more explanation be-
yond that, there are a few ‚Äúmagical‚Äù answers to help 
quell your need for realism.¬†
 
Underground springs of water provide all manner 
of sustenance. Time moves slowly here, so when 
most creatures do drink or eat, it nourishes them 
longer.
 
Because of the presence of the celestials, no one 
needs to eat. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs such a hospitable 
place for monsters: there is less competition over 
resources.
 
Races trade with the fey. In exchange for not 
wiping them out, the nymphs and dryads provide 
edible lichen and other food. After all, if you eat a 
treant today, you‚Äôll be hungry tomorrow, and then 
what?
 
At high enough levels, clerics can make food from 
nothing. Certainly, a goblin shaman could summon 
a plate of grubs for his followers.
 
The steam mephits provide magical sustenance to 
all who stand on the rocks of the Dungeon. (We 
don‚Äôt know exactly how that works.)
 
Certain races, like the driders, are experimenting 
with creature cross-breeding. Maybe chaos beasts 
or free-range chuul are tasty.
 
Cut the Dungeon into bite-size morsels and run it 
as separate lairs, each with its own passage to the 
outside.
 
Perhaps intelligent monsters are more nutri-
tious.
PRISON ARCHITECTURE 
The Dungeon was built to jail undead and demons, 
not to be comfortable. There are no barracks, kitch-
ens, or anything resembling ‚Äúliving‚Äù quarters. Squat-
ters have made do with whatever they‚Äôve found here. 

5
Makeshift barracks do not afford the comforts of 
home. The PCs won‚Äôt find a logical pattern here.
After a few weeks of exploring, the PCs may start 
coming to their own conclusions about the Dungeon. 
If not, they can always run into a lantern archon.
LANTERN ARCHONS
One of the PCs‚Äô best friends are the helpful lantern 
archons that may appear throughout the Dungeon. 
These celestials were assigned to know everything 
about their own dungeon, and some have survived to 
the present day. Each lantern archon knows why its 
Region of the Dungeon was created but is ignorant of 
conditions on other maps. These archons are a great 
way to dole out information to the PCs.
Lantern archons can be found anywhere the GM 
likes. They know many things they shouldn‚Äôt, like PC 
names, recent plunder, total dead in the area, and 
so on. They are not there to tell the PCs what lies 
beyond a door but rather to point them to the 
Dungeon‚Äôs major plots. Their original purpose 
was to watchdog the Regions, but since the 
earthquake, each archon has grown sullen 
(and perhaps a little lonely), taking on a per-
sonality of its own.
All of the lantern archons believe that 
Region O is the only exit to the Dun-
geon and that Barcellus (Room O59), a 
titan loyal to the celestials, guards it. 
They do not know that Barcellus has 
been replaced. See Region O for 
more details.¬†
Feel free to give each archon 
a unique voice. Alternately, 
ignore them altogether and 
have the PCs find their way 
through the mess.

 6
THE DUNGEON ENVIRONMENT
SCALE 
Scale is a bit of a mixed bag here. In the original 
printing, the maps needed to be at least six feet tall 
(marketing demanded it) when fastened to the wall. 
As such, there were limits as to how big the Region 
maps could be. The original intent was for the dun-
geon to be many square miles. But if you examine the 
map, it‚Äôs a lot less than that.¬†
As such, the maps were initially designed to be 5-ft. 
by 5-ft. squares, which was also the baseline for the 
third edition. However, making them 10 ft. by 10¬† ft. 
squares, in fact, gets the size of the dungeon closer to 
the original mark. However, that makes a lot of these 
hallways gigantic. So, there are a few suggestions on 
how to apply scale to these maps.
The simplest answer is the maps are not to scale. 
They give a general idea of the placement and size of 
a hallway or room, but the GM is free to mix things 
up however and whenever. When the mapping 
doesn‚Äôt line up, that‚Äôs on par with what the celes-
tials intended.
All of the squares are 5 by 5 or 10 by 10. Done. Don‚Äôt 
worry about it.
The space under the mountain does not match 
the space on top of the mountain.¬† It doesn‚Äôt have to 
make sense. It‚Äôs magic.
Region H is problematic when you try to ascer-
tain how remote this prison is. If the PCs never visit 
Region H, it is irrelevant. Alternatively, Region H is 
10 miles east of where it appears on the map. Prob-
lem solved.
The passageways between Regions (maps) are very 
long. Add a few hundred feet here and there. 
Doing any of these requires some different visual-
ization, but none of it reduces the dungeons‚Äô playabil-
ity. There are still rooms, doors, hallways, monsters, 
traps, and the occasional treasure.
SIGHT 
Keep in mind that the Dungeon is completely dark. 
Except where noted, there are no sources of light any-
where inside the Dungeon. This environment does 
not present a problem for most creatures, who rely on 
darkvision or blind vision to find their way. Of course, 
while darkvision or blindsight allows the creatures to 
see, there are distance limits.
Unless the party is composed entirely of races that 
have darkvision, the PCs must rely on light sources 
to find their way. Aside from illumination problems 
(torches burn out, light spells end), having to rely on 
light sources presents a huge handicap in sections 
where other creatures can see in the dark. Outside, 
a torch can literally be seen from miles away on a 
moonless night. Inside a dungeon, low ceilings and 
tight corridors reduce torch visibility to 100 ft. or 
so. Nonetheless, any attempts at stealth, including 
surprise, are ruined by a simple candle as watchful 
creatures likely spot the light source long before it 
becomes visible.
Nothing attracts unwanted attention in darkness 
like a source of light. Regions H, K, L, M, the eastern 
edge of N, and O all have slightly different lighting 
conditions. Higher ceilings, holes in the mountain 
tops, and other conditions make these Regions differ-
ent from the claustrophobic tunnels of the remaining 
dungeon. Review these chapters and make sure the 
PCs understand how high the ceilings are.
SOUND 
Sound doesn‚Äôt travel as far as the PCs might expect. 
While the Dungeon is not soundproof, the walls are 
very thick, muffling the screams of the demons in 
their cells. Wards were added to soften their annoy-
ing, persistent echoes. Years of neglect have caused 
these wards to warp, creating an unplanned new 
effect. Sound is unpredictable.
This means a lot to clever GMs. If the PCs are extra 
quiet, perhaps a single breath gets funneled down a 
quarter mile of corridor, alerting everyone of the PCs‚Äô 
presence. Or an epic battle in a room two doors away 
goes unheard. Echoes from the farthest reaches of 
the Dungeon could be heard at the entryway, and the 
PCs‚Äô footfalls could go unnoticed by someone right in 
front of them.
Don‚Äôt be afraid to use this to your advantage or to 
help low-level PCs sneak past larger adversaries. Drop 
hints of things to come or disguise an ambush wait-
ing to happen. It is important to note that Regions 
H, K, L, and O do not follow standard rules regarding 

7
magic, wards, and ‚Äî in this case ‚Äî sound. Feel free 
to apply these concepts as you see fit.¬†
TRAPS 
While most of the original magical traps have long 
since failed or been destroyed when the creatures 
imprisoned here escaped, the celestials maintained 
a number of other traps up until their departure to 
Regions E and G. Although they are usually in areas 
of strategic importance, traps are occasionally found 
in unexpected places.¬†
Many traps were designed only to paralyze the un-
dead and demonic forces that could not be destroyed. 
Others produce cold and/or fire depending on 
whether they were designed to kill devils or undead. 
Acid and sonic traps were effective as well, bringing 
many creatures to their knees. However, because 
of the nature of the undead and demonic beasts, 
someone always had defenses against something. As 
a result, a variety of traps were made, many of them 
magically capable of resetting themselves.
Over the centuries, many creatures have stumbled 
through these corridors, tripping glyphs, spells, and 
fire traps. The hardest ones to spot have already been 
tripped, and some never reset. The ones that have a 
marking were circumnavigated once the first hobgoblin 
was turned into a rat or doused with flaming oil. The 
easiest ones to spot have been avoided. That said, traps 
can be anywhere the GM wants to place them. Doors, 
columns, and secret panels could be trapped. Anything 
a demon might fiddle with to escape the dungeon could 
be trapped. Feel free to add all manner of non-lethal 
traps whenever the whim strikes.
Note: Corridor traps slow down gameplay. A project 
of this type requires them to some degree but be 
merciful and give the PCs a chance to spot them 
passively without the rogue calling out for searches 
every 20 feet.
OTHER 
Because the original builders had little need for 
creature comforts, the Dungeon has little in the way 
of furniture or standard dungeon decor. The occa-
sional workbench or forge might exist, though. These 
Regions are geologically unstable. So, while an actual 
collapse is not going to happen with the PCs inside 
the dungeon (unless you want one), the occasional 
rumbles and tremors are common. These rumbles 
can be anything from a minor nuisance to a real haz-
ard. If the random encounter tables do not include 
them, feel free to add them when things are slow.
INTERIOR DOORS AND WALLS: THE 
SIMPLE ANSWER
Unless otherwise stated, all walls are stone, and all 
doors are iron. 
Iron Door: 3 in. thick; AC 19; hp 30; open lock DC 15. 
Stone Wall: 3 ft. thick: AC 17; hp 50; break DC 30.¬†
Due to the Prison‚Äôs superstructure, even a small 
section of broken stone causes no lasting damage. 
Only a force on par with a cataclysmic earthquake can 
damage the foundation.
INTERIOR DOORS AND WALLS: LOCKED 
DOORS 
A number of doors in the Dungeon are locked. This 
makes the Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Tools) proficiency very 
handy. In fact, PCs shouldn‚Äôt enter the Dungeon 
without a rogue and a set of thieves‚Äô tools (lockpicks). 
As a GM, you have to decide if you want certain doors 
to be easier or harder to open. Apply advantages and 
disadvantages however you see fit.

 8
INTERIOR DOORS AND WALLS: STAN-
DARD DOORS 
Unless stated otherwise in the Room or area text, 
a standard dungeon door conforms to the follow-
ing rules.¬†
If there is no description of a door, it is closed but 
unlocked. How long and tedious would this be if they 
were all locked?
It is made of wood and bound with iron.
Iron Door: 3 in. thick; AC 15, damage threshold 12; hp 
90; break DC 21; open lock DC 15.¬†
It opens in one direction only but has pull rings 
on both sides. All doors push open into the Rooms 
from the hallway or from the previous Room unless 
otherwise noted. In case of a conflict, the decision is 
up to the GM.¬†
Although heavy, it is well anchored on common 
hinges and can be opened by any creature of Small 
size or larger simply by leaning on it. Doors can only 
be pulled by a creature able to grasp the ring. Crea-
tures of Tiny size or smaller do not have the mass to 
pull open a door, even if they have the strength.¬†
Doors are neutrally hinged and do not swing open 
or close on their own. A closed door stays closed, and 
an open door stays open unless purposely shut.
There is roughly a half-inch gap between the 
bottom of the door and the floor, allowing air, light, 
noise, and smells to escape. Most prison/vault doors 
are sealed completely.
INTERIOR DOORS AND WALLS: SECRET 
DOORS 
Unless stated otherwise in the text, a secret door con-
forms to the following rules.
If there is no description of the door, it is closed 
and of stone or whatever material the wall is made of.
Stone Door (stone wall section): 3 ft. thick; hard-
ness 20: hp 200: break DC 28.
It pivots on a central, vertical axis by being pushed 
on one or the other end. Because they are much heavi-
er than standard dungeon doors, secret doors require 
a successful DC 15 Strength check to push open or 
closed, and the following special size modifiers ap-
ply: Gargantuan +12, Huge +8, Large +4, Medium +0, 
Small -4, Creatures of Tiny size or smaller do not have 
the mass to push open a secret door, no matter how 
strong they are. In addition to these modifiers, any 
creature that is on more than two legs or is otherwise 
exceptionally stable gains a +4 modifier.
Unless noted, discovering it requires a DC 16 In-
tellegence (Investigation) check. In more advanced 
regions, this number may be as high as 20 or 25, per 
the GM‚Äôs discretion.
Unless noted, it has no locking mechanisms and 
thus cannot be locked, nor does it have a return mech-
anism. Secret doors remain open if opened or closed 
if closed.
They are six feet high by seven feet wide. When fully 
open, secret doors are completely perpendicular to 
the wall. There is roughly three feet of maneuvering 
space between the secret door and the wall. This is 
large enough for a single creature of Medium size to 
squeeze through on either side simultaneously; crea-
tures of Large size or larger usually cannot fit through 
such a space (although whether they actually can or not 
is ultimately the GM‚Äôs call and depends on the physical 
characteristics of the creature). The door sits one foot 
off the ground on a threshold to allow for the pivot, a 
fact that also makes it more difficult to detect.
Secret doors are built to very tight tolerances. There 
is a slight gap at the top and bottom through which 
air or noise might pass. Because of the thickness of 
the secret door, this gap is not large enough to allow 
light through.
Pushing a secret door open causes the stone to 
scrape slightly and makes the same amount of noise 
as a person in medium armor trying to stealth (DC 11 
Wisdom (Perception) check to detect the noise).¬†
Some encounters have special conditions or rules 
that make it harder for the PCs to defeat the mon-
sters. Some are contingent upon room conditions, 
magical effects, or sometimes sheer game balance. If 
they are hurting your games, ignore them. They are 
here to add elements to combat the PCs cannot plan 
for. Anyone who wants to kill an orc already knows 
their armor class and hit points, but what if they can‚Äôt 
plan for certain bonuses or tactical benefits?
After all, monsters don‚Äôt want to die. They will do 
everything in their power to stay alive. They fight 
from vantage points; they ambush the PCs when they 
can; they use numbers to their advantage; they flee 
or surrender when death is imminent. And since the 
monsters aren‚Äôt stupid, be prepared to kick the PCs 
around a little until they learn this. And if that doesn‚Äôt 
work, add a few Encounter Conditions of your own.

9
CEILINGS 
The dungeon ceiling is sometimes as low as 10 ft. 
and sometimes as high as 50 ft. (or more). Each 
Room and hallway is different. The GM may decide 
how tall each Room is or roll once per Region, Sec-
tion, or Room to determine the ceiling height.
If you need details, consider rolling for each Room. 
Or just roll when you think it will be relevant.
D20HeigHt
1-510ft.10ft.
6-1015 ft.15 ft.
11-1420 ft.20 ft.
15-1625 ft.25 ft.
1730 ft.30 ft.
1840 ft.40 ft.
1950 ft.50 ft.
202d6x10 ft., or 1d20x5 ft.2d6x10 ft., or 1d20x5 ft.
Outside the ‚Äúdungeon‚Äù proper, where the stonework 
juts out from the earth, the Regions are more cav-
ernous. In such places, the ceilings rise as high as 
four miles.¬†
TELEPORTATION AND EXTRA 
DIMENSIONAL TRAVEL 
The walls of a prison are useless when its inhabi-
tants can just phase out of existence and reappear 
on any plane they wish. The celestial knew this and 
surrounded the prison with a null field, negating 
extra-dimensional travel and teleportation. Any magic 
that allows the PCs or creature to gate, jump, or 
phase from place to place is negated. Creatures that 
have teleported into the dungeon (accidentally) find 
they cannot escape.¬†
Since the earthquakes, pockets have developed 
throughout the complex where the null field has 
weakened or disappeared completely. The text ex-
plains exactly where, but Regions H, K, L, and O are 
the weakest in this regard. Additionally, some maps, 
such as A, E, F, and N, have teleportation¬†built into 
their design. The maze-like nature of Regions E and 
F makes the random teleporters that much more 
devastating.
The GM may decide that creatures like barghests, 
shadows, blink dogs, and so on have limited range 
of motion on the ethereal or shadow planes, but they 
can never entirely escape the prison. Spells like di-
mension door, if allowed, only work to line of sight or 
100 feet (whichever is less). Bags of holding, portable 
holes, and the like lose their link temporarily with the 
dimension in question. Stored items inside a bag of 
holding cannot be accessed, and items added fill the 
bag as though they were a normal item.

 10
EXPERIENCE POINTS AND TREASURE
Let us explain some of the logic before getting into 
the advice.
From beginning to end, this dungeon has over 
1,600 encounters. Using the logic of 15 encounters = 
one level of advancement, the characters would reach 
level 107 when they finally exited the dungeon. And 
Dungeons and Dragons doesn‚Äôt go to level 107. Nor 
was either edition designed that way. That means that 
XP and Treasure cannot be handed out at the same 
rate as a typical dungeon.
You‚Äôre probably not going to like this, and certainly 
the players won‚Äôt, but this is an eventuality of some-
thing called the World‚Äôs Largest Dungeon. There are 
solutions, but again, these are only highly suggested. 
We can‚Äôt hover over your game table and make sure 
you‚Äôre doing it right.
Level advancement should happen at milestones. 
You know when the PCs have cleared a dungeon 
one-third of the way. Grant them a level increase, and 
don‚Äôt think too much about it. Give out XP as nor-
mal, as you like, but only use the map Regions that 
advance at the same rate as the PCs. If the PCs are 
level 7 when they exit Region A, then Regions B and 
E should be removed from the dungeon, leaving 
the PC to advance to C, F, or I.
Instead of tackling it in one big go, just run each 
Region as a stand-alone adventure. Regardless, each 
Region tells you the levels the PCs should be for 
them.
The same goes for treasure. The dungeon purposely 
has scant amounts of gold and magic items. There 
are so many routes for the PCs to take and so much 
advancement that could happen, the PCs would be 
running around with 10 +3 swords if we followed the 
regular flow of magic items. As such, the GM will 
need to hand out trinkets and prizes here and there, 
roughly one-third as often as normal. 
Note: There is some treasure here, but it is rare.
Region A has a built-in story about how the PCs are 
roped into this adventure. However, you may decide 
to start somewhere else, or you don‚Äôt like that story 
because it requires a little bit of front-loading. Either 
way, the following chart is a quick-start way to have 
the PCs inside the dungeon in no time.
QUICK-START REASON
Alternatively, if the players know that you bought this 
book, tell them to equip themselves for a long jour-
ney and pick a mission from the list below.

age. Now it‚Äôs the time for heroes. The doors

through Module B2, and have the rubble 
in Room 51 lead to Room A1 of the World‚Äôs

Each map (or Region) has a theme. Divided by ob-
stacles, territorial markings, secret doors etc., Regions 
can be divided into separate adventures or linked in 
one grand campaign. While each chapter explains its 
role, this is a short overview of each section.

11
BASIC OVERVIEW
Region A: Orcs, kobolds, and extraplanar creatures 
fight for territory. At the heart of the conflict is a 
wererat bent on controlling the entire Region. This 
introduction suggests to the PCs that something is 
going on in the prison. Levels 1 to 3.¬†
Region B: A series of traps guard a fractured goblin 
empire. Hobgoblins, bugbears, blink dogs, and a 
false king. Levels 4 to 6.
Region C: Almost as chaotic as it is ordered, Region 
C unites many classic dungeoneering themes: 
traps, puzzles, and unique monsters. Region C is 
also a dead end, and unless the PCs recover the 
special key in Room C 105, their trip here will go 
for naught. A black dragon trapped inside the maze 
and an ancient spectre make up two of the Region‚Äôs 
finales. Levels 7 to 9.
Region D: One of the most important plots of the 
entire complex, the derro are the source of most 
problems in this dungeon. Now, a xill and his min-
ions have enslaved dwarves, duergar, derro, grim-
locks, and all manner of burrowing creatures to free 
an entombed evil. Levels 14 to 18.
Region E: One of a handful of celestial outposts in 
the Dungeon, the inevitables and guardians strug-
gle for ‚Äúauthority‚Äù while monsters from Region J 
and the outermost portions of Region E break down 
their defenses. A number of creatures in this Region 
(insects, shadows, etc.) reduce the PCs‚Äô ability scores 
with their poisonous/draining attacks. Clerics will 
need spells like lesser restoration to survive the jour-
ney. Levels 4 to 6.¬†
Region F: The most complex maze in the Dungeon, 
this Region is controlled by three opposing mino-
taur tribes, each being played against the other by 
a manipulative rakshasa-medusa team. Randomly 
teleporting gates make this Region nearly impossi-
ble to map. Levels 7 to 9.
Region G:  The heart of the Dungeon and the most 
important struggle to save the PCs‚Äô world from ex-
tinction, Region G is the location of the final battle 
between the angels and demons. Levels 9 to 11.
Region H: Elf guardians and dedicated fey stand vigil 
around the ‚Äúfirst tree,‚Äù fallen into the Dungeon 
a few centuries ago. This is the most roleplay-
ing-intensive Region. Here, the PCs can affect the 
Dungeon on a different level than the high-fantasy 
conclusions of Regions D, G, and N. Levels 11 to 13.¬†
Region I: Tied to Map M, this Region is home to all 
the aberrations and ‚Äúthings that should not be.‚Äù 
Concerned that the creatures could escape into Re-
gion E, the inevitables built wards to keep them in, 
but the tide of war slowly pushes against the PCs. 
Levels 7 to 9.

 12
Region J: Based on dungeon crawls of old, this 
Region has puzzles, trapped statues, and tribes 
of monsters living elbow-to-elbow. With a nearly 
impossible finale, the Region will have PCs visiting 
again and again. Levels 13 to 15.¬†
Regions K and L: These two Regions are intricately 
linked. Another by-product of the derro dig, this 
lake and adjoining swamp are the result of the 
landslide that dropped the two-mile-high ceiling 
into the Dungeon. Throw Region H in for a com-
plete campaign adventure all its own. Levels 11 to 13 
and 13 to 15.
Region M: Tied to Region I, Region M is the most 
conflicted of the maps. Drider masters perform 
horrible experiments on their drow slaves, tossing 
the aberrant remains into Region I. An exit to the 
mountain peaks above the Dungeon promises es-
cape for those who can fly, but the cloud giants and 
flying beasts that control this Region have their own 
plans. Levels 9 to 12.
Region N: The largest and most impenetrable part of 
the Dungeon, the Tomb of the Unliving houses a 
three-way war between a lich, a mummy lord, and 
a ghost. Millennia of war have sculpted the land-
scape of this tomb, but none of these beasts have 
yet succeeded in releasing the terrible World Eater. 
Levels 14 to 18.
Region O: The climax to the Dungeon holds yet 
another twist. While the PCs may or may not know 
about the titan guarding the exit, the frost giants 
have enslaved the Region‚Äôs occupants and taken 
control of the exit. They are not pushovers, and 
PCs thinking the undead were the final piece of 
the puzzle are in for a rude awakening. Because the 
PCs can race to the end, this Region covers Levels 
16 to 20. 
Reading the Encounters
Each encounter is written in the same general format. 
Each opens with the number and name of the Room 
followed by pertinent information on running the 
encounter.
If there is specific information about the door or 
entrance to the Room that GMs should be aware 
of before the PCs enter, it can be found before the 
Read Aloud Text. Additionally, if there is a trap or 
something of note before the door, it is mentioned 
here. Some encounters happen in hallways, so be 
alert for them.
Read Aloud Text. It is recommended that the GM 
paraphrase or relay this information in his own 
voice, rather than read it aloud verbatim. This text 
relays to the players what they see, hear, and sense 
about the environment.
Initial Attitude. Attitudes for NPCs and monsters 
are Hostile, Unfriendly, Indifferent, Friendly, and 
Helpful. Few in this dungeon are Helpful. Hostile 
attitudes are hard to change, and monsters that are 
assigned to guard duty rarely change their minds 
about attacking.
Encounter. This is the meat of each Room, and 
includes the Room‚Äôs history, details of the envi-
ronment, monsters, traps, and so on. If a Room 
is completely empty, there is still a short descrip-
tion to give the GM something to improvise. If 
a monster or NPC is present, its hit points are 
listed. If the encounter refers to creatures from 
another part of the dungeon, it lists the Room 
they are from.
Encounter Condition. This is a special section. 
Written in shorthand, these notes point the GM to 
the charts explaining exactly how to conduct the 
battle. Not every encounter has a special condi-
tion, but feel free to add them to taste. Sometimes 
Encounter Conditions exist for encounters that are 
not violent. Details are still provided should a fight 
break out, or should the PCs try to sleep in a haunt-
ed chamber.
Tactics. Sometimes generic, other times Room spe-
cific, the tactics of a given monster are explained 
here. Sometimes the Tactics section helps a GM 
understand the contents of the Room, how to open 
a secret door, or what the best course of action is. 
Tactics is a catch-all when the Encounter and Trea-
sure sections don‚Äôt fit.
Treasure. Be careful not to read this aloud until the 
PC s have taken time to search the Room. Because 
there are over 1,600 Rooms in the Dungeon, no 
matter how much or how little treasure we as-
signed, it was going to be the wrong amount. Care-
fully weigh whether or not the PCs need another +1 
longsword; would the campaign be better served 
with a potion of healing instead? Don‚Äôt be afraid to 

13
give out less treasure at the start of a Region, antici-
pating greater rewards at the end.
Scaling. Each encounter with a monster or trap 
includes tips on how to make the encounter easier 
or harder. The GM should feel free to ignore this 
section or embellish each encounter as he sees fit.
The GM is always free to increase DCs. Increasing 
the DC is as simple as saying ‚Äúthe stonework is very 
dense‚Äù, or ‚Äúthe pervading darkness and low ceilings 
make it hard to see.‚Äù 
This book is a great big toolbox, and you are the 
craftsman.
Encounter Conditions
Some encounters have special conditions or rules 
that make it harder for the PCs to defeat the mon-
sters. Bear in mind that the monsters don‚Äôt want to 
die; they will do everything in their power to stay 
alive. They fight from vantage points; they ambush 
the PCs when they aren‚Äôt looking; they use numbers 
to their advantage; and they flee or surrender when 
death is imminent.
None of the monsters in this dungeon are stupid. 
Be prepared to kick the PCs around a little until they 
learn this. And if that doesn‚Äôt work, add a few En-
counter Conditions of your own.
Encounter Conditions listed in [brackets] are not au-
tomatic. Some are optional while others are contingent 
upon something in the encounter. Read the Encounter 
thoroughly to note the difference.
Ambush: The monsters have advantage on all Stealth 
checks prior to Initiative.
Ambush (darkness): The monsters have advantage on 
all Stealth checks prior to Initiative and attack light 
sources from a distance and then attack the PCs 
from darkness, taking advantage of their darkvision.
Bog: Area is considered difficult terrain. Dexterity 
checks and saves are made at disadvantage. Ev-
ery torch or other flame-based light source has a 
50% chance of going out; roll once for each source 
at some point during the encounter. If someone 
carrying such a light source goes prone the light 
source is automatically extinguished.
Concealment: Monsters in the Room are considered 
lightly obscured unless they are adjacent to a PC. 
While obscured they have the benefits of half cover.
Concealment (total): Monsters in the Room are con-
sidered heavily obscured unless they are adjacent 
to an PC. While obscured they have the benefits of 
three-quarters cover.
Cover: Monsters in this Room maintain full cover 
until they are adjacent to a PC. While in full cover, 
they have advantage on Dexterity saving throws and 
cannot be targeted by attack rolls.
Cover (soft): As Cover, but the cover does not grant 
advantage to Dexterity saving throws.
Cover (total): As Cover, but unless adjacent to a PC, 
monsters have three-quarters cover while adjacent 
to cover, regardless of PC sight lines.
Cursed X: Something isn‚Äôt right about this Room. Its 
inhabitants are slightly unhinged or its walls seem 
to sag with an undefinable sadness. The longer 
PCs spend in this Room, the harder it is for them 
to leave. Increase the DC of all Wisdom and Cha-
risma saves by X while in this Room. Monsters or 
PCs already suffering from madness do not suffer 
this penalty.
Deep Darkness: This Room is cast in perpetual mag-
ical darkness that cannot be dispelled. Torches and 
lanterns give off ¬Ω their normal light and magical 
light requires a Concentration check (DC 15 + spell 
level) or it is extinguished.
Deep Silence: This Room is cast in perpetual mag-
ical silence, as per the silence spell, that cannot be 
dispelled.
Desecration X: Add X to undead saves against effects 
that Turn Undead.
Diseased (Name) X: For every minute the PCs spend 
in this Room, they must succeed at a DC X Consti-
tution saving throw or contract the named disease. 
Even diseases that normally are only contracted 
through ingestion or injury can be contracted in 
this Room.
Distracting Noises: There are noises in the darkness 
that cannot be explained, Nonetheless, they can af-
fect the wandering minds of PCs. Similar to Echoes, 
this Room also imposes Disadvantage on Wisdom 
and Dexterity saving throws, as well as Concentra-
tion and Perception checks. PCs must succeed on 
a DC 22 Constitution check in order to gain the 
benefits of Short or Long Rests in this Room.

 14
Distracting Visions: Something is waiting in the 
darkness, or the shadows play strangely on the 
walls. While in this Room, the PCs suffer Disad-
vantage on Initiative rolls and Attacks of Oppor-
tunity. PCs must succeed on a DC 22 Constitution 
check in order to gain the benefits of Short or 
Long Rests in this Room.
Drafty: Open flames, such as torches, each have a 
50% chance of being extinguished at some point 
while in this room.
Echoes X: A great deal of noise and distraction in-
creases the DC of all Perception checks by X.
Extreme Cold: Anyone remaining in this Room for more 
than 1 minute begins to suffer the effects of cold. 
Casting spells in the cold is difficult: teeth chatter and 
fingers shake. Casting a spell in this Room requires a 
successful Constitution check (DC 8 + the spell‚Äôs level). 
The cold can be magical or natural.
Extreme Heat: Anyone remaining in this Room 
for more than 1 minute must succeed on a DC 
12 Constitution saving throw or suffer 1 level of 
exhaustion. PCs in medium or heavy armor have 
disadvantage on the roll. The heat can be magical or 
otherwise. This stacks with other sources of ex-
haustion, but can only add up to 3 points (4 for PCs 
wearing heavy armor) and fades after 30 minutes 
outside of Extreme Heat.
Fear X: An inexplicable pallor of evil permeates this 
Room. PCs must succeed on a Wisdom saving 
throw (DC equal to X) or be frightened until they 
leave the room.
Fearless: Monsters and NPCs are immune to the 
Frightened condition, do not negotiate, and do not 
flee. Effects like dissonant whispers still deal damage 
but do not force the target to flee. Undead cannot 
be Turned, but on a failed save still suffer damage 
equal to the level of the cleric.
Flooded: These Rooms have become flooded by a 
higher water table or some magical effect. Area is 
considered difficult terrain. Ranged Attacks and 
Dexterity checks and saves are made at disadvan-
tage. Every torch or other flame-based light source 
has a 50% chance of going out; roll once for each 
source at some point during the encounter. If 
someone carrying such a light source goes prone 
the light source is automatically extinguished.
Fog X: Everything in the Room X feet or further away 
is considered heavily obscured.
Hallowed X: This Room is holy. Clerics and Paladins 
gain X bonus to all Charisma based skill checks and 
undead and fiends have disadvantage on all sav-
ing throws.
Haunted: Rest is impossible. PCs can spend hit dice 
during a rest to regain hit points, but otherwise 
gain no benefits from resting.
Hazardous Footing X: The floor is covered in de-
bris, rocks, glass, or sharp objects, or it otherwise 
impedes movement. PCs moving more than half 
their speed must succeed at a DC X Dexterity check 
or take 1d4 damage for each 5 ft. they move that 
round. Small and Tiny creatures have advantage on 
the Dexterity check.
Invisible: For some magical reason, the monsters in the 
Room gain the benefits of invisibility until they take 
an Action (attacking, casting a spell, etc.) that removes 
this benefit.
Negative Energy: Undead heal 1 hit point per hour 
in this Room. PCs lose 1 hit point per minute in 
this Room.
Poor Footing X: All (ground-based) monsters and 
PCs have disadvantage on melee attacks unless they 
succeed on a Dexterity saving throw (DC 10 + X).
Positive Energy: PCs heal 1 hit point per hour in this 
Room. Undead suffer 1 hit point of damage per 
minute in this Room.
Safe: This Room is generally safe and might be a good 
place to rest. Reduce the chance of an encounter here 
to 1/6
th
 the normal rate of Random Encounters for the 
Section (e.g. if Random Encounters are rolled every 
hour, they are rolled every 6 hours in this Room).
Smoke: The air in this Room is thick with an un-
breathable smoke, either from magic use or a 
recent fire. A character who breathes smoke must 
make a Constitution saving throw each round (DC 
13, +1 per previous check) or be Incapacitated until 
the start of their next turn as they spend the round 
choking and coughing. A character who chokes for 
2 consecutive rounds takes 1d6 points of nonle-
thal damage. Many creatures that do not breathe 
(demons, aberrations, etc.) use Smoke to their 
advantage.
Spell Resistance: This Room is guarded by wards 
and spells that dispel all magic cast within it. All 
occupants have advantage on saving throws against 
spells and other magical effects.

15
Stagnant Air: As Smoke, but instead of taking dam-
age, a character who chokes for 2 consecutive 
rounds is considered Poisoned. Many creatures 
that do not breathe (demons, aberrations, etc.) use 
Stagnant Air to their advantage.
Submerged: The Room is completely underwater 
and the PCs must swim across it. The PCs must 
have some way to breathe water to remain in this 
Room, or they will begin to drown.
Tremors X: A tremor shakes the Dungeon, drop-
ping stones on the PCs. PCs must succeed at a 
DC X Dexterity saving throw or suffer 2d6 points 
of bludgeoning damage at a random point in the 
Encounter.
Unhallowed: This Room is unholy. Clerics and Pala-
dins have disadvantage on all skill checks.
SUMMONING MONSTERS
It‚Äôs bound to happen. A PC realizes that nothing in 
this dungeon ever leaves. The magic of the prison 
holds it on this plane. ‚Äú I can spend 14 days summon-
ing badgers for the big battle, right?‚Äù
We don‚Äôt feel good about the answer GMs are 
going to give the PCs on this one, but here goes. PCs 
shouldn‚Äôt have access to summoning spells. It‚Äôs game 
breaking. We can‚Äôt eliminate conjuration magic en-
tirely, even though, by the backstory of the Dungeon, 
it shouldn‚Äôt work at all. Now. There are workarounds. 
Summoned monsters are pseudo-magical and turn 
to goo or something when the duration expires. 
But that‚Äôs more explanation headache on your part, 
should the PCs push back on the ruling.
There is one way to stop the wizard with 400 bad-
gers around her, and that is to eliminate control of 
the monsters once the summoning spell wears off. 
The badgers turn on the wizard or run off into the 
dungeon on their own.
And do we have to say this? Summoning monsters 
to turn around and kill for XP is worth nothing.
Our suggestion is to not have summoning work at 
all. Tell the players they can choose other conjuration 
spells, but anything that brings a creature into the 
dungeon does not work.
Demons and devils still retain their demon-sum-
moning abilities. This flies in the face of what we‚Äôve 
just said about summoning spells, but there‚Äôs a game 
balance reason for this. The XP and challenge rating 
of the demons is based on their ability to summon 
allies. For some creatures, it‚Äôs all they have.
But if they can summon other demons and devils, 
why haven‚Äôt they summoned more to them to help 
break out of their cells?
DEMONIC SUMMONING
Demons are unpredictable. They don‚Äôt follow orders 
well, and no one needs sixteen lemures hanging 
around and screwing up their master plans. Addi-
tionally, there is limited space in these cells, and 
summoning another demon into your Room is just 
stupid. Some demons are already elbow to elbow. 
And while demons feed on chaos, one could guess 
that after 4,000 years of being trapped inside a dun-
geon cell next to Bob the Eternal Jerk,¬†‚Äúsummoning‚Äù 
Rob the Endless Moron is going to make the scen-
ery so much worse.
Most of the devils are trapped in Region D, where 
there is no more room. Also, the devils in the Dun-
geon have an attitude problem. They often don‚Äôt 
work well with others and know that another devil 
of equal power is going to rival it. Finally, imps are 
useless in high-powered regions of the Dungeon. 
Summoning one as a scout would be like delivering 
a free pizza to your neighbor.
MAKING IT WORK
It‚Äôs all about the fun. While a great story will always 
be remembered, a series of great evenings is all we 
could ever ask from a product of this scope. We en-
courage GMs to make things challenging, heroic, and 
epic, but above all, fun. A lot of people put a lot of 
work into this book, and if you don‚Äôt gain some kind 
of enjoyment from it, then we‚Äôve failed.
And we don‚Äôt like to fail.
So sit back, relax, and enjoy what will be the best 
(and longest) gaming experience of your lives.

Z1 - Z2 . A TITAN DIES

Z1    . THE TITAN
As you climb the mountain, rocks and debris slow 
your ascent. Numerous tracks of different creatures 
ascend the hillside. Some you recognize. Others... 
The climb levels off as you get closer to the cave 
mouth. You see a humanoid figure the size of a 
galleon lying on the ground at the cave opening. 
As you get closer, you can see that death has taken 
him. Despite his obviously decomposed state, 
the man does not exude the odor of decay. There 
are no signs of a struggle. Who was he, and how 
did he die?
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: The body of Breysus, a dead titan, lies at 
the opening of the World‚Äôs Largest Dungeon. For 
centuries, he stood guard at this doorway while his 
brother guarded the other side of the mountain 
(see Room 59, Map O).
Tactic: N/A
Treasure: His Gargantuan halberd and Huge chain-
mail are not much use to the PCs. Even if they 
find a way to carry these items, the armor only fits 
Breysus. Though they are made of fine steel, neither 
the halberd nor the chain shirt can be cut down to a 
useful size, though the links of the shirt could con-
ceivably make an excellent chain for a ship‚Äôs anchor.
In his pockets are a millennium‚Äôs worth of 
notes and scribbles written in an ancient language, 
totaling over 500 lbs. of appropriately sized writing 
materials. Some are strewn about the area, having 
been scattered by various creatures looking for 
something of value. Other notes have been taken

He has no gold, no gems, and nothing 
else of value.
The notes are written in an ancient form of 
celestial. If the PCs can ascertain their meaning, it

stream-of-consciousness note taking about Brey-
sus‚Äô day-to-day observations. One in 50 pages talks 
about the nature of the prison and the honor he 
and his brother have been allowed to guard this 
entrance. Another one in 100 pages talks about the 
demons and devils held captive inside. Nothing 
specific, as he does not know the manner of their 
captivity, only the brushstrokes of what the pris-
on represents. Some of the pages talk about the 
earthquake, but he never went inside to see the 
effects of it. He died before Longtail came through, 
so there is no mention of the creatures that now 
occupy Region A.

Should the PCs examine the cave, read further.
The cave is low and shallow, obviously dug by

EXITS
If you look carefully at the maps, you‚Äôll see that Maps 
D, H, L, M, and O all hint at something ‚Äúbeyond.‚Äù 
While Maps H, M, and O are designed to be exits, 
Maps D and L have potential exits left to the GM‚Äôs 
imagination. It would be close-minded to create a 
dungeon of this magnitude without leaving room 
for the GM to expand. In fact, another book could 
be published with potential exits and surrounding 
environs. Where would it end, exactly? Would the PCs 
be over level 20 when they got there?¬†
It is up to the GM to decide whether or not the PCs 
can use these exits.
East of Region D: Some of the tunnels running east 
of the Map are perfect places for new adventures, 
a whole new campaign to begin, or a route to the 
surface. How far do those tunnels go? How long is 
the route to the surface?
East of Region H: While technically, the PCs can 
‚Äòfly‚Äô out of the top of the Dungeon above this 
Region, the elves guard their steeds carefully. PCs 
with the ability to fly can go straight up and out of 
the Dungeon.
East of Region L: How far to the east the lake extends 
is up to the GM. Perhaps it‚Äôs another 100 feet, or 
perhaps channels extend for miles underground, or 
to another dungeon entirely.
North and west of Region M: While we haven‚Äôt 
defined the Dungeon beyond the borders of the 
map, the GM can either have the cavern dead end a 
few hundred feet up or perhaps there is a series of 
twisting tunnels at the higher reaches of the moun-
tain. This could mean another adventure trying 
to get out.
North of Region N: The tomb by itself is completely 
walled off, but it‚Äôs up to the GM how far the cavern 
around it extends.
Region O: The obvious exit is here. PCs who defeat 
the frost giant who has taken over are sure to find 
the real exit to the Dungeon. In addition, the ceiling 
above Regions H, K, and L is open... a few miles up. 
The PCs can escape from these locations if they are 
so inclined and able.
X1 . MAGMA FLOW
The following location in the magma flow cuts 
through the center of all the maps and is described 
here for ease of reference. This description fits the 
magma flow in every Region.
The flow of molten rock meanders to the southeast, 
consuming all it touches. Bubbling up from the 
flaming river are occasional pockets of scalding 
steam, shrieking and moaning, disrupting the 
earth‚Äôs quiet. Though the flow is indeed hot, it is 
bearable, and when you watch the floating bit of 
rock flare into flame, you can see multitudes of 
small imp-like creatures playing in the stream, 
tossing balls of flaming slag at the dancing clouds 
playing on the fiery river‚Äôs surface.
Initial Attitude: Indifferent¬†
Encounter: After the earthquake shattered the 
Dungeon‚Äôs foundation, opening a rift extending 
for miles, something strange happened. A small 
stream of liquid rock slowly filled the chasm created 
by the quake. It wore away the caves that underlay 
the Dungeon‚Äôs foundation, collapsing enormous 
sections of the magma below and further widening 

 18
the gorge. As the magma filled the bottom of 
the rift, it stranded many denizens on small rock 
islands amidst a sea of fire. Understandably, the 
temperature rose. Though the heat warmed the 
complex, it was somehow survivable. No toxic 
fumes wafted from the flow‚Äôs surface, just steam as 
water from the tiny cracks and fissures poured into 
the burning river, creating patches of semi-solid 
rock on its surface. Stranger still, the creatures in 
the Dungeon could approach its shores without 
suffering from the extreme temperature. Because 
of its unusual properties, the complex could sustain 
all forms of life.
Of course, there is nothing natural about this 
dungeon, and the odd properties of the flow 
surprised no longtime inhabitants of this place. 
In time, it became clear why the molten rock did 
not fill the caves with poisonous fumes and lethal 
temperatures: the force of the earthquake had 
interacted with the Dungeon‚Äôs magical properties 
to tear open a permanent gate in two of the Inner 
Planes: Earth and Fire. Liquid fire and a river of 
earth poured out of the gate, and when the streams 
crossed, the magma was created.
On the Elemental Plane of Fire, the tear attract-
ed a lot of attention. The native magma and steam 
mephits investigated the gate and watched where 
the liquid fire blended with the flowing earth. Like 
moths to a flame, fire, magma, and steam mephits 
passed through the portal. To their horror, they dis-
covered the gate was one-way, trapping them in the 
cold caverns of the massive complex. Worse, they 
could not warn the other mephits, who continued 
to spill through the gate, trapping more and more 
of their kind until the chasm filled.
Hordes of mephits came through the tear, 
but they found the frigid Dungeon inhospitable. 
The mephits gathered in and around the magma 
flow, with steam mephits lurking near the surface 
and magma mephits swimming through it. These 
outsiders absorbed the heat emitted by the molten 
rock. The steam mephits, thriving in such environ-
ments, contained the toxins and poisons.
Now, the mephits rarely leave the security of the 
magma, which allows other creatures, including 
the PCs, a chance for survival. The mephits have 
been here so long they are no longer interested in 
getting back to the Elemental Plane of fire and are 
content to spend their days mindlessly basking in 
the magma‚Äôs heat. They do not communicate with 
other creatures and attack only if some fool falls in.¬†
Fortunately, the effects of the mephits on the 
magma reduce the severity posed by this environ-
mental hazard. Falling into this magma flow does 
not deal the normal damage. Instead, the magma 
deals only 21 (6d6) points of damage to unprotect-
ed characters each round, insulated as they are 
by the mephits who swim through it. Victims are 
still subject to drowning rules as described in the 
GMG. In addition, a swarm of magma and steam 
mephits attack any victim who falls into the flow. 
The number of mephits attacking each round varies 
as the flow carries them onward. Each round, 8 
(1d10+3) magma mephits attack submerged PCs, 
or 4 (1d6+1) steam mephits and 4 (1d6+1) magma 
mephits attack PCs floating on the surface.
Encounter Condition: Extreme Heat¬†
Tactics: The flow does not go in a single direction. 
It bounces back and forth, swirling through the 
Dungeon core.
Treasure: N/A¬†
Scaling: To increase the challenge, double the num-
ber of mephits that can attack the PCs. To decrease 
the challenge, have them arrive every other round.¬†

NOMENCLATURE
We used a few keywords to make reading 
this a little easier.
Map. There are 16 maps in this dungeon. 
They can be cut into smaller lairs for in-
dividual adventures or brought together 
into one campaign.¬†
Random Encounter. Every Section of the 
Dungeon has its own Random Encoun-
ter chart. These are usually rolled every 
hour, but they can be altered to taste. 
Region. An entire Map and its contents 
are called a Region. There are 15 Re-
gions in the Dungeon, with Region 
N being twice the size of the others. 
Each Region has its own chapter in this 
book. While Region and Map are nearly 
synonymous, they are not interchange-
able terms.
Room. The place where the PCs are 
standing. It can be a 10 ft. by 10 ft. cube. 
Or it can be a 100 foot wide cavern. So 
long as there is an encounter there, it‚Äôs 
a Room. Every Room is numbered. If it‚Äôs 
not numbered, it‚Äôs not a Room.
Section. The territory that the monsters/
creatures/NPCs occupy. ‚ÄúRooms K1 
through K24,‚Äù for instance, is a Section 
of the Dungeon. Some rules affect an 
entire Section, or certain Random En-
counters may occur only in that Section. 
A Section comprises many Rooms and 
should not be confused with a Region.

has been thoroughly mapped and detailed, every 
GM will find that they want just a bit more detail. 
These Rooms are here for that reason and may be

SPELLBOOKS
Wizards do not have it easy in this dungeon. No, that‚Äôs not strong enough. Wizards get hosed 
by this Dungeon. Because the PCs are going to be underground for about two game years, 
with no way of returning to the surface, it‚Äôs difficult for wizards to justify spells appearing in 
their spellbooks without reason.
Sorcerers, druids, and clerics all draw their power from a less tangible source, but a wizard 
has no new sources of magic. Because this may upset those wanting to play spellcasters, there 
are a number of ways to help wizards through this.
There are plenty of scrolls scattered throughout every Region (and plenty of room for the 
GM to drop them into the Dungeon as you see fit). When these scrolls are discovered, the wiz-
ard can merely place the spells in his spell book rather than use them in combat. This ensures 
that wizards always have something but wholly determines what they can and cannot learn.
Alternatively, the GM can allow wizards to start with a full spellbook (as a 20th-level wizard), 
forcing the fledgling wizard to choose all his spells ahead of time. This is challenging, but 
can also put a wizard who is unprepared for specific challenges at a huge disadvantage. GMs 
should choose half of the spells for a spell book of this nature.
If a wizard gains access to a divine (or bardic) spell that also appears on the arcane spell list, 
the GM may allow the wizard to learn that spell. If the wizard studies the spell from a divine 
spell caster, add +5 to the DC check to learn it. Increase the modifier by +2 per spell level 
difference between the lists. If the wizard wants to learn a spell that‚Äôs 3rd level for a cleric but 
2nd level for a wizard, increase the DC by +7. No matter what, the wizard can learn only those 
spells that appear on his spell list.
Finally, the GM can simply allow the PC to choose whichever spells he likes as he goes up in 
level. This is the least exciting method, but gives PCs the greatest spread of options.
Ultimately, whatever the GM decides is law.
One last thing: there are certain spells (grease, entangle, web, etc.) that are one-note and a 
little powerful for an all-dungeon campaign. They will get repetitive and exploitative. It is our 
recommendation that GMs do not include them. GMs should do the same with the PCs.

Room isn‚Äôt quite as clean and spotless as it appears. 
Any creature or object that remains in this Room 
for more than an hour turns invisible. The effect is 
continuous and cannot be dispelled so long as the 
creature or object remains inside the Room.¬†
Encounter Condition: Invisibility
Tactics: PCs walking cavalierly through the Room are 
liable to bang into the table. A Small creature will hit 
its head and chest, while a Medium creature strikes 
its thighs and waist into the table. This is annoying, 
but the table doesn‚Äôt damage the PCs.¬†
As soon as the PCs leave the Room, the effect 
ends, and they can be seen again. PCs of low Wis-
dom believe they remain invisible for 1d4 minutes 
per point of Wisdom below 10. In essence, the In-
visibility is a trick on the mind of the person being 
affected, not the person viewing them.
Treasure: The table cannot fit through the doors, even 
if it is unbolted from the floor. It is made of sturdy 
hardwood and is not magical. Nothing else lies in 
this Room except for invisible dust and dirt.
Scaling: N/A
W11 . EMPTY ROOM ELEVEN 
The pale brown walls, ceiling, and floor are covered 
with some sort of leathery canvas, though no 
means of attachment can be seen. The air is stag-
nant, and the odor of sweat is heavy in this room. 
A small, dark, irregular circle seems to be painted 
on the floor.¬†
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: At one time, this Room was trapped with 
an incredibly complex and powerful spell, a last line 
of defense against a particularly nasty inhabitant 
of this Region. The only remnant of the trap is the 
Room itself, made up of the body of the creature 
that triggered the trap.¬†
The dark paint on the floor is actually a blood stain 
where the floor was once cut.
Encounter Condition: Fear 12
Tactics: Once the PCs realize the walls were made 
from the flesh of a living creature, a fear effect 
is produced. Failing a DC 12 Constitution saving 
throw causes them to become nauseated for 3 (1d6) 
minutes. Nauseated creatures have disadvantage on 
physical ability checks and all attack rolls.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: N/A
W12 . EMPTY ROOM TWELVE 
Opposite the massive stone door of this hall is a 
10 foot statue of black stone. The effigy represents 
a humanoid male, thick arms crossed across its 
massive chest. Though out of place, the statue 
is surprisingly clean and in good condition. Its 
pupilless eyes seem to stare eerily at you.
Initial Attitude: N/A¬†
Encounter: Angel wardens, now dead, sculpted this 
statue of a great celestial. It has remained un-
touched to this day.¬†
Encounter Condition: Hallowed 5
Tactics: Due to its powerful magical aura, monsters 
avoid this Room. As such, Random Encounters 
occur half as often here.¬†
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: N/A
W13 . EMPTY ROOM THIRTEEN
A small grove of trees surrounds the stone floor of 
this Room, standing amidst snow-covered benches 
and a stone bowl full of ice. The normal floor gives 
way to a beautiful wintry landscape. As you look up 
to see the top of a giant fir tree in the corner, the 
stone ceiling blocks your view.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: The scenic winter wonderland is real, cre-
ated by an artist of unsurpassed talent, with several 

25
sets of marvelous pigments. The trees, though not 
alive, are real. The snow and ice are real. Anyone 
can walk among the trees and kick up some snow. 
There are no magical illusions in this Room, but the 
walls are painted in such a way as to trick the view-
er‚Äôs eye. Visually, the Room appears to extend for 
miles when, in actuality, it fills an area 10 feet larger 
to a side than the Room‚Äôs original space.
Encounter Condition: Safe¬†
Tactics: If the PCs stand in the center of the Room, 
the optical illusion is perfect. If the GM feels so in-
clined, creatures from the Region could be resting 
here, but none are inclined to conflict because the 
Room radiates a constant Calm Emotions effect 
that can only be overcome with a DC 22 Charisma 
saving throw.
Treasure: Though PCs may find this Room a trea-
sure beyond words, there is nothing of physical 
value here.
Scaling: N/A¬†
W14 . EMPTY ROOM FOURTEEN 
This empty Room is best used if the PCs need to get 
across to another door. Otherwise, it will just frus-
trate them.
A dense fog fills this room, obscuring sight and 
muffling sounds. Footsteps can be heard walking 
away from the door through the fog, but beyond 
that, you find yourself completely isolated from the 
world around you.¬†
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: All sound in this Room is magically damp-
ened past 10 feet. This means that PCs venturing 
more than 10 feet away from each other lose contact 
completely until they stumble upon each other again 
in the fog. The footsteps start and stop every few 
seconds and eventually lead PCs to a door out of the 
Room (possibly the one they came through). Players 
that request to do so may have their PCs attempt a DC 
17 Intelligence (Arcana) or Spellcasting ability check to 
realize the sound of the footsteps is illusory.¬†
Encounter Condition: Fog 5, Haunted
Tactics: Feel free to have the footsteps move in 
random directions. This effect works best in a large 
Room with at least two doors.
Do not use miniatures or maps for this encounter.
Treasure: Feel free to drop a common magic item 
(or two potions) somewhere in the Room. On each 
PCs turn roll 1d20: on a roll of 19 or higher they are 
within 10 feet and a DC 16 Wisdom (Perception) 
check will find it.
Scaling: N/A¬†
W15 . EMPTY ROOM FIFTEEN
The interior of this room reeks of rotting flesh, and 
flies buzz loudly. In the center of the room, a pile 
of charred wood is surrounded by six humanoid 
corpses. Another corpse lies on its side, partially 
leaning against the wall opposite the door. All of 
the bodies are in similar states of decay and have 
been stripped.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: The corpses are of six goblins that got 
lost in the Dungeon and finally settled down here 
to rest before taking up their wandering again. 
Unfortunately for the goblins, the guard on watch 
fell asleep, and the whole group was murdered in 
their sleep.
Encounter Condition: Stagnant Air
Tactics: It is not clear who killed them and if the kill-
ers were the ones to loot the bodies.
Treasure: If the PCs search the bodies, a DC 16 
Wisdom (Perception) check turns up a gold neck-
lace worth 100 gp around the ankle of one of 
the goblins.
Scaling: N/A
W16 . EMPTY ROOM SIXTEEN
The door to this Room is locked, requiring a DC 15 
Dexterity check using thieves‚Äô tools to unlock. In 
addition, the lock is trapped. Choose a trap from 
Appendix A.
At the center of this room, a badly decomposed 
winged body lies. Its arms, legs, and wings cast 
out to the four winds; the body has obviously been 
the target of violence since its death. Shreds of fine 
raiment cover the body, but all weapons, armor, 
and goods have been removed. Next to the body, 
writing has been scratched in the stone.
Initial Attitude: N/A

 26
Encounter: This was one of the members of the ce-
lestial garrison who was slain after the first earth-
quake. Before he died, he carved his last words on 
the stone floor. In Celestial, they read, ‚ÄúAlsar of 
the Bright Host. I stood fast against the darkness 
and now travel into the light. Let you who find 
my body carry on the fight in my stead.‚Äù Alsar was 
slain, and his corpse was desecrated by creatures of 
the Dungeon.
Encounter Condition: Positive Energy
Tactics: Perhaps the Room‚Äôs contents have been 
shrouded by illusion, or the PCs were destined to 
find it, but this discovery points out that the Dun-
geon was once something much different than 
they thought. If this is their first encounter with the 
celestials or this information has never been im-
parted to the PC, they now have some record of the

Treasure: Touching the body of the celestial turns it 
to dust but grants that PC +1 Con and +1 Wis until 
their next Long Rest. In addition, the PC is granted 
a vision of some important event in the history of 
the Dungeon . Make it vague but provide a hint 
that the Dungeon was more than it is now (as the 
spell divination). The celestial also bore a signet ring 
on his left hand. This signet could prove useful in 
Region C, E, or G, where identification as a ‚Äúceles-
tial-aligned‚Äù being is useful.
Scaling: N/A
W17 . EMPTY ROOM SEVENTEEN 
The floor of this room is missing. Instead, there is 
a pit of significant depth, at the bottom of which 
is nothing but spikes and corpses. The walls and 
ceiling are bare except for a few scratch marks. 
A foul odor indicates that the bodies have been 
rotting for some time.¬†
Initial Attitude: N/A¬†
Encounter: This Room contains a pit trap that is now 
stuck in the open position, nothing more than a 
very deep pit with spikes at the bottom. Some of 
the local residents use the pit for garbage disposal, 
particularly for the bodies of their enemies. With a 
DC 17 Dexterity check using thieves‚Äô tools, the trap 
can be repaired and the floor restored to the Room.
 '
Hidden Pit. Mechanical trap. This pit has a cover 
constructed from material identical to the floor 
around it. A successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) 
check discerns the uncanny appearance of the 
section of ground that forms the pit‚Äôs cover while a 
successful DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check 
is necessary to confirm that the trapped section of 
floor is actually the cover of a pit. When a creature 
steps on the cover, it swings open like a trapdoor, 
causing the intruder to spill into the pit below. The 
pit is usually 10 or 20 feet deep but can be deep-
er. Once the pit trap is detected, an iron spike or 
similar object can be wedged between the pit‚Äôs 
cover and the surrounding floor in such a way as to 
prevent the cover from opening, thereby making it 
safe to cross. The cover can also be magically held 
shut using the arcane lock spell or similar magic.
Encounter Condition: Stagnant Air
Tactics: Because residents frequently bring trash 
here, roll for a Random Encounter after 30 minutes.¬†
Treasure: If the PCs climb down into the pit and 
make a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check, they find 
13 sp, a rusted shortsword, and 2 (1d3) mundane 
trinkets of the GM‚Äôs choice.¬†If they succeed on a DC 
19 Wisdom (Perception) check, they additionally find 
a large yellow diamond worth 500 gp.
Scaling: N/A

27
W18 . EMPTY ROOM EIGHTEEN
Before the PCs open the door, read the following:
This door is abnormally warm. Heat emanates 
from the room beyond, and you can hear the sound 
of fire and an odd ‚Äúwhooshing‚Äù noise after short 
but irregular intervals.
Once the PCs open the door, read the following:¬†
This entire Room is scorched black. After a few 
seconds, the Room is entirely engulfed in flame, 
creating a ‚Äòwhoosh‚Äô noise as air rushes in to feed 
the fire. This process repeats frequently, rarely 
taking longer than half a minute between bursts.
Initial Attitude: N/A¬†
Encounter: This Room contains a fireball trap, but

goes off at random intervals (every 5 (2d4) rounds), 
destroying anything placed inside. The vent for the

turn it off is on the far wall. If the PCs wish to cross 
the Room, they must find a way to disable the trap

The PC disabling the trap must brave the fire 
to reach the lever. Once they reach the lever, they 
must move as quickly as possible to disarm the trap. 
While a DC 16 Dexterity check using thieves‚Äô tools 
disables the trap, this takes 5 (1d6+2) rounds. Every 
two points by which the PC‚Äôs roll exceeds 16 reduces 
the time needed to disable the trap by 1 round.
 '
Fake Fireball Trap. Magic trap. A spell or other effect 
that can sense the presence of magic, such as detect 
magic, reveals an aura of Illusion magic around the 
Room. PCs hit by the flames take no damage but 
must succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom saving throw or 
become Frightened for one round.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: The fire is an illusion. A powerful illusion, but 
an illusion. The PCs should believe on every level 
that it is real until proven otherwise.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
make the fireball trap real. To decrease the chal-
lenge, add some element to the Room that makes 
the trap appear more ‚Äúfake.‚Äù
 '
Real Fireball Trap. Magic trap. A spell or other effect 
that can sense the presence of magic, such as detect 
magic, reveals an aura of Evocation magic around 
the Room. PCs hit by the flames must succeed on

fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a

W19 . EMPTY ROOM NINETEEN
The door to this Room has broken off its hinges.
The door to this room has long ago been splintered,

Encounter Condition: Fog 15¬†
Tactics: N/A¬†
Treasure: If the PCs succeed at a DC 16 Wisdom 
(Perception) or Intelligence (Investigation) check or

Scaling: N/A
W20 . EMPTY ROOM TWENTY
While no heat radiates off the walls of this Room,

Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: The wall of fire is an illusion. It produc-

 28
if they believe it is real, it deals 18 (2d6+11) fire

7 (2d6) rounds after the fire goes off, the walls

MAP V .
THE VAMPIRE TOMB 
The only location that exists under the Dungeon is

REGION A
STOP!
If you still need to read the introduction, do so now. 
You must understand the foundation of the dungeon 
to run this adventure. Details on lighting, doors, and 
so on all explain how to run this adventure.
LONGTAIL
Longtail is a wererat sorcerer with a quick mind, cha-
risma, and grand ambitions. With research and the 
aid of his imp familiar Achsyyx, Longtail uncovered 
some of the secrets of the dungeons, its history, and 
their original purpose.
Through Achsyyx‚Äôs ability to commune with the 
infernal powers, he learned that there was a long-for-
gotten chapel close to the dungeon entrance that 
held a gateway to an extradimensional space where 
multitudes of infernal beasts had been trapped. 
According to Achsyyx, releasing those beasts would 
make the wererat their master and grant him a fero-
cious army. Longtail‚Äôs destiny was clear.
Longtail‚Äôs endless charm allowed him to bring 
together a diverse force of humanoids to accompany 
him on his quest. Gathered from the disaffected 
elements of half a dozen tribes; kobolds, troglodytes, 
orcs, and even an ogre rallied to his side.
Fueled by the promise of treasure and led by liz-
ardfolk guides, Longtail‚Äôs forces made their way to 
the dungeon in short order. Entering the long-lost 
entrance, they began exploring the area searching 
for the tomb‚Äôs fabled wealth. Longtail himself, guid-
ed by Achsyyx, led a small expedition into the far-
thest reaches.
At first, empty-handed, the humanoids were 
eager to exploit their new home, greeting Long-
tail‚Äôs absence as a chance to gather as much trea-
sure as possible. But as party after party came back 

29
empty-handed and with tales of barren rooms filled 
with nothing but traps, trouble ensued.
Longtail‚Äôs natural leadership had held the unusu-
al force together. Soon, however, natural rivalries 
began to assert themselves. Insults and slights led to 
shouting and infighting, and suspicions and rumors 
of unshared loot led to bitter accusations. 
Inevitably, an armed confrontation took place, and 
Longtail‚Äôs force was splintered in two. The reptilians, 
composed of the kobolds, troglodytes, and lizardfolk, 
banded together against the more numerous orcs 
and their ogre enforcer.
The dungeon was divided, each side looking for 
treasure they would never find. After fruitless days, 
both sides became convinced that the other side had 
found something. Soon, spying gave way to battle as 
the two factions fought across the length and breadth 
of the area. In a short time, they forgot about trea-
sure, concerned only with wiping out their enemies.
Whatever magic once existed in the prison-dun-
geon to keep hostilities squashed had evaporated. 
The dungeon was now fomenting with dissent and 
hate. Something Achsyyx either didn‚Äôt understand 
or didn‚Äôt plan for. And now, Longtail‚Äôs quest was a 
side note in the scuffle; some even forgot about the 
half-fiend.
They would soon be reminded.
Even as the humanoids fought amongst them-
selves, Longtail led his expedition to the forgotten 
chapel. There, with the aid of his familiar Achsyyx, he 
opened the gateway. 
Things did not go as planned. A wave of extraplanar 
beasts, driven by hatred, rushed through the gate-
way and into the dungeon. Falling on the fighting 
humanoids, the beasts struck a hammer blow that 
filled the dungeon with the blood and the screams of 
Longtail‚Äôs erstwhile allies. As Longtail tried desper-
ately to gain control, Achsyyx and the infernal pow-
ers smiled.
Random Encounters
The release of the extraplanar beasts has thrown this 
entire Region into chaos. Whereas before, there were 
clear areas under the influence of a particular group 
of humanoids, the resulting chaos means that there 
are no longer any actual areas of control. Between the 
hunting beasts and the scared, lost humanoids, there 
is plenty of motion and confusion in this dungeon. As 
a result, a party traveling through this Region is just 
as likely to encounter a reptilian as they are an orc or 
an extraplanar beast.
Rather than checking at some specific time interval 
for random encounters, the GM should use this table 
whenever they deem appropriate. Remember that 
despite the number of Rooms in this Region, there is 
not a lot of distance between most Rooms and areas 
and sound carries well in such an environment. If the 
action is slow ‚Äî for instance, the PCs are taking their 
time searching through the rubble in a Room or are 
being extra cautious as they move down a hall ‚Äî the 
events from this table will liven things up.
Another way to use the chart is to add a random 
element to the encounters described in the various 
Rooms. Many of the listed random encounters add 
an interesting twist to the otherwise standard com-
bat scenarios inevitable in a dungeon of this size. 
After all, the noise of combat is bound to attract 
some interest.
A final option for this table is if the PCs return to 
areas or Rooms where they have already been. Since 
the dungeon is in constant flux, it is likely that some-
thing other than the original inhabitants now occupy 
the Room. A particularly bold GM could use this 
table to add the occasional encounter to an otherwise 
empty Room.
Additional suggestions. Roll a random encounter:
 
Whenever the PCs spend too much time in one 
place
 
Whenever the PCs do something noisy 
 
Whenever the PCs rest with any sort of food or 
fire in a non-safe room
