A1 . ENTRANCE 
This is the last chance the PCs have to rest and reflect 
before entering the dungeon. Nothing else enters it 
as long as the PCs are in the entrance chamber. An 
inspection of the passageway as it approaches the 
‚Äòbarrier‚Äô reveals that it is absolutely featureless, devoid 
of markings, symbols, or even any sign of use.
As you move through the passageway, the edge of 
the tunnel disappears into a blackness that lies just 
beyond. It is not a wall barring entry but an inde-
scribable void. Darkness and light meet in a perfect 
duality. Peering cautiously into the darkness for 
signs of movement, you see none. There is a still-
ness in the air. No breeze in front of you. Nothing. 
Your ears detect only the breathing of your fellow 

31
adventurers. The darkness betrays nothing of what 
lies beyond.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: The passageway ends in an opaque 
magical field. This field prevents all vision, includ-
ing darkvision, as well as all sound from passing 
through from one side to the other in either direc-
tion. In addition, the magical field has an unusual 
and permanent force effect that allows creatures 
and items to enter the dungeon without difficulty 
but absolutely prevents them from leaving.
Opaque Door Barrier: Permanent, one-way wall of 
force. Cannot be dispelled or disintegrated, and no 
sound can pass through it.
If the PCs want to enter the dungeon, they 
simply must take that leap of faith and step beyond 
the door. Cautious PCs may stick only a hand or an 
object through, but they find that when they try to 
withdraw the hand or object, they cannot because 
the barrier prevents the return movement. No 
amount of pulling brings the hand or object back 
through the barrier, although if enough force is 
used, the object could undoubtedly be broken or 
the hand severed.
Encounter Condition: Safe
Tactics: Subtly encourage the PCs to prepare them-
selves by healing, resting, and readying equipment 
and weapons, etc., prior to having them enter the 
dungeon if they need it. Nothing bothers them as 
long as they are in this Room, and they can take all 
the time they need to make sure they are in tip-
top shape. 
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
do not indicate a barrier has been passed. Simply 
let the PCs walk through an invisible force field 
unknowingly. To decrease the challenge of this 
encounter, give the PCs a hint that this barrier is 
one-way, or simply ignore this effect completely. 
Allow the PCs to come and go as they please. This 
eliminates a lot of the dread of the dungeon but 
does give back one more gaming option to players 
who demand complete agency.
A2-A20 . ORC STRONGHOLD
Rooms A2 through A20 make up the former orc 
stronghold within this Region. The orcs chose the 
area closest to the entrance for defensive reasons and 
launched all of their search expeditions from here. 
While this portion of the dungeon is defensively 
strong, these same qualities limit the ability of the 
orcs to explore the other parts of the dungeon.
As the conflict with the reptilians escalated, the 
orcs‚Äô leader, a barbarian named Orghar, decided that 
it was time to force a decision. Marshaling the orcs, 
he led them in an all-or-nothing assault on the reptil-
ians throughout the dungeon.
Since launching the attack, the orcs have aban-
doned this section. Although they planned to return 
and establish a garrison to guard the entrance once 
they were victorious, none returned. Various groups 
established themselves throughout the Region but 
have been displaced since.
A2 . THE FIRST ROOM 
Your torchlight gleams feebly in the complete 
gloom, lighting up a small section of the room. 
Barely glinting in the torchlight, two iron doors, 
one straight ahead of you and the other to the side, 
are the only things visible in the walls of worked 
stone. The chill and damp clings to your body. 
You are not the only one feeling it, judging by the 
coughs coming from the darkness.
Initial Attitude: Unfriendly 
Encounter: Three orc warriors sit huddled together 
in the northeastern corner of this Room. They are 
battered remnants of the orcs who followed Longtail 
into the dungeon. There could be others. Somewhere. 
They look exhausted, and their scar-marked faces are 
ashen and pale. Infected wounds are evident, as well 
as bruises and blood stains from weeks of fighting. 
One has an eye full of pus. Another is missing teeth 

 32
and spits blood into a rusted cup. One orc attempts to 
stifle a lingering, persistent cough.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: The orcs are fatigued from their recent expe-
riences. Each orc suffers from one level of exhaus-
tion. They are not looking for a fight and will only 
attack if the PCs attack them first. The PCs are free 
to move about the Room ‚Äî the orcs only watch 
listlessly. Even if elves or dwarves are with the party, 
the orcs do no more than half-heartedly bare their

Any PC succeeding at a DC 13 Wisdom (Insight)

and then says ‚ÄúYou will see soon enough‚Äù in broken

the smallest one stifling his cough. The orcs ignore 
any further questions, answering with half-hearted, 
surly glances.
Any acts of intimidation, bluffing, or diploma-
cy fail on these tired warriors, and no amount of

anyone or anything. No matter what, the orcs do 
not accompany or aid the PCs in any way. They

If a fight ensues, the orcs do what they can to 
defend themselves, but their fatigue and defeatist

ploy no tactics other than a straightforward attack.
If the PCs return to this Room later (at least an

Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter,

alty to Strength and Dexterity).
A3 . BODY STORAGE 
Even before the door opens, you smell something 
amiss. As it swings open, the stench from within

chunks hang on hooks, while a barrel filled with 
harvested organs stews in the center of the room. 
On the northern wall, a makeshift shelf, warped by 
too much blood and sagging from the weight of

Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: These bodies are trophies brought back

Examination of the bodies shows their wounds were 
caused by sharp-edged weapons.
If the PCs move around the room, they most 
certainly kick over a jar of preserved eyes that lies in 
the darkness. However it is possible to spot it with a 
Wisdom check (DC 16) before that happens. Whoev-
er left this has a sick sense of trophy-hunting.
The smell of decay is strong enough to require a 
DC 12 Constitution saving throw from every living 
creature that enters the Room. Failing the save 
causes the creature to be poisoned for the duration 
of their stay in the Room as well as for 1d4 rounds 
thereafter. Any living creature spending more than 
a single round in the Room is also subject to catch-

Filth Fever: DC 11 Constitution save. On a failure: 
in 1d3 days, Dexterity and Constitution are each 
reduced by 1d4 until the disease is removed. Repeat 
save every 8 hours. Filth Fever ends after three con-
secutive successful DC 11 Constitution saves.
The secret door in the eastern wall is a standard 
secret door (Intelligence (Investigation) DC 15) that 
pivots on a vertical center hinge. The space opened 
by the door is just wide enough for a creature of 
medium size or smaller to pass on either side of the 
door (so up to two medium-size creatures can pass 
through simultaneously).
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: A kobold liver is mashed and cut up at the

a normal-sized human finger, however.
Scaling: N/A

A4 . ANTECHAMBER 
The southern door to this Room is trapped with burn-
ing hands. Anytime a Tiny or larger creature touches

 '
Burning Hands Trap. 3d6 fire damage. Creatures

Both doors into this hallway are open.

ft. wide hallway. Bits of clothing and leather armor

The Introduction presents a number of ways 
to get a party started in the World‚Äôs Largest 
Dungeon. A more specific example is suggest-
ed here, detailing the ambitions of Longtail and 
the imp Achsyyx. Although the exact reasons 
for the PCs‚Äô travel to the dungeon are up to the 
GM, Longtail‚Äôs plans feed directly into the plot 
of this region.
If you include this canon, Longtail has stolen 
a book of rituals from a nearby church.
In its simplest form, this means the PCs 
could be retained by said church to stop Long-
tail‚Äôs plans. This is also a handy way to ensure 
that the PCs are adequately equipped before 
entering the dungeon, with the third party pro-
viding essential aid, such as perhaps an ongo-
ing source of magical lighting or two.
An alternative idea is the PCs have had a 
run-in with Longtail or his humanoid allies 
before entering the World‚Äôs Largest Dungeon. 
This would require the GM to author up his 
pre-pre-adventure. Nothing complicated. Just a 
short series of investigations that keep Longtail 
always one step ahead.
Regardless, once the PCs arrive at the dun-
geon, they find themselves in the middle of 
the action. 
The PCs don‚Äôt need to be aware of any plots 
to enter the dungeon, either. If they are trea-
sure-seekers searching for a long-lost magic 
item, this might be enough motivation to enter. 
In this case, the PCs just happen to be unfortu-
nate enough to enter the dungeon shortly after 
the release of the extraplanar beasts.

the northeastern portion of the dungeon.

reduced to one-half of their hit points or until out-

 40
rats pursue fleeing PCs, attacking the rearmost PC

Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encoun-

Consider adding one more dire rat. To decrease the 
challenge of this encounter, add a third fiendish 
dire rat but have them all fight over a scrap of food

round of surprise.
A14 . ORC QUARTERS
The door to this Room is open. 
Trash lays in the hallway. The smashed door indi-
cates something was already here. Instincts tell you

Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: With a successful DC 14 Wisdom (Percep-
tion) check, the PCs notice a small tin box lying un-

A15 . CORNERED FIENDISH DARK-
MANTLES
The door to this room is open.
The bitter smell of rodent dung and decay is 
overwhelming. Trash is strewn across the floor, 
ankle-high in most places. The occasional blood-
stain marks the floor and walls, accompanied by

Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: This is a former orc sleeping area; the

Clinging to the ceiling of this Room are two 
fiendish darkmantles. Realizing they had become 
prey to a nearby swarm, the pair retreated here to

to pass, clinging to the center of the room. Splotchy 
purple birthmarks on one of the darkmantles make 
it easier for it to hide.
Note: The pair keeps a close watch on the door by 
constantly emitting high-frequency sounds, making 
it almost impossible to surprise them.
Encounter Condition: Ambush, Darkness
Tactics: The fiendish darkmantles work as a team in 
their pursuit of prey. Once they are aware that it is 
a group of humanoids ‚Äî and assuming the odds 
aren‚Äôt overwhelmingly against them ‚Äî one dark-
mantle moves to position itself directly above the 
door, while the other moves into the far corner to 
be harder to spot (DC 25 Wisdom (Perception) for 
the one above the door, DC 20 for the one in the far

The fiendish darkmantles surprise the first PC

41
if the PC spots the fiendish darkmantle on the far

If the duo cannot achieve surprise, the one on 
the far wall invokes its darkness ability while the

combat near the doorway to prevent numerous PCs 
from flanking them while, in turn, gaining flanking

If either fiendish darkmantle is reduced to less 
than one-half their hit points (or is killed), they 
flee using their darkness ability to help cover their

PCs, concentrating on the rearmost and letting the 
others go.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encoun-
ter, add a third darkmantle inside the room and/
or another fiendish darkmantle that attacks a PC 
in the hall, thus limiting movement. To decrease 
the challenge, remove the darkmantle‚Äôs ability to 
surprise the PCs.
A16 . SOUTHERN  
HALLWAY ROOM
Both doors in this room are open. 
You can already see the exit of this room, an open 
door directly across from you. Like so many rooms

Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room is empty, save some dust and

Tactics: Once the nearby darkmantles and stirges are

Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
have the fiendish stirges in Room A18 roll at ad-
vantage. To decrease the challenge of this encoun-
ter, have the fiendish stirges in Room A18 roll at

A17 . MIDDLE HALLWAY ROOM
Both the doors in this room are open. 
This room looks much like the others, with bare

Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Like Room A16, this room is completely

Encounter Condition: Drafty, Echoes 2
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: Now worthless, the wood-etched triptych

Scaling: N/A

 42
A18 . NORTHERN  
HALLWAY ROOM
All three doors in this room are open. 
This room appears to be a junction, with three 
open doorways leading in different directions. Like 
the previous two rooms, it is empty. Something 
about it indicates the room was used for something 
else, a long time ago. Your intuition is screaming 
this place is more than just an underground vault. 
Perhaps a prison. Or a torture chamber. A place 
where things were collected and stored. The lack of 
any features seems almost alien and fiendish.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: As in Rooms A16 and A17, this Room is 
completely empty. It served as a junction Room 
and defense point for the orcs. Before that, it would 
have been a transfer point for prisoners. The doors 
and wall radiate the faintest abjuration magic to 
those who would detect it.
If they have not spotted the PCs previously, six 
fiendish stirges alternate flying and hopping about 
the room, obviously agitated. Deciding that this 
was an excellent spot to wait for potential prey, the 
six have taken up residence. However, given their 
alignment, the fiendish stirges do not trust one an-
other. As such, they continuously hop and fly from 
perch to perch to prevent one another from being 
the first to feed.
The stirges have been mutated and transformed by 
the fiendish magic that claimed them. Their hooked 
bills are split in two, segmenting their faces. Their 
eyes have grown into two vertical, but not symmet-
rical, sets on each side of their faces. Each fiendish 
stirge is slightly different from the next but with 
terrifying and bizarre visages.
Encounter Condition: Concealment
Tactics: When one of the fiendish stirges sees or 
hears something of interest, it goes to investigate, 
and the others follow. In the case of the PCs mov-
ing through A16 and A17 or either of the hallways, 
roll Wisdom (Perception) checks for the fiendish 
stirges as the PCs move. On a successful Wisdom 
(Perception) check (DC 13), one of the fiendish 
stirges has either seen the PCs or heard them and 
flies off to investigate. One round later, two more 
fiendish stirges follow the first, and on the third 
round, the remaining ones follow. The lead fiendish 
stirge attacks the first PC it comes across, and the 
others join in as soon as they arrive.
Each fiendish stirge fights as an individual and will 
not cooperate with another stirge. They prefer to 
seek out their own victims rather than share. As a 
result, each PC finds themselves fighting at least 
one stirge directly. In combat, the stirges use their 
ability to fly to dart in, drain a PC, and then evade 
retribution. They continually switch the PC they‚Äôre 
attacking, buzzing about and around the group like 
flies around red meat. 
An individual fiendish stirge will not pursue a flee-
ing PC as long as there is an open PC in the imme-
diate area.
Although aggressive, the fiendish stirges are also 
cowards. If damaged, each flees, abandoning the 
others to their fate. If two of the six are killed, the 
remaining flee.
A satiated fiendish stirge (one that has drained 4 
points of Constitution) will fly off down the hallway 
to the east to find a place to digest its meal.
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
have all six of the fiendish stirges arrive at the same 
time. To decrease the challenge of the encounter, 
have two of the fiendish stirges begin to fight each 
other rather than the PCs.
It is possible that this fight will be over quickly. 
Feel free to bring in more scavenger-type rein-
forcements‚Äîmore dire rats, for instance. Have 
another stirge show up, but it has a series of weird 
powers and even more messed-up features. The 
list goes on.
A19 . REFUSE 
PCs approaching within 20 ft of this alcove become 
aware of the putrid smell. Read the following text 
when they reach the alcove. 
You have traced the smell to its source: a hole some

43
It appears that the first died from the inside out,

Filth Fever. DC 11 Constitution save. On a failure: in 1d3

A20 . ORGHAR'S QUARTERS
The door to this Room is open as is the secret door in

A table, a stool, and a bed, all intact, sit across

Orghar‚Äôs evil permeates everything here. And

ings, while the dirt served as a crude chalkboard to

Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A

A21 . THE SECRET ROOM 
The eastern door leading to Room A72 is trapped. 
Pulling the door open releases scything blades 

 44
located underneath it. The blades swing out at any-

A22-A24 . PILLAR ROOMS
Rooms A22 to A24 are part of the original construc-
tion of this dungeon. Although the dungeon‚Äôs cre-
ators did not require much comfort, they did create 
some places to pass the time. This is one of the areas 
and consists of these three Rooms, each with a differ-
ent function.
The humanoids all knew of these Rooms but only 
used Room A22 for its water supply. They never real-
ized the magical properties of Room A23 and avoided 
Room A24 due to the uncomfortable silence. Current-
ly, there is only one monster in these Rooms.
A22 . WATER PILLARS
The door to this Room is open. 
You hear the sound of trickling water as you ap-
proach. The sound comes from four pillars, one in 
each corner of the large room, with water channels 
cut into them.
Initial Attitude: Unfriendly 
Encounter: The running water imposes disadvantage 
on all Wisdom (Perception) checks to hear made by 
any creatures either while in the Room and trying 
to listen to noise within or outside the Room, or for 
creatures outside of the Room trying to make out 
noises from inside the Room.
Before the PCs have a chance to refresh them-
selves, they must contend with the ogre that is 
currently catching a rest here.
This Room, along with Rooms A23 and A24, is 
actually part of the original construction of the 
dungeon. The water that runs down the pillars is 
the result of a permanent create or destroy water 
effect that resides in a hole in the top of each pillar. 
Water flows down a channel cut into the pillar, 
which is somewhat larger at its base than at its top, 
and ends up in a small 1-ft. diameter and 1-ft. deep 
pool at the base of the pillar. Thanks to the magic, 
the system is constantly in balance, and as long as 
no more than two gallons of water are taken in any 
round, no drop in the water flow or in the pool will 
be noticed.
If detect magic is used on the pillars, they radiate 
a strong (but old) transmutation aura. Destroying 
the pillars destroys the magic. Although the original 

45
inhabitants did not need the water for survival, it is 
perfectly drinkable.
Except for the pillars, this Room is otherwise 
empty. There were once meditation mats but 
they are long gone. Rotted pieces might still be 
around the room.
Encounter Condition: Drafty or Poor Footing 2
Tactics: Bragdor the ogre is not the brightest of 
fellows, but even he knows when he is overmatched 
and the beasts that are crawling all over the dun-
geon intimidate even him. Of course, he can deal 
with the humanoids, and the PCs are ideal for 
taking out his frustrations.
Bragdor‚Äôs face is covered with scars from fight-
ing darkmantles. Though the wounds aren‚Äôt new, 
they haven‚Äôt completely healed yet. His greatclub 
has rat teeth buried throughout its length, partially 
as ornamentation and partially for effect. The han-
dle is wrapped in darkmantle skin. Bragdor carries 
a very sharp camp knife. He uses it mostly for odd 
jobs, not fighting. But it‚Äôll cut someone up pretty 
well in a pinch.
Even though he sits on the ground, resting 
his bulk against the northeastern pillar, Bragdor 
notices any light source moving down the hallway 
or coming from A23 readily enough, and once he 
spots it, he readies himself for some sport. Due to 
the noise of the water falling, he is unlikely to hear 
any creatures before they enter the Room unless 
they are making a lot of noise (the ogre suffers dis-
advantage on all Wisdom (Perception) checks made 
to listen). Depending on where the light is coming 
from, he attempts to hide his bulk behind a pillar 
(the northwestern pillar if the light comes from the 
hall or simply standing by the pillar he is resting 
against if the light is coming from Room A23).
If Bragdor manages to hide, he is actually 
difficult to Spot in the shadow of the pillar (DC 15 
Wisdom (Perception) check) until a light shines 
on him, at which point he is easily seen. Whether 
he is hidden or not, the moment he spots some-
thing, he takes a defensive pose, gauging how the 
PCs will act.
If forced to fight, Bragdor does not hold back. 
Like most ogres, Bragdor is a bully. As long as he 
feels that he has the advantage over his opponents, 
he gladly bashes them away with his huge club. 
Consider giving Bragdor an advantage on his next 
roll after a round in which he deals 10 or more 
points of damage.
If the PCs gain Bragdor‚Äôs respect, either by 
reducing him to one-half or fewer of his hit points 
using physical attacks or by causing at least 15 
points of damage from spell attacks, the ogre 
changes his tactics. He backs away from his foes 
toward the most tactically favorable position, using 
full defense while calling out for parley.
It is up to the PCs whether they parley or not. 
If PCs attack, Bragdor fights his way to one of the 
doorways and defends himself there, fighting to 
the death if no other option is available; he only 
makes the parley offer once. If the PCs accept his 
parley offer by lowering their weapons or verbally 
agreeing to it, Bragdor looks around warily before 
lowering his club.
The PCs may, if they choose, talk with the ogre. 
With his newfound respect for the PCs, he is happy 
to engage in conversation and even apologizes 
for any PCs that were injured or killed. Bragdor is 
capable of relating the details of the journey to the 
dungeon, the name of the orc leader (Orghar), the 
history and state of relations between the orcs and 
the other humanoids, as well as the sudden appear-
ance of various strange beasts that attacked every-
one. The exact details of such a conversation are left 
to the GM. Given the ogre‚Äôs rather simple mind, 
he is incapable of giving specific details on such 
things as directions or anything beyond simple 
impressions of the beasts (caped bats, big rodents, 
stinging flies).
He knows that Orghar has become more evil 
and violent in recent months? Years? How long 
has it been, he wonders. But he doesn‚Äôt know the 
source of this evil. Bragdor remains extremely 
scared of Orghar; the orc‚Äôs concentrated malev-
olence left a deep impression. Whenever talking 
about Orghar, Bragdor checks over his shoulder 
to see if the orc is nearby. He tries to avoid saying 
the name out loud, worried it might summon him, 
and performs odd, superstitious little tricks with his 
fingers, warding off the orc‚Äôs evil eye. 
If explicitly asked about Longtail, Bragdor has 
trouble remembering who it was, and the PCs 
may have to jog his memory with a description. 
Even then, all he can share is that the ‚Äúrat-man‚Äù 
has been gone for some time. Bragdor cannot 
make the connection between Longtail‚Äôs absence 

 46
and the appearance of the beasts in the dungeon 
on his own.
Once the PCs and Bragdor are done talking, 
they may wish to leave. He will not accompany 
them under any circumstances, stating that it 
would not be a good idea if he was seen with them 
because ‚ÄúOrghar might get mad.‚Äù 
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
Bragdor surprises the PCs, and no parley is allowed. 
To decrease the challenge of this encounter, reduce 
Bragdor‚Äôs hit points total ‚Äî he was injured from a 
previous fight.
A23 . PILLARS OF ILLUSION 
The doors to this Room are open. 
This room is even larger than the previous one, 
though these four large pillars seem to be made of 
something other than stone. There is a soft hum, 
clearly coming from the corners.

Encounter: The Room appears empty, and the pillars

lusion of fiendish creatures coming through cracks

less clues about Region A.

A25-A36 . THE MAZE 
The ‚ÄúMaze‚Äù, as the humanoids call it, is a mystery. 
Perhaps its maddening design kept prisoners from

quarters, countless doors, and winding halls were a 
perfect reminder of home for this particular tribe of 
troglodytes. 
Orghar had enough tactical acumen to realize that 
dozens of orcs could get bogged down in the ‚ÄúMaze‚Äù

on the reptilians; Orghar planned to deal with the

darkmantles that Longtail had released. Currently, the 
troglodytes hold the eastern Rooms in their grasp, 
having fought off the fiendish darkmantles in the

Due to the close quarters and the effects of the 
troglodyte musk, this is a dangerous area for even

The doors in the maze portion, that is, the doors

cated. Doors between hallways can open in either di-
rection; the decision is the GM‚Äôs. Note that any action

A25 . PILLAR ROOM 
All doors to and from this Room are open. 
A giant pillar, some 10 feet in diameter and rising 
from floor to ceiling, dominates this room. Defaced 
images cover every inch of the column, leaving no 
clue as to what they might have once been. Several

A28 . THE WHIMPERER IN DARK-
NESS
An orc corpse lies in the hallway just before the door, 
another victim of the fiendish darkmantles. If the PCs 
attempt to open the door, read the following. 
Pushing against the door, you sense resistance.
If the PCs push harder, read the following.
When you push a little harder, the door moves 
slightly before moving back towards you as if

Initial Attitude: Unfriendly
Encounter: The door is being held closed by Turag,

mantle swarm by seeking refuge in this Room even 
as his fellow orc was being killed right outside the

ing on for dear life. 
The PCs can force open the door by succeeding 
at an opposed Strength check against Turag (Turag 
has advantage on the check due to his Strength and 
the leverage the spear provides). But Turag cannot 
hold out forever. He loses advantage after five rolls 
(should he succeed that long). Turag whimpers all 
the while the PCs try opening the door.
Once the door is forced open, Turag retreats 
to the northwestern corner, grasping his battleaxe 
and trying to look as threatening as possible, even 
though he is shaking with fear. A DC 8 Wisdom 
(Insight) check reveals that the orc is clearly in no 
condition/mood for conflict.
If the PCs attack Turag, he goes down fighting 
(see tactics). If, on the other hand, the PCs make 
any friendly overtures, the orc falls to his knees, 
drops his battleaxe, and begins pleading with the 
PCs to help him escape.
Although this exchange should be role-played, 
the GM can resolve this through a DC 14 Charisma 
(Persuasion) check, with advantage if none of the

yikt (Room A69) and his kobolds are accompanying

and hold off the PCs by looking as threatening as is

If the PCs agree to help the orc, he is incredibly 
relieved and grateful, throwing himself at his rescu-
ers‚Äô feet and in general being subservient. Although 
he is still an orc, Turag is clever enough to know 
that, at least at this moment, the PCs are his only 
way of making it out alive and will do what he can 
to help them; he plays up the role of the servant 
to the maximum. He‚Äôs obsequious, eager to help, 
and always offering strange bits of proverbial orcish 
wisdom such as:
 
A dead badger in your sack is better than a live 
one in your trousers
 
Might as well kill the bastard now than regret not 
killing them later
 
The best way to catch a goblin is firmly by the 
throat.
The PCs could gain an NPC retainer out of this. Con-
versely, if a character has recently died, someone 
can play Turag for a while.
Naturally, this is largely lip service, and Turag 
avoids doing any actual work (especially fighting) 
unless absolutely necessary to defend himself or if 
he is threatened with abandonment or bodily harm. 
What Turag does should the PCs encounter a group 
of his brethren or a powerful antagonist Turag 
might feel inclined to throw his lot in with is up 
to the GM. Having some reliable comic relief in a 
campaign is always a good idea. Turag‚Äôs experiences 
in the region might be a useful way of imparting 
information the PCs otherwise miss. Of course, 
having a beloved NPC suddenly turn traitor is a 
dramatically effective move too. Do whatever suits 
your campaign best. 
If the PCs will not help, Turag accepts the judg-
ment with a shrug and returns morosely to his cor-
ner. The orc does not say anything to, or respond to 
anything from, the PCs from that point on. How-
ever, once the PCs leave the Room, Turag stealthily 
follows them, dogging their steps just out of range 
of any light sources. He is determined to follow the 
only chance he has at salvation. Even if caught at 
this game, Turag does not give it up unless the PCs 
kill him. If confronted about his actions, he whines 
and pleads ad nauseum, making a series of increas-
ingly implausible claims about his various talents. 

 50
Turag can relate the general events of the orc 
entry into the dungeon and their battles against

cading it against his fellow orcs) and was somehow

Turag cannot tell the PCs much of anything

Asking the orc about Longtail receives little

He has not seen the ‚Äúrat-man‚Äù in some time and

Encounter Condition: Concealment, Cover

If he joins the PCs, Turag stays out of combat,

Turag is a covert coward, however. He tries to be

A29 . CASUALTIES

51
Although primarily scavengers, this wave is actively

A30-A36 . SICK AND TIRED
The hallways and Rooms north of Room A30 and west 
of and A36 are the home of the troglodytes. PCs that 
enter the area are automatically considered poisoned 
the entire time they are within the area from the 
strong concentration of troglodyte musk that per-
vades the area. 
They must also succeed on a DC 11 Constitution 
save when within the hallways or Rooms A31, A35, 
and A36. On a failed save, the PC is nauseated (un-
able to attack, cast spells, concentrate on spells, or do 
anything else requiring attention; only a single move 
action per turn is possible) for 1 minute, after which 
time they continue to be poisoned for as long as they 
are in the area but can no longer be nauseated. Be-
cause of the massive concentration of musk, there is 
no need to roll for reactions to the musk of individual 
troglodytes while in this area.
As the PCs pass through this area, they notice a 
number of fiendish darkmantle corpses (roughly one 
every 10 ft.) the troglodytes killed as they retreated 
down the hall.
The only way to eliminate the sickening effect is to 
leave the area (either go south of Room A29 or east 
of Room A36), at which point the sickening effect 
remains for another 1d4 rounds.
There are a number of options for characters 
wishing to counter the smell. A rag dipped in vinegar 
(found in Rooms A5, A70, and A79), or alcohol, and 
worn as a mask negates the smell as it hits the PCs 
faces, thus eliminating the penalty. A magic-user with 
a spell like Gust of Wind can be used to dispel the 
noxious musk in a room, while more reckless PCs 
might try and burn it out.
The GM should be open to creative methods to try 
and overcome, or at least mitigate, the effects of the 
troglodyte musk.

A31 . A NOT-SO-TASTY MEAL 
The doors to this Room are open. 
The bodies of two troglodytes lie on the floor, ob-
viously suffocated to death. Stirges suck whatever 
blood remains in their desiccated corpses.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: These troglodytes met their fate as the

 

 

Two troglodyte warriors hide in the darkness in

marked with a ‚ÄúB‚Äù; both troglodytes occupy a single 
square). Although they blend in as well as they 
can, the fact is they have nowhere to hide and are

The remaining troglodytes hide behind the

 54
an eye on the hallway. They are much harder to

Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: Given the tight quarters in this area, the

notice any light sources in the hallway.
Unless the PCs have a way of knowing where the 
troglodytes are, or are especially cautious, the trog-
lodytes gain one surprise round before initiative is

tween the two alcoves one of the troglodytes from

Once combat begins, the troglodytes hold their

caught between the alcoves (the two in the alcoves 
receiving flanking bonuses) and the other three 
providing backup for any troglodyte that falls. Al-
though they secrete their musk, the smell is already 
so bad that it has no further effect on the PCs.
Knowing that they are trapped, the troglodytes 
fight to the death. They do everything they can to 
stop the PCs from reaching the wounded in Room 
A34. Given the chance, the troglodytes push the 
PCs back onto the darkmantle corpses, knowing

sible. During the surprise round, consider giving

Given recent history, the troglodytes consider

If the PCs retreat, the troglodytes do not pur-
sue, realizing they would be giving up a significant 
advantage by doing so. Since the rather desper-
ate troglodytes recognize that it was not orcs or 
beasts attacking them, allow a DC 16 Charisma 
(Persuasion) check if the PCs speak draconic (with 
advantage if no troglodytes were wounded or killed 
during the initial ambush), and attempt a parlay 
after retreating.
If Turag (from Room A28) is with the PCs and the 
troglodytes notice him, they demand to take him 
as a prisoner in exchange for information. Turag, 
of course, is against this plan but turns even more 
sniveling if the PCs appear to agree to an exchange. 
If Turag fought against the troglodytes, there is no 
chance of parley, and they focus their energies on 
killing the orc. The PCs are seen as allies and also 
dispatched without mercy. 
If parlay is successful, the PCs can speak to 
Yrkak, the troglodyte cleric from Room A34, though 
they are not past the alcoves. The lead troglodyte 
fetches him instead. The troglodytes share their 
own personal stories of the Region, but precious lit-
tle concerning Longtail and his plans. Yrkak recalls 
that when he last heard of Longtail the ‚Äúrat-man‚Äô‚Äô 
was heading to the east.
If the parley fails, the troglodytes leave the PCs 
alone as long as they do not return. In no way do 
the troglodytes join with the PCs. They are busy car-
ing for the wounded at the moment and enjoy their 
tactically sound position. Should the PCs render 
aid, they are most appreciative and offer them the 
acid flasks from Room A34.
Once the troglodyte warriors are healthy, the 
group attempts to leave the area. 
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
change two of the troglodytes to incensed berserk-
ers. Their claw and bite attacks do two addition-
al points of damage, and the first time they are 
reduced to 0 hit points, they make a Constitution 
saving throw. On a success, they stay standing with 
two hit points remaining. To decrease the challenge 
of this encounter, remove the two troglodytes 
behind the door. They are inside Room A34, and 
wounded instead. 

55
A33 . TROGLODYTE LIVING 
QUARTERS
The door to this room, as are all the doors in this

Several troglodytes lie in a fetal position on reed 
mats, otherwise this room appears to be empty.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: There are a total of six dead troglodytes

Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A

A34 . TROGLODYTE LIVING 
QUARTERS
The door to this room is open (as are all the doors in 
this section). 
Some badly wounded troglodytes lie on reed mats. 
Several others sit and sulk. One of them looks older 
and wiser, tending to the injured. In the south-
eastern corner is a collection of orc weapons, some 
armor, a pile of clothes, and a sack. 
Initial Attitude: Hostile 
Encounter: There are a total of seven wounded 
troglodytes (hp 8, 5, 5, 3, 0, 0, 0) within this Room. 
They are casualties of the fiendish darkmantle 
assault and are being tended to by Yrkak, a troglo-
dyte cleric.
Three of the wounded are incapacitated and at 0 
hit points, and the other four warriors are fatigued

Note: If the PCs rest somewhere after the ambush

Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: Yrkak is busy doing what he can for the

ment of spells to fight the fiendish darkmantles. If

lodytes see no chance for peace. The four wounded

There is a chance for the PCs to negotiate here, 
but it is slim.
Yrkak kills the three disabled warriors (taking 
three rounds to perform the coups de grace), rather 
than having them fall into enemy hands. He makes 
a prayer to his god as he does, granting him advan-
tage on his next three die rolls after this. The mercy 
killings Yrkak carries out prove to be a mistake, 
however. In 1d4+1 turns, the dead warriors return 
to life as ghouls and proceed to attack the nearest 
target ‚Äî whether troglodyte or PC. They‚Äôve been 
inflicted with the same fiendish contamination as 
the orc the PCs might have encountered earlier. 
Should these ghouls somehow remain in the dun-
geon for a month or more, they gain the fiendish 
template as well.
Once Yrkak has finished with the three dis-
abled warriors, Yrkak joins any remaining war-
riors in combat, throwing the acid flasks at the 
strongest PCs. If the PCs have rested before en-
tering the room, he has his full complement of 
spells restored.

 56
Everyone fights to the death.
Treasure: Yrkak has an amber holy symbol of his god 
(100 gp) on a leather thong around his neck, a jav-
elin, a potion of healing (which he is saving for the

The troglodytes have collected a number of scav-
enged items from some of the dead orcs. There are 
some suits of leather armor, some clubs, and axes. 
All of it is crudely made, but valuable in a pinch 
should the PCs be running low on supplies.
There‚Äôs also an orc pack that no one has gone 
through yet. It contains two bottles, 12 feet of

stone inside, special wine in a wineskin, and a jar

ing alcoholic beverage that doubles as a cure light

and the potion is wasted. Otherwise, it works nor-
mally, but tastes horrible.
The lodestone compass always points north, 
except when around magical areas, in which case it

The wineskin is well made and looks custom. 
It contains a delicious human wine that was once 
worth roughly 100 gp.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter,

al (they are still wounded but not exhausted) and

crease the challenge of this encounter, make all the

Four large Rooms encompass A37 through A40,

 Several large workbenches are arranged in a

A39 . DESTROYED WORKSHOP

stone on an orc‚Äôs hand (105 gp); six sets of the gold 
kobold horn caps (5 gp per each cap for a total of 60 
gp); an electrum earring in a kobolds ear (3 gp); a 
spear that lays near Borryn; a blue coral necklace (6 
gp) torn from the neck of an orc; a gold pendant in 
the shape of a tree (25 gp) around a kobolds throat; 
a pair of fine leather boots (50 gp) on the feet 
of an orc. 
An additional item of interest is a large chest sit-
uated in the southwestern corner of the Room that 
has an orc corpse slumped across it. This was the 
kobold chieftain‚Äôs personal chest and is locked with 
an average lock (DC 15 Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Tools)); it 
is not trapped. It contains a bolt of purple silk (10 
square yards; 100 gp), a plain gold circlet (25 gp), 
five sacks of copper pieces (523 cp total), two sacks 
of silver pieces (147 sp total), one sack of gold pieces 
(92 gp total), a small pouch of platinum pieces (17 
pp total), and two pouches of gems (21 total gems 
of 4d4 gp in value). 
Note that searching for treasure can leave the 
PCs distracted (disadvantage on Perception checks) 
during the arrival of the fiendish rat swarms from 
Room A44. 
Scaling: N/A
A44 . KRENSHAR STABLES 
Both doors to this area are open. To the west is an 
opening devoid of a door.
This description assumes the PCs approach from 
the west. If they enter the Room from the southeast, 
ignore the ‚Äúdevoid of bodies‚Äù line.
This open area is divided by several walls into 
smaller individual spaces. The ceiling is extremely 
high as well, disappearing into the darkness. Straw 
is scattered across the floor, with animal dung 
throughout. The area is eerily devoid of bodies 
given the carnage in other rooms, though the 
smell of death is present. The sounds of something 
ominous can be heard around one of the many 
dividing walls.
Note: This is a complicated encounter.
Initial Attitude: Hostile 
Encounter: Currently, there are a number of fiendish 
creatures in the Room, keeping to their respective 
places but on the verge of attack.
Two fiendish snake swarms wait in the north-
eastern corner for the fiendish rat swarms to leave 
the near center of the Room. Meanwhile, three 
fiendish darkmantles cling to the ceiling, some 80 
feet in the air.
This Room was used by the kobolds to stable 
their krenshar mounts. The kobold and mounts 
attempted to hold this area in the face of the orc 
onslaught but succeeded only in getting killed. 
Bloated maggots and pus-filled centipedes feed on 
the corpses, especially since the rats and snakes are 
waiting to feed. 
These waves followed a fiendish darkmantle 
swarm that had been released by Longtail and 
came to this Room directly from Room A108 via the 
one-way secret door in the western wall (see Room 
A108 for a complete description). Although the PCs 

63
may well decide to explore the eastern hallway, the 
nature of the secret door to Room A108 prevents 
them from entering Longtail‚Äôs chapel (unless they 
have the tools to chip through solid rock).
Should the PCs investigate, they will find two 
dead krenshar, one in the northwestern portion and 
the other in the southeastern portion, and two dead 
kobolds in the doorways in the corner. It is possible 
the PCs have never seen anything like these crea-
tures before. They look like deranged cat wolves 
without ears and spikey hair.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: All three groups are on constant guard 
against one another. They‚Äôve been locked in a stale-
mate for days, waiting for the other to make a mis-
take. The presence of the PCs throws this balance 
into disarray, though. Some of the creatures will 
turn on the PCs, and some will turn on each other.
If the snake swarm from Room A42 has already 
summoned the snake swarms here, they are gone 
and the rat swarms have scattered to various cor-
ners of the Room. In this case, the PCs are left to 
face the rats and darkmantles at the same time.
If the snakes haven‚Äôt fled, or there are more 
snakes here from Room A42, the rat and snake 
swarms turn on one another, though some turn on 
the PCs as well. Should the PCs try to take advan-
tage of the infighting, the swarms stop fighting one 
another and fight the PCs.
The fiendish darkmantles wait for the perfect op-
portunity to ambush anything that moves, whoever 
is weakest.
In all, this encounter is an orgy of violence that 
should consume a lot of PC resources.
To make matters worse, Longtail may send 
Achsyyx from Room A103 if he hears the commo-
tion. If the PCs are 3rd level or higher, there is a 3 
in 20 chance for Achsyyx to appear after the combat 
is over. Additionally, there is a 1 in 20 chance that 
Longtail is with him. See Rooms A103 and A104. If 
they do arrive, however, they are likely to fall back to 
a safe position after a few rounds of fighting. They 
are only here as a scouting operation.
Additionally, the fight may proceed long enough 
to draw a random encounter.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge, add one more 
fiendish rat swarm and one more fiendish dark-
mantle. To decrease the challenge of this encoun-
ter, remove all of the fiendish darkmantles, but 
give the PCs the impression that something could 
be up there.
A45 . BARRICADED HALLWAY 
All the doors in and out of this hallway are open and 
partially damaged. They will never lock again. 
The bones of two large felines and a pair of kobolds 
are strewn about the hallway. Their clothing is torn. 
Rat carcasses litter the hallway as well. Centipedes 
and worms burrow through the remains. Makeshift 
barricades and battlements are nothing but splin-
tered wood now. But what was once an important 
front line is nothing now.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: Protruding from the skull of the larger 
kobold is a crude, oversized knitting needle. It was 
improvised as a weapon during the fight by an orc 
and left there. The kobold weapons were stolen and 
taken back with the surviving orcs.
This Room was under constant patrol and de-
fense by two kobolds and two krenshars when the 
orcs attacked. Arriving simultaneously from both 
the east and west, the orcs slaughtered the kobold 
guards, sustaining no casualties themselves and 
leaving the bodies as a message to the others. The 
fiendish rat swarms came to feed on what re-
mained, having their way with the corpses, but they 
too died when orcs returned to retrieve their dead.
Now, maggots and vile-looking centipedes 
worm through the flesh of the dead, just like in 
Room A44. 
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A 
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: N/A

 64
A46-A56 . NO MAN'S LAND
Covering Rooms A46 through A56, this core portion 
of the Region was not claimed by the orcs or rep-
tilians and served as neutral ground ‚Äî when the 
alliance was held. It was simply a pragmatic matter to 
deem the area free of hostilities, lest everyone perpet-
ually have knives to their figurative throats. 
Although some parts of the area did see heavy 
fighting ‚Äî no treaty is perfect ‚Äî large parts of this 
area were left alone for a long time. A number of un-
discovered secrets, traps, and treasures remain.
A46 . WORKSHOP 
The western door to this room is locked, but simple 
enough to pick, or break open with a DC 16 Dexterity 
(Sleight of Hand) or Strength (Athletics) check. 
The southeastern door to this room is closed and 
trapped. Draconic writing on the door reads ‚ÄúDan-
ger. Do Not Enter.‚Äù The doorway is trapped with an 
automatically resetting burning hands trap. The trap 
activates the moment any creature opens the door to 
Room A46. It shoots down from the ceiling in a cone 
shape, striking the square in front of the door on 
both sides. Because the vent is built into the archway, 
this trap is nearly impossible to spot. 
 '
Burning Hands Trap. Deals 3d6 fire damage in a 
15-foot cone. Creatures take half damage on a 
successful DC 8 Dexterity saving throw. DC 25 Wis-
dom (perception) check to find, DC 16 Intelligence 
(Arcana) check to disarm. Automatically resets when 
the door closes.
Read the following once the PCs open the door.
Although this room is now empty, you can all but 
guess at its previous purpose. A complete forge 
sits in one corner. A large workbench, along with 
two stools, dominates the center, while there are 
numerous hooks and nails on the wall, indicating a 
place where tools were once kept. A hallway leads 
on past this area.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: This was at one time a workshop. The 
place was cleaned out, but the forge couldn‚Äôt be 
moved. Although covered with dust, the forge is 
still functional if fuel is found.
There is a 3 in 20 chance of finding a fiendish 
fire mephit trapped in the furnace.  Silver-inscribed 
runes keep the mephit here. If the runes are bro-
ken, cracked, or somehow erased, the mephit es-
capes or returns to its home plane (GM‚Äôs choice). If 
the fire mephit is antagonized with water or liquids, 
it erupts in a ball of expansive flame, much like the 
trap in this Room.
Encounter Condition: Safe
Tactics: Assuming the PCs survive the trap or bypass 
it, this is an excellent Room to rest. 
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase the trap damage to 5d6, and the likelihood 
of a fiendish fire mephit being present to 7 in 20. 
To decrease the challenge of this encounter, reduce 
the trap damage to 2d6, and allow the fiendish fire 
mephit to grant one minor boon if it is freed.
A47 . LABORATORY
Several tables are pushed up along the sides of this 
room, along with a trio of stools. 
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: This was a magical laboratory. Unlike the 
one in Room A40, this one did not sustain any ma-
jor damage. The valuable equipment was cleaned 
out, but a couple of items were left behind. 
PCs examining the tables can note discoloration 
and burn marks from the use of various chemicals 
during the experiments. A DC 10 Intelligence (In-
vestigation) check of the Room reveals several piles 
of glass shards from broken beakers and contain-
ers. Bare-foot creatures have avoided the Room for 
this very reason.
Encounter Condition: Distracting Noises or Haunted
Tactics: N/A 
Treasure: A PC willing to search (DC 20 Intelligence 
(Investigation) check) through the glass shards is 
rewarded with a small, flawed diamond (500 gp).

65
More importantly, the owner of the lab created 
three hiding places for some of his lesser creations.
The first is a small metal box, about 4 inches in 
length, 4 inches in width, and 2 inches in height, 
that attaches under one of the tables and is found 
relatively easily with a DC 11 Intelligence (Investiga-
tion) check. 
This box is trapped with a poison blade holding 
greenblood oil weakened with age. The razor-sharp 
blade releases when the box is opened, slicing 
across the box opening and cutting into flesh. A 
PC that shakes the box hears small objects rattling 
within. Unfortunately, this box is a red herring and 
contains only a few pebbles. 
 '
Poison Blade Trap. +7 to hit, one target within 20 
ft. On a hit, the target takes 1d6 piercing damage 
and must succeed on a DC 8 Constitution saving 
throw or suffer 1 point of Constitution damage for 
24 hours. A creature immune to poison is immune 
to this effect. DC 17 Wisdom (Perception) check 
to find, DC 11 Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Yools) check 
to disarm.
A second hiding place is behind one of the rocks 
of the furnace. The mechanism is actually a flat 
piece of rock attached to a metal flap that is lifted 
to gain access to the space behind; it is revealed 
by a more difficult DC 18 Investigation check. This 
hiding place is also guarded by a spring-loaded 
punching dagger blade that flies out the moment 
the rock flap is lifted, punching itself into the face 
or chest of the person opening the door. The blade 
is coated with greenblood oil that has lost much of 
its potency. 
 '
Punching Dagger Trap. +7 to hit one target. On a 
hit, the target takes 1d6 piercing damage and must 
succeed on a DC 8 Constitution saving throw or 
suffer 1 point of Constitution damage for 24 hours. 
A creature immune to poison is immune to this 
effect. DC 17 Wisdom (Perception) check to find, DC 
11 Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Tools) check to disarm.
Located in the hollow space behind the mech-
anism are three arcane scrolls ‚Äî magic missile, 
guidance, and flaming sphere. 
The final location is the most difficult to find 
(DC 22 Intelligence (Investigation) check) and is 
actually a hollow stool leg that contains a wand of 
acid arrow (17 charges). The wand gives no clue as to 
its function and identify only reveals the command 
word (bahris-kyh). If the PCs detect magic, the wand 
radiates magic, but no school can be discovered.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
restore the potency of the greenblood oil poison. To 
reduce the challenge, remove the poison.
A48 . COLLAPSING  
ENERGY FIELD 
The door to this area is closed and has draconic writ-
ing on it that warns ‚ÄúDanger. Do Not Enter.‚Äù
A large, shimmering ruby-red crystal about the 
height of a human floats in the center of the cham-
ber some three feet off the ground. The ever-present 
energy of both good and evil can be felt stepping 
into the room.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: The ruby red crystal is the remnant of 
an energy field that once held a minor devil. It lost 
its primary function when the fiend escaped, but 
it still has enough energy to be dangerous should 
any person or object disturb its surface. The kobolds 
never touched it, sensing something dangerous 
about the stone.
The shimmering is actually a result of the slow 
ebbing of the field‚Äôs energy. Disturbing the energy 
field‚Äôs surface in a physical manner, be it through 
touch, using a pole, throwing a stone, etc., caus-
es the protective field to collapse in on itself and 
release the remaining energy in a 20 ft. radius all 
around the ruby. This release causes 3d4 points of 
force damage to all within the radius. Those caught 
in the blast can attempt a DC 12 Dexterity saving 
throw to take only half damage. There is no way to 
disarm the energy field. 
Encounter Condition: Drafty, Safe (if the PCs leave 
the ruby alone)
Tactics: The first time a PC speaks within earshot of 
the crystal, a devilish laugh echoes off the energy 
field. The sound pierces through the quiet of the 
area, alerting all the nearby Rooms that some-
one is here.
Treasure: N/A 

 66
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase the force damage to 4d6. To decrease 
the challenge of this encounter, reduce the force 
damage to 2d4 and the radius to 15 ft.
A49 . THE LONG HALLWAY 
All the doors leading into this hallway are open. 
The length of this room extends beyond the edge 
of your light source. Here lies an orc corpse, there 
rests a dead kobold, and over there, a flying octo-
pus, with three of its tentacles severed, lies limp 
against the wall. Bones and other bits against 
another wall. The lengthy chamber is a miasma of 
corpses and debris. Scuffles have obviously been 
happening here for a while.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: The key to controlling Region A lies in 
controlling this hallway, as it affords access to the 
rest of the dungeon. Orghar made it one of his key 
objectives when planning the orc assault. Although 
they were officially neutral, the kobolds realized the 
significance of this hallway, as well, and always kept 
a guard force nearby. Although numerically supe-
rior, the orcs had difficulty controlling the hallway 
due to the presence of Boyikt, a kobold wizard, and 
his brother Borryn. However, as with the battle in 
the kobold stronghold (Rooms A41 through A45), 
the sudden appearance of extraplanar beasts ended 
the fight in a way neither side anticipated.
Numerous dead lie in the hallway, including 
orcs, kobolds, a couple of krenshar, fiendish stirges, 
fiendish darkmantles, and even some fiendish dire 
rats (exact numbers up to the GM). Otherwise, the 
hall is strangely empty.
The smell is nearly as bad as the musk in the 
northwest corner of the region.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: Given the importance of this place and the 
numerous paths for access, the GM should roll 
for Random Encounters while the PCs are in the 
Room. One roll when the PCs enter and another 
just before they leave is ideal, although there can 
certainly be more.
These encounters need not be hostile, though 
some creatures will be shocked to see humans 
(and their ilk) in the dungeon. Some might even 
have questions.
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: Varies
A50 . KOBOLD GUARD POST 
The doors to this Room are open. 
Shackled to the wall in the southwestern corner is 
the skeleton of a kobold, standing over a reddish 
and green slime. The skeleton moves and twitches, 
kicking harder when someone approaches, but it is 
no use. The slime bubbles and gurgles, mimicking 
the pattern of your footsteps. 
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: Although neutral by agreement, the 
kobolds kept a regular group of guards here. When 
the orcs attacked, the guards joined the battle in the 
hallway (Room A49).
Both the skeleton and slime radiate necro-
mantic magic.
Boyikt used his magic to turn some of the dead 
kobolds into skeletal warriors to join the fight. This 
one refused to stay down and they had to shackle 
it to the wall. The slime at his feet is the brain his 
skull once housed, now dissolved into a bloody goo. 

67
Should anyone cast dispel magic onto the brain, it 
returns to the shape of a kobold brain.
PCs investigating the Room have a chance to 
spot a metal plate trigger in the floor at the north-
west corner. When pressure is applied and kept on 
the plate, a loud click can be heard. When pressure 
is released, the click is heard again. This turns off 
and turns on the hallucination trap in Room A97. 
It wouldn‚Äôt take more than a few pounds of weight 
on the plate to keep the trap turned off. PCs won‚Äôt 
know what it goes to, but they will know it does 
something.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A 
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: N/A
A51 . "THE COFFIN"
The door to this Room is closed. The smell here 
is as bad as the musk in the northwest corner of 
the Region.
Several skeletons of varying sizes lie about the 
room, rags hanging off their bones. The smell is 
almost unbearable, forcing you to cover your nose.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: Given the Room‚Äôs isolation, it is ideal for 
body disposal. All manner of humanoid and beast 
has been thrown here over the centuries creating a 
distinct pile of bones and rotting flesh.
A large stone grind wheel has been turned over, 
but closer inspection shows it was used to grind 
bone years ago. Rust and decay have rendered it 
less than useful.
Encounter Condition: Safe
Tactics: There is a 1 in 20 chance of encountering a 
pair of kobolds or orcs disposing of a body while 
the PCs are present. They are not ready for a fight 
and may just want to step away, unless the PCs 
press for combat. There is an additional 1 in 20 
chance of a fiendish rat swarm having a meal. If 
neither of those events happens, there is a 3 in 20 
chance of a fiendish snake swarm present in the 
body pile, though it finds no need to attack unless 
necessary. There is plenty to eat.
Treasure: Some bone dust lies on the ground. 
Enough can be gathered to be used to create pro-
tection circles and the like as a powerful material 
component. A DC 18 Intelligence (Arcana) check 
reveals this information to a wizard or warlock. If it 
is used in this manner, it doubles the duration of 
the protection circle. 
Scaling: N/A
A52 . SECRET THRONE ROOM
The door to this Room is open. 
This large room has a simple throne carved from 
stone situated near the eastern end. Bits of chain 
and iron rings hammered into stone unleash a 
sense of dread. The taste and smell of something 
fiendish permeates the air. The sounds of groans 
and soft crying can be heard, but no one is there. It 
is as though the walls themselves are in pain.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: It is unclear who altered this Room and 
used it for evil, but minions were tortured here for 
the viewing pleasure of whosoever sat upon the 
throne. Sharp-eyed PCs can pick out numerous 
large rust-red stains on the floor (DC 14 Wisdom 
(Perception) check), the blood of those exe-
cuted here.
The throne is non-descript, having an almost 
alien appearance to the thrones of human kings. It 
has been hewn from a single piece of rock ‚Äî just 
the right size for a dwarf or similar-sized creature. 
Two red gems are cut into the backrest, like eyes 
staring back at the PCs. Shadowy forms inside 
the gems enhance the creepiness of a parei-
dolic headrest.
There is a definite unease about this cursed 
throne. The vile deeds perpetuated by its owner 
have warped the stone into something evil and 
hateful. Any living creature who touches the throne 
is subject to the curse and must succeed at a DC 14 
Wisdom saving throw (rolled in secret by the GM). 
If the save fails, the cursed creature is afflicted with 
confusion but does not notice the change. If the 
save is made, the PC is still cursed but aware that 
something strange has taken place.
The PC is not aware of the curse at first and acts 
outwardly normal. However, anytime the PC is in a 

 68
stressful situation, such as combat or trying to per-
form a skill check quickly, the confusion surfaces.
Roll on the following table the first round that a 
PC is confused.
D20BeHavior
1-5
Attack the nearest ally (for this purpose, a 
familiar counts as part of the subject‚Äôs self )
6-7
Become nauseated (unable to attack, cast 
spells, concentrate on spells, or do anything 
else requiring attention. The only action 
such a creature can take is a single move 
action per turn)
8-13
Cower (take no actions, ‚Äì2 penalty to Armor 
Class and loses his Dexterity bonus)
14-18
Flee away from the area at the top pos-
sible speed
19-20
Twitch uncontrollably (‚Äì2 penalty on attack 
rolls, saving throws, skill checks, and 
ability checks)
The confused condition passes the moment im-
mediately thereafter or when a stressful situation 
passes. Note that the curse can afflict any number 
of creatures and can be countered just like the spell 
bestow curse.
Otherwise, the curse lasts for a number of days 
equal to 16 minus the PCs Wisdom score at the time 
of the curse (minimum two days).
The painful sounds emanating in the room grow 
louder the longer the PCs remain. Tormented spirits, 
though not manifesting as threats, still live within the 
blood, chains, and walls. They will remain here forever 
until a cleric or other holy person casts a spell that 
can release them. Even something as simple as bless 
might do it.
PCs who get too close to the chains and iron rings 
find themselves grappling with animated chains. 
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase the Wisdom saving throw DC to 17. To re-
duce the challenge of this encounter, the curse lasts 
only one day.
A53 . WESTERN GALLERY
Rooms A53 and A54 share the space, though encoun-
ters are slightly different.
The southern door in the hallway is open. Read the 
following description once the PCs have moved down 
the hall and turned west. 
A number of skeletons from a range of creatures 
hang on the walls spaced equally apart, iron spikes 
visible below their bones. More bones dot the floor, 
spread out and broken.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: After the demons broke out, hundreds of 
years ago, they took over portions of the dungeon 
in a mad orgy of violence. For a time, Room A53 
served as a ‚Äúgallery of torture.‚Äù During its time, the 
walls held the mounted corpses of a number of 
creatures from drow to duergar and every human-
oid in between. Since then, time has reduced the 
corpses to skeletons making it more difficult to 
identify the individual species of each.
The exact composition of the bodies is up to 
the GM; any humanoid up to Large size is present. 
Given the limited encounters that the PCs of levels 
1 to 3 have had with humanoids, they probably can‚Äôt 
identify the various creatures, although such things 
as an ogre, an orc, a dwarf, an elf, a halfling, etc. 
might be familiar.
Once complete, a number of the skeletons are 
missing such things as a head, an arm, a leg, etc. 
Casting animate dead on these bones produces truly 
disturbing skeletons.
Encounter Condition: Distracting Visions or Haunted
Tactics: N/A 
Treasure: Some personal effects might be found 
among the bones, but nothing of immediate value. 
Bracelets, rings, dull knives, earrings, costume 
jewelry, and combs (for instance) are among the 
various items strewn around the room.
Scaling: N/A

69
A54 . EASTERN GALLERY
Rooms A53 and A54 share the space, though encoun-
ters are slightly different.
The southern door in the hallway is open. Read the 
following description once the PCs have moved down 
the hall and turned east. 
A number of skeletons from different creatures 
hang on the walls spaced equally apart, iron spikes 
visible below their bones. More bones dot the floor, 
spread out and broken.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: Identical to Room A53 in shape, this 
Room houses the more unusual skeletons of the 
collection, such as mummified lamia, and the 
rotted carcass of a two-headed wolf-dog-creature 
(exact composition is up to the GM) all mounted on 
iron spikes.
Encounter Condition: Distracting Noises or Haunted
Tactics: N/A 
Treasure: A half-suit of bone armor hangs from an 
iron peg. It is made for a larger-than-average hu-
man but provides armor protection like chain mail. 
Scaling: N/A
A55 . GUARD ROOM 
The door to this Room is closed.
Pieces of broken furniture and a dirty floor indicate 
someone once lived here. A single broken bed lies 
near the center of the room. Rubble and rags have 
been piled up in the northeastern corner. The smell 
of unwashed feet and disgusting food linger in the 
air. One can almost imagine orcs still living in here.
Initial Attitude: Varies 
Encounter: Behind the rubble is a near-dead orc (1 
hp), who was left behind during the last retreat 
through here. The other orcs assumed he was dead 
when he didn‚Äôt respond. Rather than leave their 
friend out in the open, they left him behind the 
rubble. They took his weapons and personal effects, 
however, leaving him with pants and boots.
How he escaped the notice of the fiendish crea-
tures nearby is anyone‚Äôs guess.
The orc has numerous wounds and a dented 
skull. If the PCs are able to heal him and bring him 
back, he has amnesia. He doesn‚Äôt even know his 
own name. He does not speak Common and may 
not be able to communicate with the PCs. The orc 
will not join the PCs and will run the first chance 
he gets. If forced to help, he will pretend to be an 
ally before running into the dungeon when they are 
not watching.
Stats are not provided for this orc. If the PCs 
choose to kill him, the fight is over quickly.
Encounter Condition: Deep Darkness
Tactics: Four rounds after the PCs have been in the 
Room, four hungry fiendish darkmantles enter 
looking for a quick meal. They immediately turn 
the Room dark with their aura and then descend 
to feed. They fight desperately and to the death in 
some depraved fashion. They make hungry, gnash-
ing noises that impart disadvantage to the PCs 
during the first round of combat. 
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
have the orc turn on one of the PCs in a fit of fear 
and panic. He tries to steal an item and run away 
with it or bash someone from behind with a rock. 
To reduce the challenge of this encounter, reduce 
the number of fiendish darkmantles to three.
A56 . GUARD ROOM
The door to this Room is closed.
A broken table lies upturned against one wall, while 
a heavy wooden chest leans against the table. The 
walls and floors are non-descript, though there are 
dozens of tally marks cut into one wall. Along the 
floor are various, tiny torn pieces of paper.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: This Room served as the home of a guard 
captain, but any functioning furniture was cleaned 
out during a regroup and retreat. The table was left 
alone as it had no value. The chest was left because 
it holds a special trap.
The chest contains a silver dagger wrapped in 
the skin of a darkmantle. The skin has been care-
fully cut from the organs, stretched, and made into 
a wrap, or small cloak. It‚Äôs unclear of its intend-
ed purpose.

 70
 Once the skin is unraveled a glyph of warding 
is exposed. The glyph of warding (explosive runes) 
affects only the character holding the skin, dealing 
5d8 lightning damage and forcing the character 
to scream in pain. A successful DC 15 Constitution 
saving throw halves the damage and the character 
does not scream. The dagger is not affected by the 
spell.wwwScattered on the floor are tiny shreds 
of paper, perhaps from a journal or log. Whatever 
was written on them was in another language, and 
few full words remain. PCs may attempt to piece 
it together, revealing a kobold letter detailing the 
mind-numbing work of being a guard.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A 
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase the saving throw DC of glyph of warning 
by 2. To decrease the challenge of this encounter, 
decrease the saving throw DC of glyph of warn-
ing by 2.  
A57-A77 . EARTHQUAKE DAMAGE
Both the reptilians and orcs avoid the area covering 
Rooms A57 through A77 and the hallways in between. 
Almost destroyed in the heavy earthquakes that dam-
aged the entire complex, the area is unstable. Chunks 
of the ceiling lay everywhere, making it an easy place 
to hide in but a difficult place to maneuver through. 
When the occasional tremor rumbles through this 
portion of the complex, it causes more dust, dirt, and 
rocks to fall from the ceiling, giving the entire area a 
sense of imminent annihilation; no creature willingly 
makes its home here. 
That is not to say that there are not currently some 
residents. Extraplanar scavengers roam the area hop-
ing to find an easy meal. A handful of reptilian refu-
gees also hide in the area, hoping to escape notice. 
The unstable and damaged condition of the area 
creates an interesting tactical situation for the PCs 
and any creatures that rely on land movement. The 
rubble that is strewn everywhere hampers movement 
throughout the entire area; each square moved costs 
double. The rubble also prevents any land-based 
charges or running throughout the entire area. Final-
ly, any land-based attempts to Stealth are rolled with 
disadvantage due to the rock and grit underfoot.
Note: Major tremors in this Section have the 
potential to collapse parts of tunnels, sections of 
Rooms, block doors, etc., making it even more diffi-
cult to move through the area or even get out at all. If 
a door or passage is blocked by rocks, it requires 1d20 
minutes to clear the space for a Medium creature to 
squeeze through.
A57 . NEARLY EMPTY ROOM
The door to this Room has been wedged partial-
ly open by the earthquake and requires a DC 18 
Strength check to force it completely open.
Darker than most rooms, rubble and dust cover the 
floor. Squinting your eyes, you can see a small boot 
sticking from behind a stack of rocks.
Initial Attitude: Varies
Encounter: This Room appears empty, but if the PCs 
investigate they find the boot is on the foot of a hal-
fling near death. The halfing is hiding from nearby 
creatures and hoping for some kind of intervention.
The purpose of this encounter is two-fold. 
One, this is a chance for the PCs to meet an NPC 
who may or may not join the group. Two, if a PC 
has died, this halfling could be their replacement. 
Therefore, the name, class, and gender of the hal-
fling are left for the gamemaster to define.
If the halfling remains an NPC, he/she/they 
slipped into the dungeon by accident a few weeks 
ago and snuck around in the dark avoiding the 
dangers. The halfling doesn‚Äôt know where the major 
factions are in this area, but might be able to draw 
a crude map of earthquake hallways.
The halfling knows there are nearby monsters 
and speaks quietly. The halfling is also slathered 
in some kind of oil and musk that is reminiscent 
of skunk and lavender. It is strange, but not over-
whelming. It conceals his/her/their scent from the 
nearby rats.

71
Encounter Condition: Tremors 14
Tactics: Allow any creatures or random encounters 
(perhaps prep them after this) in Rooms A58, A60, 
A61, and A62 to roll Wisdom (Perception) checks at 
advantage opposed by a Stealth check by whoever 
opened the door to Room A57.
Should the PCs decide to kill the halfling, the 
combat is over in seconds, but the creatures in 
Room A58 definitely hear it without requiring a roll.
Note: If the PCs have already dealt with the 
other monsters, ignore the concerns about noise. 
though the halfling may be more ready for the 
group in such a case.
Treasure: The halfling carries a wineskin, two more 
days of rations, a perfume bottle with oily perfume, 
a torch, some rope, and a personal weapon. If the 
PCs have already made a level or two before arriving 
here, the weapon is magical.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
place a small hole in the wall between Rooms A57 
and A58. Something might come through when 
the PCs least expect it, or the creatures in Room 
A58 already hear the PCs coming. To decrease the 
challenge of this encounter, do not allow the nearby 
creatures an advantage of any Wisdom (Percep-
tion) checks.
A58 . FIENDISH MEPHITS 
The earthquake forced both doors off their hinges. 
They lay on a pile of rubble just inside the doorway. 
The western one is far worse than the eastern one, 
which acts as a semi-barrier to entry.
This rubble-strewn room appears to have an exit; 
you can make out the top half of a door in the 
wall across from this doorway. Darkness and dust 
shroud the contents as strange shadows dance on 
the walls.
Initial Attitude: Hostile 
Encounter: This Room is filled with rubble. Parts of 
the ceiling have given way, collapsing inward, along 
with dirt and granite. There appears to be three 
fiendish darkmantles among the rocks near the 
center of the room. However, they are exceptionally 
difficult to distinguish from dust, dirt, and boulders 
(DC 25 Wisdom (Perception) check).
Also hiding amongst the rocks is a fiendish dire 
rat. It waits to feed on whatever falls into its lap. It 
is not aggressive, but will defend itself.
Encounter Condition: Poor Footing 4
Tactics: The well-camouflaged fiendish darkmantles 
are, in fact, fiendish steam mephits wearing the 
hides of dead darkmantles. Most likely, the mephits 
gain surprise and can move and attack before the 
PCs. They roll initiative separately, acting as unique 
individuals. The mephits wait until a PC is within 10 
ft. to attack, throwing off the dead skin onto the PC, 
and then taking action.
The first mephit casts misty step (which lasts 
for 1 minute) and teleports to behind the PCs, the 
second mephit uses its steam attack, and the third 
mephit flies into melee range with an exposed PC, 
using its claw attack. Mix it up round after round, 
after this.
Treat the mephit‚Äôs use of the darkmantle skin as 
a ranged attack, at advantage. If a mephit hits, that 
character is blinded until an action is spent remov-
ing the skin. If the attack fails, the skin falls to the 
ground with no effect.
The fiendish dire rat only fights if it needs to, 
helping the mephits flank if the opportunity arises. 
The mephits tolerate the rat and vice versa, though 
they turn on one another if the need arises, most 
likely after the fight is over.
The rubbled floor creates uneven footing for the 
PCs meaning any Dexterity check or saving throw 
is made with disadvantage. This does not affect the 
fiendish steam mephits, nor the fiendish dire rat.
Misty step works up to 30 feet, so one of the 
fiendish steam mephits can teleport just out-
side the door or to the other side of the Room if 
necessary.
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter 
add two fiendish dire rats and have them en-
gage the PCs aggressively. To decrease the chal-
lenge, remove the darkmantle skins from two of 
the mephits.
A59 . CLOSET 
The earthquake caused the lintel above the door 
to collapse. As a result, the door requires a DC 15 

 72
Strength check to open, which causes the lintel to 
collapse further, like a falling block trap.
 '
Falling Block Trap. +7 to hit one target (whoever 
opened the door). On a hit, the target suffers 3d6 
bludgeoning damage. DC 12 Intelligence (Investiga-
tion) check to find, DC 16 Strength (Athletics) check 
to disarm.
 Once the door is opened, read the following text. 
Peering through the narrow juncture, you can see a 
number of opened chests lined against one wall of 
this small room. 
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: The Room contains four opened and 
emptied wooden chests of varying sizes and qual-
ities and one closed one. Some torn sacks lie on 
the floor as well. Some soiled blankets remain from 
when someone used this Room to rest. Metal shav-
ings and chipped stone lie inside one of the chests, 
where someone has sharpened a blade.
Inside the closed chest is a warlock‚Äôs familiar, a 
cat. During a fight, the cat hid in the chest and it 
snapped shut. He‚Äôs been in there for days, unable 
to get out. The warlock is presumed dead, but 
is actually alive in Room A99. The cat‚Äôs name is 
Gypsum, though it‚Äôs a cat so it won‚Äôt respond to the 
name anyway.
The PCs are welcome to take the cat with them, 
though the cat still behaves like a cat despite its 
high intelligence. Should the PCs attempt to com-
municate with the cat (using empathy, magic, skills, 
etc.), they must succeed on a DC14 Intelligence 
(Arcana) or a DC14 Wisdom (Animal Handling) 
check. If they offer the hungry Gypsum some food, 
this check is made at advantage. If they win Gyp-
sum over, the cat quickly comes to understand their 
objectives slightly better and tries to attach itself to 
a magic-user, preferably a wizard (or someone who 
can take on an animal companion).
Should the GM approve, a PC may always cast 
find familiar on the cat, adding it to his retinue. And 
should the party find the warlock (Nylinn) in Room 
A99, he will probably want his cat back.
Once the Room is cleaned up, this is a safe place 
for the PCs to rest, especially with only one way in. 
It is even possible to rig up a pulley, using a rope, 
to enable the fallen lintel to be raised and lowered 
from within quite easily‚Äìnegating the need for a 
Strength check each time the PCs wish to enter. 
With a little thought, the PCs could turn this into 
an effective outpost for themselves.
Encounter Condition: Safe, Tremors 10
Tactics: N/A 
Treasure: Amidst the debris on the ground are a few 
soiled blankets and shards of metal. PCs succeed-
ing at a DC 16 Intelligence (Investigation) check find 
a torn bag filled with 16 gp and a chipped eye agate 
(55 gp). This eye agate belonged to the now-miss-
ing wizard.
All of the chests have long since been looted.
There is one of interest, however. On a DC14 
Wisdom (Perception) or Intelligence (Investigation) 
check, a false bottom can be discovered in one of 
the chests. Beneath the false bottom is a portal 
connecting this chest to one of the other empty 
chests in Room A67. Any item of small size passed 
through this portal ends up in the chest in A67 and 
vice versa. This magical effect is permanent, and 
the distance between the two chests has no impact 
on how effective it is. Clever PCs can likely think of 
dozens of ways of making use of this connection. 
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase the Wisdom (Perception) and Dexterity 
(Thieves‚Äô Tools) DCs of the falling block trap to 20 
and increase the damage to 3d6. To decrease the 
challenge, reduce the Intelligence (Investigation) 
and Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Tools) DCs to 12 each and 
reduce the damage to 1d6.
A60-A63 . SOLITARY CELLS 
These small cells are near-identical. The door to each 
is closed, but there is a locking bolt on the outside. 
The PCs may deduce that these were holding cells for 
something.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: Due to their narrow construction, these 
former cells have managed to escape the damage 

73
suffered by the rest of this area. Each cell contains 
a series of crude graffiti depicting orcs triumphing 
over their foes, bullying troglodytes, and crushing
