The doors to these cells are fully functional.
There is a 3 in 20 chance of finding the rem-
nants of an extraplanar creature‚Äôs remains under

Encounter Condition: Drafty or Stagnant Air, Safe
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: N/A
A64 . SOLITARY CELL
The door to this Room is locked with a bolt on this 
side. Opening the door is easy enough, but the PCs 
may ask first, ‚ÄúWhat is locked inside?‚Äù
A rotting dead orc lies on top of a pile of rubble. 
The earth below is ruptured, and viney plants grow 
up around the rubble wherever it can reach. Some 
of the plant life has tangled around the rotting 
corpse, begging the question: how long has the orc 
been dead, and how fast do the vines grow?
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Captured and killed by the kobolds, this 
orc sorceress was thrown into this cell and locked 
inside after being strangled. To be sure she could 
not come back and harm them, the kobolds locked

The plants in this cell grow faster because of the

mate the orc, and she will return as a revenant with

Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A 
Treasure: The shin bones of the orc have come loose

But to what end? The GM is encouraged to allow

Scaling: N/A 
A65 . SOLITARY CELL
The door to this Room is open.
Pushing open the slightly open door, you see 
another cell filled with rocks and destruction. 
Rubble piles up, cracking the stonework. Exposed 
dirt beneath the floor shows signs of viny plants 
growing through the cracks. And with plant life

Initial Attitude: Unfriendly 
Encounter: As the PCs stay longer in the Room, more

be noticeable at first, but eventually the floor will

ish insect swarm.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: If the PCs stay too long, the swarm burrows

PCs leave, the swarm eventually finds them an hour 
later. If the PCs defeat this one, another swarm 
shows up in one week‚Äôs time.
For some inexplicable reason, the swarm cannot 
see/sense elven characters, who become immune to 
the swarm‚Äôs attacks. This should not be evident for a

Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add a second swarm, three rounds after this one

ter, allow the PCs Wisdom checks to notice the

A66 . PRISON 
All of the doors to this Room are open.
The floor is covered in rubble. Wood and linen 
lie crushed under hundreds of pounds of stone. 
Centipedes and other bugs feed on whatever they 
can find, turning on one another as well. A dead 

 74
dire rat lies on its side, bloated stomach exposed to 
the elements and being eaten from the inside out 
by insects.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Everything is buried under rubble that 
comes up to the average human‚Äôs waist. Although 
this Room reveals nothing of interest, it is the gate-
way to the vault at Room A67.
The PCs must clamber across the top of the 
rubble to reach any of the numerous doors in 
this Room. Doing so requires a successful DC14 
Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. 
A failure results in 1d3 falling damage as the char-
acters tumble down, shredding hands, knees, and

first time they attempt the rubble.
The walls here are unstable and it is possible for

 '
Collapsing Wall Trap. Creatures in a 15-ft. cube must 
succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take 4d6 
bludgeoning damage. Creatures that succeed take 
half damage. DC 14 Investigation check to find, DC 
16 Strength check to disable.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A 
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: N/A 
A67 . PRISON VAULT 
The door to this Room is partially open. Rubble 
blocks the doorway except for a narrow 1-ft. wide 
opening. Inside, magical darkness eats up most of 
the light.
Though the door will not budge, you can see into 
the room from the doorway. The darkness of this 
room becomes evident. While you can see the edges 
of the room from your torchlight, the light only 
barely reaches. It is as though the darkness was 
swallowing the light.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: This was once a prison vault for items of 
minor importance. Magical darkness stops light 
from traveling too far or illuminating the details. 
Any check related to sight suffers disadvantage on 
the roll. Dispel magic will not negate this magical 
darkness, and a light spell is only a temporary fix.
A Small creature or smaller can crawl through 
the opening without a problem. A creature of Medi-
um size must succeed at a DC 19 Dexterity (Acro-
batics) check to pass through the existing opening. 
A Large creature or larger cannot pass through.
Attempts to widen the opening require caution. 
A successful DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check 
reveals that the entire thing will collapse unless

threat of collapse as a falling block trap.
 '
Falling Block Trap. +7 to hit one target (whoever 
opened the door). On a hit, the target suffers 3d6 
bludgeoning damage. DC 12 Intelligence (Investiga-
tion check to find, DC 16 Strength (athletics) check 
to disarm.
 Widening the opening properly requires 1d6 
hours. Attempts to widen the opening without the 
benefit of a successful check results in the entire 
thing collapsing and burying the entire doorway 
under rubble, causing the damage stated in the 
trap description above. Ironically, doing so creates 
an opening large enough for a Medium creature 
to crawl through near the top of the doorway. The 
vault itself is in good shape, having been well de-
signed. There are a total of 5 chests in the vault, all

Encounter Condition: Tremor 18
Tactics: N/A 
Treasure: One of these chests is the sister Telepor-
tation Chest to the first one, found in Room A59. 
Determining which requires a DC14 Intelligence 
(Investigation) check. Beyond this, all of the chests 
are empty except for one that holds a small black

Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase the attack bonus of the falling block trap to 

75
+9 and the damage to 5d6. To decrease the chal-
lenge, reduce the damage to 2d6.
A68 . COLLAPSED GUARD POST 
The door to this Room is partially open. Rubble 
blocks the door, and a DC 14 Strength check is re-
quired to push it open. The PCs can smell smoke and 
burned flesh coming from inside.
The smell of smoke and charred flesh fills the air. It 
is not suffocating, but smells awful. Although there 
has been a partial collapse of the ceiling, which has 
crushed much of the furniture that was once here, 
there are still three chairs in one piece. Two bodies 
lie burned to a crisp along one wall.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: This Room was a guard post a while ago, 
but the furniture was left behind when the ko-
bolds retreated south. The chairs are unremarkable 
and made for creatures with shorter build. There 
is a weapons rack behind the door, holding four 
rusty spears.
A pair of kobold bodies lie burned, having died 
from disease ‚Äî most likely the mold from one of 
the earlier Rooms. The kobolds set fire to the bodies 
to kill any infection.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A 
Treasure: The spears, despite being dusty, are 
fit for use. 
Scaling: N/A
A69 . RESERVE BARRACKS 
The door to this Room is open. 
Large portions of the floor of this room are strewn 
with rubble. The numerous cracks in the walls do 
not suggest much safety. Rows of dark wooden 
bunk beds, most of them damaged by the rubble, 
give some clue as to what this area was used for.
Initial Attitude: Hostile 
Encounter: As a former reserve barracks, this area was 
emptied of anything of interest when the previous 
occupants left. The bunk beds are clearly designed 
for humanoids. 
Currently Boyikt, the kobold wizard (and broth-
er of the dead kobold leader Borryn), four kobold 
warriors (hp 14, 9, 8, 8), and a krenshar occupy the 
Room. Having escaped the orc assault and the 
subsequent attacks by the extraplanar beasts, the 
kobolds have sought refuge. They have regrouped 
and sometimes send scouts out for a way out of 
the dungeon. Presently, four kobold foot soldiers 
have taken the route south and then east in search 
for an exit. 
Encounter Condition: Concealment, Cover
Tactics: The kobolds always have one of their number 
along with the krenshar stationed near the door 
keeping an eye, ear, and nose out on things. PCs 
using light sources are quickly spotted, and even 
those moving silently and in darkness cannot es-
cape the krenshar‚Äôs scent ability. The remaining ko-
bolds have built an impromptu fort by piling stones 
in the southeast corner of the Room, sectioning off 
a 10-ft.-by-10-ft. region. This provides three-quar-
ters cover and advantage on Dexterity saving throws 
and Dexterity (Stealth) checks. 
Once the krenshar and/or kobold guard spot 
an enemy, the two retreat back to a small blind 
near the fort gaining half-cover. The kobolds hope 
that danger passes them by and remain silent. 
If this does not work, they ambush their enemy 
with surprise.
While waiting to see what develops, Boyikt 
prepares magic missile as a held action while the 

 76
remaining kobolds prepare their slings as held 
actions. The kobolds attack with their slings the 
moment the first PC steps through the door while 
Boyikt casts his magic missile. The krenshar holds its 
scare ability in readiness should the PC attempt to 
advance into the Room.
Once the opening shots have been fired, the 
combat can go any number of ways. If the PCs wish 
to shoot it out with distance weapons and spells, 
they can take advantage of the cover offered by the 
doorway, the rubble, and the beds. In general, this 
provides half cover. If they choose to charge at the 
fort they find the going across the rubble-strewn 
floor slowed (the rubble is considered rough ter-
rain) while being subjected to Boyikt‚Äôs area effect 
spells. The kobolds continue to fire their slings 
while the krenshar makes use of its scare ability; the 
physically smaller kobolds avoid physical combat 
whenever possible, only using their spears when 
the krenshar resorts to its natural weapons.
Boyikt holds his spells in reserve for critical mo-
ments. He picks off weakened PCs with ray of frost 
and acid splash, but holds his area of effect spells 
such as color spray and sleep until he can get maxi-
mum effect out of them. One particular combina-
tion is to cast mirror image when the PCs get too 
close, and then vampiric touch to keep the enemy 
guessing which image cast the spell. He might also 
cast animate dead on a fallen krenshar.
The well-prepared kobolds are a strong chal-
lenge to the PCs and if combat can be avoided it 
should be. The kobolds are paranoid, afraid of ev-
erything that moves and for this reason they attack 
any non-kobolds that come into the area. However, 
that does not mean they are unwilling to negoti-
ate. After all, their situation at present is less than 
comfortable given not only the monsters roaming 
the dungeon but also the instability of this area. If 
the PCs choose to negotiate, either before combat 
starts or even after, Boyikt listens.
Boyikt‚Äôs attitude is indifferent for the purpose of 
resolving any Charisma (Persuasion) checks con-
cerning a cooperative arrangement once hostilities 
cease. If Turag (Room A28) is with the PCs, impose 
disadvantage on the Persuasion check. Although 
the exchange should be role-played rather than 
relying on dice. If the PCs manage to establish 
rapport with Boyikt then he demands an exchange 
of information.
Boyikt can relate his experiences concerning the 
battles with the orcs and the coming of the ex-
traplanar beasts. More importantly, Boyikt believes 
the beasts are coming from the northeastern Re-
gion of the dungeon, and he suspects that Longtail 
is behind the appearance of the creatures, although 
how precisely that came about is a mystery. He can 
tell the PCs about the secret door to Room A108. 
The kobolds discovered it while they were securing 
their area but were unable to open it (let the PCs 
come to the conclusion that it is a one-way door on 
their own as Boyikt only knows they could not get 
the door open).
Although he is free with information, Boyikt has 
no intention of joining the PCs to face Longtail. He 
has a healthy dose of respect for the wererat sorcer-
er and has no intention of going to the place where 
he suspects all those beasts came from. If the PCs 
say that they are looking for a way out, Boyikt and 
the kobolds may become convenient allies of the 
PCs, but only if Turag is not with the party (Boyikt 
cannot be persuaded to change his mind on that 
point and, in fact, wants the orc dead before mak-
ing any deals).
If the kobolds do accompany the PCs, they insist 
on being treated as equals. Of course, Boyikt is 
smart enough to realize that if the PCs are really 
heading for a showdown with the wererat (heading 
east is a strong clue), then he and the kobolds part 
ways with the PCs. 
In combat, the kobolds‚Äô preferred tactics are to 
engage from a distance and gang up on opponents 
whenever possible; fighting alongside the PCs, they 
prefer to let the PCs do the close-quarters fighting 
while they pepper the opponents with sling stones, 
rushing in to attack and finish off weakened foes.
Being trained in teamwork, the kobolds work 
closely with the PCs and coordinate their attacks 
with them. They help out the PCs to the best of 
their ability, although always with an eye to their 
own safety, and expect the same from the PCs. 
Boyikt is a decent tactician and is especially adept at 
using his spells to the best effect. However, he will 
always try to hold a spell or two in reserve (usually 
sleep and mirror image) just in case the alliance with 
the PCs goes sour. In a worst-case scenario, he uses 
his scroll of tiny hut to escape the PCs for as long 
as possible.

77
Whenever the kobolds are on the move, one 
kobold warrior and the krenshar take the lead 
acting as scouts and they suggest the same if they 
are traveling with the PCs. Once the scouts have 
spotted something, they sneak back to the remain-
ing kobolds and report the situation. The kobolds 
prefer to avoid combat when possible and sneak by 
opponents rather than face them. PCs that insist 
on fighting everything they see find the kobolds 
leaving them.
If facing combat, the kobolds set up an ambush 
in the most favorable location ‚Äî one that restricts 
the movement possibilities of their foes while 
allowing the kobolds to concentrate their missile 
fire and using the krenshar‚Äôs scare ability to prevent 
any enemy rushes at their positions. Because of 
the krenshar‚Äôs good movement rate, they use the 
creature as bait to lure extraplanar beasts into a 
prepared ambush whenever possible.
Treasure: The kobolds have nothing to spare. Not 
even food. They might have some orc weapons they 
were able to scrounge, but even healing potions 
have been used to keep them alive. If the PCs kill 
all of the kobolds, they find Boyikt‚Äôs spell book and 
scroll, along with some of the trapmaking parts the 
kobold warriors have scrapped together. If the PCs 
are especially kind to any of the warriors, he shares 
a trinket with one of the PCs ‚Äî a pebble that stays 
warm all the time. He personally uses it when he 
makes soup. Another kobold may share some of his 
edible mushrooms that he keeps in a warm sack.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
have the kobolds place trip wires across the floor, 
requiring a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw to cross 
the Room without tripping and falling prone. To de-
crease the challenge of this encounter, have Boyikt 
ready sleep instead and make parlay a more obvious 
approach to the encounter.
A70-A77 . THE RUBBLE
While still a subset of a larger Section, these eight 
Rooms are daily uninhabited and ravaged by the 
earthquake. Only a few of these Room possess any-
thing of value as well. Random encounters are rare

A78-A99 . THE WIDENING GYRE
The convoluted hallways and strange locations of 
Rooms A78 through A99 show the celestial‚Äôs dedi-
cation to traps within traps within traps. Building 
corridors where they were not needed, erecting secret 
doors to areas of no relevance, and planting traps to 
fill the emptiness, they befuddled and confused the 
prisoners of this dungeon for centuries. 
The lack of logic and straightforward access made 
this Section a prime location for the treasure-hunting 
activities of the humanoids, who braved its twisting 
corridors and hungry traps in search of the gold 
promised to them by Longtail. After all, who would 
build something as convoluted and trap-ridden as 
this without having something to hide?
It was in this area that the tenuous alliance be-
tween the orcs and reptilians faltered as search teams 
stumbled upon other search teams, and neither side 
could truly tell who had the rights to which Rooms. 
The situation was not helped by the fact that entire 
search teams from both sides were wiped out by 
traps, naturally leading each side to believe that the 
other had killed them.
Currently, the area is home to large numbers of 
extraplanar beasts who are competing for the right to 
establish nests in the area. As Orghar and a few orc 
survivors huddle in a small Room, the orc war lead-
er‚Äôs mind slowly disconnects from reality. Finally, the 
lizardfolk guides have found temporary shelter (Room 
A96) in their search for an escape.

A80 . FIENDISH STIRGE NEST 
Note: This is a very difficult encounter, even for a 
3rd-level party. PCs are encouraged to back down if 

 82
their numbers dwindle. Gamemasters are encour-
aged to keep some stirges in reserve if too many PCs 
start to die.
Four extinguished and broken furnaces, one in each 
corner of the room, look out onto a floor littered 
with splintered wood. A large number of the flying 
bloodsuckers are hopping about the room. In the 
center of the room, a pale green aura fills an area 
about 18 inches across.
Even before the PCs arrive at the doorway, they 
hear the flapping and calling of the fiendish stirge 
swarm in this Room. The door to this Room is open 
and secured with a large iron spike that has been 
driven into the ground to prevent the door from be-
ing closed. A DC 18 Strength check is required to pull 
out the spike.
Initial Attitude: Hostile 
Encounter: This area was once a workshop, destroyed 
years ago by escaped prisoners on a rampage. 
Currently, a large swarm of fiendish stirges has 
gathered here to make its home among the broken 
benches and empty furnaces. They sensed the evil 
here to be welcoming.
Encounter Condition: Safe (once the stirges are gone)
Tactics: There are a total of 20 fiendish stirges in this 
Room, making all manner of noise as they hop 
about, fighting each other for the ideal nesting 
place amidst the rubble. Due to the cacophony, the 
fiendish stirges have little chance of succeeding at 
a Perception check (they have disadvantage on the 
check) to hear or spot the PCs. However, any light 
source grabs their attention.
The fiendish stirges here are hyper-aggressive 
as they fight for dominance amongst themselves. 
Although they may notice the PCs, the fiendish 
stirges are not interested in pursuing them outside 
of the Room, so unless the PCs enter the Room, the 
fiendish stirges leave them alone. However, if the 
PCs enter the Room, the fiendish stirges attack. The 
easiest way to handle this is for the GM to divide 
the Room into quarters and assume that five or 
six fiendish stirges respond to the PCs whenever 
they enter one of the quarters while the remainder 
squabble amongst themselves. 
The same method is also used for area effect 
spells cast by the PCs or their allies. Whether the 
spell does harm or not, an area effect spell gets a 
response from the fiendish stirges that are in the 
area. If a spell covers only one quadrant, then only 
the five or six fiendish stirges within that quadrant 
respond. If it covers two quadrants, the 10 to 12 
fiendish stirges in those quadrants respond. How-
ever, unless the spell covers the entire Room, even 
if cast in the center no more than 10 to 12 fiendish 
stirges should respond. 
If the PCs remove the spike from the stone and 
close the door, the fiendish stirges are effectively 
trapped in the Room. Simply exiting the Room 
ends the encounter, and the stirges will even-
tually die.
No matter how many fiendish stirges attack, 
they seek out their own individual targets, prefer-
ring not to share their meal with anyone; the GM 
should spread the fiendish stirges out among all 
the available targets as evenly as possible, doubling 
up only when necessary. Because they are defend-
ing their territory, these fiendish stirges fight to the 
death, pursuing fleeing PCs out of the Room but 
not out into the hallway. 
Treasure: Resting on the floor, in the center of the 
Room, is a gold ring. It glows pale green and hums 
softly (if the PCs get near it). It is a ring of warmth, 
corrupted by the magic of the dungeon. It radiates 
a small degree of warmth at all times (whether or 
not it‚Äôs worn), and its presence here makes this 
Room hospitable. However, should a PC touch the 
ring, every stirge in the Room senses the distur-
bance and attacks.
The ring has no negative side effects other than 
the glow, which cannot be controlled, and casts a 
permanent light spell with a 1-foot radius.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
divide the Room in half instead of quarters (mean-
ing 10 fiendish stirges respond to an invasion of 
territory or a spell cast into each half ). To decrease 
the challenge of this encounter, the fiendish stirges 
are not hungry. They can only drain 5 hit points 
each, instead of the usual 10.

83
the hallway door directly to the north of the doorway

Read the following description when the PCs 
near the door.
A sturdy door stands before you. If you‚Äôre not

check is required to push the door open against the

Nearly a dozen orcs stand, lean, and sit around

If the PCs have seen the table in Room A20, this

of the table is a crude version of this one, redrawn 
from memory. Orghar saw it in Longtail‚Äôs books, and 
he, in turn, tried to recreate it here, thinking it would

Initial Attitude: Hostile; Varies
Encounter: Orghar personally led the attack on Room 
A49 intent on establishing orc control. Meeting with 
surprisingly stiff kobold resistance, the orcs never 
noticed the emergence of the extraplanar beasts 
from Room A103 until it was too late. Forced to re-
treat, Orghar and his warriors fought their way back

along the way. The door was battered by darkman-
tles and other creatures, rendering the lock useless.
There are a total of eight orcs (hp 18, 14, 13, 13, 
12, 12, 11, 10) in this Room, plus a berserker (hp 32), 
who is second in command to Orghar (Room A82). 
They are all that remains of Orghar‚Äôs clan, most of 
them still injured from the fighting. The health-
iest take turns standing guard, while waiting for 
Orghar‚Äôs leadership.
The orcs just want him to lead them from this 
forsaken place. 
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: Two orcs stand guard near the doorway at 
all times. One keeps an eye out on the secret door 
to the west, the other one on the northern hallway 
door. Utterly spooked by the carnage that they 
witnessed, the moment either of those doors open, 
the orcs raise the alarm, close the door, and hold it

but does not help hold the door.
The orcs know someone is coming and cannot 
be surprised, but it is unlikely the PCs are surprised 
either. There is a moment of shock when the orcs 
realize they are not fiendish creatures or kobolds. 
After the PCs push their way into the Room, 
both guards (the healthiest ones) and the berserker 
occupy the area around the doorway. The berserker 
meets the largest PC at the doorway.
The other orcs, wounded, take a round to get 
to their feet and ready their weapons. One orc 
runs to Room A82 to alert Orghar. The rest fight 
to the death ‚Äî having nowhere left to go ‚Äî but 
do not pursue fleeing PCs. If there is time and/
or the PCs take too long getting to the door and 
into the Room, the berserker quaffs his potion of 
bull‚Äôs strength.
Since the orcs hold their position within the 
Room, there is no immediate conflict unless the 
PCs attack. As such, the PCs can attempt to parley 
at any time. If they do not start a parley, a standoff 
begins. Eventually, the orcs will get gruff with the 
PCs and demand that they leave. Or worse.
If Turag is with the PCs, there will be questions 
(on both sides), but he encourages everyone to 
make peace. He hopes to rejoin his brethren and, if 
necessary, betray the PCs.
After enough time passes, Orghar arrives and 
demands someone speak. Though the orc attitude 
is initially hostile, the orcs are actually indifferent 
toward the PCs. Who are they anyway? Why are they 
here? This attitude remains even if Boyikt and his 
kobolds and/or Turag are with them.
Orghar‚Äôs goal for his group is survival, most 
likely by leaving the dungeon as quickly as pos-
sible. The PC‚Äôs presence indicates some hope in 
this regard. Regarding his own life, he does not 
care anymore.
If the PCs suggest an alliance, Orghar sudden-
ly comes to life. Seeing this as a challenge to his 

 84
power, the clan head dismisses talk of an alliance. 
Instead, he orders an attack on the PCs. How this 
situation evolves depends on how the PCs have 
acted and how the orcs perceive them.
If the PCs are obviously injured or in some way 
act inexperienced or unsure, the orcs do as Orghar 
commands, and a full-scale battle to the death be-
gins. If the PCs have the orcs‚Äô respect, the warriors 
stand there unsure of themselves.
This vacillation angers Orghar. Calling up his 
rage, he attacks the PCs. Some of the orcs join 
the fight; others do not. Orghar has no intention 
of losing the leadership of the clan and fights to 
the death.
If the PCs kill Orghar, the remaining orcs 
propose an alliance with the PCs. The strongest of 
the remaining orcs suggests they work together to 
escape the dungeon.
While the orcs will work with the PCs and even 
battle alongside them, they do so with plans of 
eventually betraying their allies. As long as they 
fight the beasts, the orcs are highly motivated to 
do their part, but when facing anything else, they 
mind their own safety and let the PCs carry the 
brunt of the fighting.
If Boyikt is with the PCs, he encourages the PCs 
to attack along with his troops and finish the orcs 
off. If the PCs refuse, he baits the orcs, perhaps 
even casting a spell into the doorway, in an effort 
to start a fight. However, he does not engage the 
orcs while they have the tactical advantage. PCs 
can attempt to defuse the situation as they see fit, 
but the kobold wizard has a hostile attitude to-
wards any suggestions of an alliance with the orcs. 
Feel free to assign positive modifiers to attempts 
at Charisma (Diplomacy) checks with the kobold 
wizard if the PCs have saved the life of Boyikt 
or his kobolds. There is no way to convince the 
kobold wizard to ally with the orcs; either the PCs 
give up this idea of an alliance with the orcs, or the 
kobolds leave. If the PCs are foolish enough to try 
to stop the kobolds, the kobolds fight.
If Orghar arrives and there is a fight already in 
progress, he joins the combat with gusto, gaining 
an advantage on all rolls during the first round 
(the ring he wears drives him to kill, even in his 
defeated mental state). However, his malaise takes 
over two rounds later, in which he suffers one 
disadvantage on his first roll and one disadvantage 
on another roll the following round. Unless he sees 
some hope in the fight, Orghar eventually lowers 
his ax, gives up, and lets the PCs win, whatever that 
looks like in your game.
If Orghar dies while the others fight, the healthi-
est orc screams out with a battle cry, declaring him-
self the new clan leader. The rest accept until the 

85
battle is over and then fight amongst themselves 
for leadership.
This is most likely a bloodbath.
Treasure: Collectively, the orcs carry maybe 15 gp in 
various denominations, some trinkets, and their 
weapons. They have no magic, and only the ber-
serker possesses a potion, which he most likely has 
already drunk.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add four fully healed orcs or two berserkers. To de-
crease the challenge of this encounter, the orcs (not 
the berserker) are shaken.
A82 . ORGHAR'S SOLITUDE 
The door to this Room is open. Whether the PCs 
negotiate or fight their way past the orcs in Room A81 
to get to this point, the text is the same. 
A smaller room lies mostly barren, with floor mats, 
blankets, and some general adventuring gear 
strewn about the floor. Dirty candles have been 
knocked over and snuffed out.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This is Orghar‚Äôs private chamber. He is 
head of the clan of orcs that followed Longtail to 
the dungeon. Having watched virtually all his clans-
men die at the hands of the extraplanar beasts has 
caused his mind to drift.
Orghar is tall and powerful. Even for an orc, 
he stands half-a-foot taller than most. His face is 
a maze of scars, showing his experience in battle. 
Perhaps his prowess could be questioned, but his 
survival rate cannot. His left eye is missing, re-
placed with a glass eye that doesn‚Äôt match. It gives 
him a slight advantage when attempting to intim-
idate someone. There are tattoos all over his arms 
and neck, one for each battle he has won.
No longer interested in anything, he spends 
his time in this Room, lost in private reverie. He is 
morose and expects to die at any moment. His clan 
thinks he is dreaming up a plan for escape, but he 
has truly given up.
Orghar‚Äôs reputation within the clan is so great 
none of his clansmen attempted to replace him, 
even though he has led his clan to its demise and 
is exhibiting signs of mental illness. They have that 
much respect for him.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: One way or the other, Orghar has made it to 
Room A81 before the PCs find this Room.
Treasure: Orghar‚Äôs ring is a plain, unadorned circlet. 
It fits any finger perfectly. 
Orghar‚Äôs Ring: (Ring, Very Rare, Doesn‚Äôt Require 
Attunement)
While wearing the ring, your alignment changes to 
the next in sequence (so Lawful Good would be-
come Lawful Neutral; Neutral Good would become 
Neutral; and so on). You gain advantage when mak-
ing a Charisma (Persuasion) or Charisma (Intimi-
date) check against and with an evil creature. 
Scaling: N/A 
A83 . HOLY ILLUSORY FIRE 
The smell of burnt flesh and leather hangs heavy 
in the air.
This smell is part of the illusion. The door to this 
Room is closed and trapped; a fiery elemental-type 
creature is painted on the door. Describe it however 
you like to the PCs, as they‚Äôve probably never seen 
one before. A fire spell triggers the moment a Tiny or 
larger creature touches the door. A large glyph signals 
the presence of the trap, however.
 '
Fire Trap: Fire erupts in a 10 ft. radius. Creatures in 
the area must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving 
throw or take 3d6 (illusory) fire damage or half on a 
successful save. DC 14 Wisdom (Perception) check 
to find, DC 16 Intelligence (Arcana) check to disarm. 
DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) to disbelieve.

 86
Once the door is open, read the following.
The lighting inside the room is strange. There is a 
gray-blue glow coming from somewhere, but it is 
unclear where the source is. The ceiling, floor, and 
walls of the Room are covered in a thick layer of 
burnt slime. Embedded in the far wall is the imprint 
of an angelic shape, like a fossil cracked out of a 
stone. A simple, colorless glass sphere rests atop a 
stone pedestal in the center of this room.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: The temperature of the Room is extreme-
ly hot, though this is an illusion. Characters spend-
ing too much time here suffer 1d4 damage (no 
save). Repeat this as often as necessary.
Turag and/or Boyikt do not trust this area of 
the dungeon. While they do not know this Room, 
they lost enough allies in this area that they will not 
enter. They will adamantly refuse, going so far as to 
fight a PC not to enter this Room.
A one-foot-diameter glass sphere rests atop an 
ornate pedestal. Glyphs and sigils cover the edges 
and legs. The glass appears to have something fiery 
inside, though it is blurry and unclear. It does not 
look humanoid but rather ghostly. Should a PC 
touch the sphere, the fire revenant inside ignites 
the PC‚Äôs hand and escapes into their body.
Encounter Condition: Extreme Heat, Smoke
Tactics: The PC appears to be on fire, but this is an 
illusion. The fire revenant is just a trickster spirit. It 
cannot harm the PC, but the PC will not know that. 
Each round, they will make contestsed Wisdom 
checks to see who controls the PC‚Äôs body for one 
turn. This continues until the PC has won three 
contests in a row or the PC is knocked unconscious.
Regardless, the revenant then escapes and dissi-
pates into steam. If the sphere is left in the Room, 
the fire revenant returns in one week. If the PCs 
take the sphere with them, it is extremely warm and 
heavy and makes for a nice centerpiece. Maybe it‚Äôs 
worth something.
Once the PCs have had a chance to rest, they 
realize the illusory fire damage isn‚Äôt real, and all 
of it heals, except for any damage the PCs dealt to 
one another.
Treasure: A careful examination of the angelic im-
print on the wall reveals a silver coin in the angel‚Äôs 
hand. It can be pried from the wall and taken as a 
fire token. Once removed, the coin feels thin and 
brittle. It is a one-use casting of fireball (6d6). The 
PCs won‚Äôt know exactly what it does until they flip/
hurl the coin.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
allow only half the damage to heal after a rest. To 
decrease the challenge of this encounter, allow the 
PCs to use the glass sphere to summon one fire 
elemental one time.
A84 . GREEN ICE 
The door to this Room is closed and cold to the 
touch. Anyone pushing open the door suffers 1d4 
cold damage. No save. Once the door is open, read 
the following.
The lighting inside the room is strange. There is an 
amber glow coming from somewhere, but it is 
unclear where the source is. The ceiling, floor, 
and walls of the Room are covered in a 
thin layer of translucent green ice. A 
simple dark gray box rests atop a 

87
stone pedestal in the center of this room. Two dead 
orcs lie at the foot of the pedestal.
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: The temperature of the Room is extreme-
ly cold. Characters spending too much time here 
suffer 1d4 damage (no save). Repeat this as often as 
necessary.
A one-foot-long dark gray stone box rests atop 
the ornate pedestal. Glyphs and sigils cover the 
edges and legs. The box has soft rounded edges, 
and it seems to devour both heat and light. The 
inside of the box is laced with cultivated yellow 
mold that bursts in a 10-ft. cloud when the box top 
is lifted.
 '
Box of Yellow Mold. A cloud of poisonous spores 
bursts forth. All living creatures within 10 ft. must 
succeed on a DC 12 Constitution save or suffer 1d6 
points of immediate Constitution damage for 24 
hours. After 1 minute, they must succeed on the 
same save to avoid a further 2d6 points of imme-
diate Constitution damage. Creatures reduced 
to 0 Constitution die immediately. DC 16 Intelli-
gence (Investigation) check to find, DC 13 Dexterity 
(Thieves‚Äô Tools) check to disarm.
Note that even if a PC succeeds at the first 
check, he is still required to make the second save.
The lid of this box is weighted, so it always drops 
back down to close unless it is held open.
If either Turag and/or Boyikt are with the party, 
then either one of them can warn the PCs about 
the box (though the dead orcs should be warning 
enough). Whether they choose to do so, especially 
Turag, is another story.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: One of the keys the PCs found elsewhere 
in the dungeon opens the box without setting 
off the trap.
Treasure: A +2 ritual dagger rests inside the box. It 
cannot be held by evil or chaotic characters, how-
ever. Well. It can. But it does not confer a magical 
bonus to them.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
remove the dead orcs. To decrease the challenge of 
this encounter, reduce the damage of the mold to 
1d4 and 2d4.
A85 . SLEEP TRAP 
The southern door to this Room is closed and pulses 
with static electricity. Anyone pushing open the door 
suffers 1d4 lightning damage. No save.
The western door to this Room is closed and coated 
in a thick gray slime and some blood.
Once either door is open, read the following.
The lighting inside the room is strange. There is a 
purplish glow coming from somewhere, but it is 
unclear where the source is. The ceiling, floor, and 
walls of the Room are splattered with blood, fur, 
and bits of skin. An ivory tusk, less than a foot 
long, rests atop a stone pedestal in the center of 
this room. Two blackened pigs lie on the floor, guts 
splayed out, the bodies covered in maggots and 
flies. Oddly, there is no odor.
Initial Attitude: Hostile 
Encounter: There are two fiendish panthers resting 
in a corner of the Room. But the Room is so dark 
it has to make them out against the purple light 
(DC 25 Wisdom (Perception) check). They have not 
touched the dead pigs and will not eat them.
On the pedestal is a tusk (see treasure). Should 
anyone touch it, a flare trap and sleep trap go 
off simultaneously ‚Äî though the sleep trap only 
affects the PC touching the tusk. Whether the PCs 
successfully save against these trap effects or not, 
the flare negates the use of darkvision and low-light 
vision for 15 minutes.
 '
Flare Trap. Creatures within 20 ft. must succeed on 
a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or be blinded for 1 
minute. Trap resets after 1 round. DC 18 Wisdom 
(Perception) check to find, DC 16 Intelligence (Ar-
cana) check to disarm.
 '
Sleep Trap. Roll 7d8 to determine how many hit 
points of creatures this affects. Creatures within 
20 ft., starting with the creature with the lowest 
hit points, fall unconscious if the total roll exceeds 
their current hit point total. Each time a creature 
is affected, subtract their hit point total from the 
remaining pool before affecting the next creature.
Turag and/or Boyikt know nothing about these 
traps, but they have seen this Room configuration 

 88
before. They may or may not warn the PCs and defi-
nitely do not enter the Room.
Encounter Condition: Ambush (darkness), 
Concealment
Tactics: After the sleep trap triggers, the fiendish 
panthers spring into action and attack whoever is 
left standing, gaining surprise on the first round. 
Assuming, of course, the PCs didn‚Äôt spot the pan-
thers earlier.
Although aggressive, these fiendish panthers 
do not fight to the death. Being reduced to 50% 
or fewer starting hit points is enough to make a 
panther flee.
If healthy, the panthers pursue fleeing PCs.
Treasure: The tusk is carved with faint, archaic runes 
and shaped like a weapon, complete with pommel. 
It is a dagger of venom, radiating faint necromancy,

Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter,

prise round.
A86 . REFUSE ROOM 
The secret door at the end of the western hallway is 
easy to find, as the smell of garbage seeps through 
the cracks in the door. It rotates on a central pintel 
but is rather wide when opened. 
There is no door to this Room. The smell starts long 
before the PCs reach the doorway.
A bubbling mass of garbage covers most of the 
floor. The smell is unbelievably bad. Here and there, 
the handle of a broken tool or piece of furniture 
peeks out from the morass. Rotting matter is 
everywhere. Dead rats can be seen on top of the 
trash. The sounds of rats under the surface can 
also be heard.
Initial Attitude: Hostile 
Encounter: This place is a refuse heap and, except 
for a 15-ft.-by-10-ft. area in front of the hallway, is 
filled knee-high with garbage. The bubbling of the 
garbage is caused by three fiendish rats swarms (hp 
18, 16, 13) moving beneath the filth. 
The smell is bad enough to require a DC 13 
Constitution saving throw as the PCs approach the 
Room. Failure indicates that the PC is considered 
poisoned while within range of or inside this Room 
(the poisoned condition lifts 1d4 rounds after exit-
ing the area).
Any PC spending more than a single round in 
the Room is also subject to catching an airborne 
variant of filth fever.
 '
Filth Fever. DC 11 Constitution save. On a failure: 
in 1d3 days, Dexterity and Constitution are each 
reduced by 1d4 until the disease is removed. Repeat 
save every 8 hours. Filth Fever ends after three con-
secutive successful DC 11 Constitution saves.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: The fiendish rat swarms are busy rooting 
through the garbage and have a tough time notic-
ing the PCs (disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) 
checks), especially since the strong garbage smell 
completely masks the PCs‚Äô odor from the rodents‚Äô 
scent ability. Of course, once the PCs are noticed, a 
general squeaking alarm echoes as rat waves rush 
out from the garbage.
The fiendish rat swarms vigorously defend the 
trash pile and chase the PCs out of the Room if 
they flee.
The swarms flow over the adventurers, covering 
as many PCs as possible in their 10-ft.-by-10-ft. 
area. Only one fiendish rat swarm may cause dam-
age to a given PC each round, even if he is within 
the space occupied by two swarms; there simply 
isn‚Äôt enough space.
In addition to the smell and the disease, the gar-
bage signals an additional danger. Over the years, it 
has been outgassing, and given the tepid nature of 
the air in the dungeon, this gas has been building 
up. The churning of the fiendish rat swarms has 
released this gas, which represents a great hazard 
at this point. Any open flame (such as a torch or 
spell such as burning hands) that enters the area 
ignites the gas. This creates a non-magical 5d6 
fireball that covers the entire Room plus the first 10 
ft. of the hallway (Dexterity saving throw, DC 15 for 
half damage). 
PCs without the scent ability have trouble 
distinguishing the smell of gas from the smell of 
garbage unless they succeed at a DC 18 Intelligence 

89
(Nature) check or a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) 
check. Any creature with the scent ability can figure 
out that gas is present. Note that just because a PC 
notices the gas does not mean that the fire hazard 
becomes evident. 
Treasure: A DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals 
a +1 longsword among the debris, should anyone 
be brave enough to dig into the trash, though this 
risks disease again.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add a fourth fiendish rat swarm. To decrease the 
challenge of this encounter, decrease the fireball 
damage to 3d6.
A87 . SECURE PRISON 
The door to this Room is closed and trapped with two 
traps. The first trap is a scything blade trap. Pushing 
the door open releases the blade, which is located 
on the interior wall next to the doorframe, so that it 
swings down and cuts the hand of anyone pushing 
open the door. A hidden bolt near the top of the door 
can be slid into place to block the blade from falling

 '
Scything Blade Trap: +6 to hit, one target, 3d8 slashing 
damage. DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check to find.
The second trap is a lightning trap that triggers 
whenever a Tiny or larger creature crosses the thresh-
old. The lightning strikes down from the lintel to 
the floor and can affect only the creature within the 
doorframe at the time of the triggering.
 '
Lightning Trap. Deals 5d8 lightning damage. Crea-
tures take half damage on a successful DC 15 
Dexterity saving throw. DC 20 Wisdom (Perception) 
check to find, DC 21 Intelligence (Arcana) check to 
disarm. Resets after 1 round.
Any humanoids with the PCs are unable to 
tell about the exact nature of the traps. They can 
share with them the fact that it is more than likely 
trapped. If they so choose.
 Once the PCs open the door, read the following. 
This was clearly a prison cell at one time ‚Äî shack-
les everywhere ‚Äî and then refurbished as an 
armory. The large room is home to a number of

Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: N/A
Encounter Condition: Drafty
Tactics: N/A 
Treasure: The weapons themselves are actually well

addition, each weapon is etched in both dwarven

The following arms and armors are readily avail-
able (each item appears only once).
Tailored for a Derro: Studded leather armor, buckler,

bow without the loading tag), and a vial of green

Tailored for a Drow: chain shirt, light shield, rapier,

 '
Drow Poison. On a hit, the target must succeed on 
a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or be rendered 
unconscious for 1 minute. At the end of 1 minute,

Tailored for a Duergar: chainmail, heavy shield, war-
hammer, light crossbow.
Tailored for a Dwarf: scale mail, heavy shield, war axe,

Tailored for a Human: chainmail, medium shield,

Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter,

A88 .-A93 . THE LAIR 
The rather large chambers from Room A88 to A93 
were used as everything from living quarters to 
prison dens to workshops. Although the humanoids 
freely explored these areas, they were considered 
too large by either side to defend properly and were 
generally left alone.
The presence of a community is still obvious. The 
accumulated debris of years of occupation litters the 
floor (disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks in 
these Rooms), and the sharp eye can make out non-
sense graffiti. 
Currently these Rooms are proving an attractive site 
to a large swarm of fiendish darkmantles; the flying 
beasts find the open spaces a pleasure to be in. Each 
member has selected an area and only leaves it to go 
hunting in the dungeon.
If any of the orcs from Room A81 are with the PCs, 
they are all too familiar with the area, having retreat-
ed through. They gladly and ferociously attack any 
fiendish darkmantles they encounter. 
A88 . LAIR ENTRANCE 
Both doors to this Room are open. 
The floor of this large room is covered with debris, 
and settled dust coats everything. Three hulking 
shapes can be seen in the darkness on the other 
side of the room.
Should the PCs take their eyes off the beasts in this 
Room, they notice:
Footprints cut through the dirty floor, indicating 
someone was here recently. Someone without 
shoes. They came in from the south and exited 
through the door in the north. 
Initial Attitude: Hostile 
Encounter: Three fiendish axe beaks currently occupy 
this Room. They entered through the opposite door 
from the PCs a few moments ago. In addition to 
the axe beaks, include any creatures that may have 
retreated from Rooms A89 and A90.
Once the PCs move further into the Room, they 
notice a couple of orc corpses lying against the op-
posite wall. They would have been food for the axe 
beaks, but now they have the PCs to contend with.
Encounter Condition: Concealment
Tactics: The fiendish axe beaks are in an uneasy truce 
with each other and keep a wary eye out. Because of 
this, they do not work as a team and roll initiative 
separately. 
Although aggressive, these fiendish ax beaks do 
not fight to the death. There are two exits, so it is 
easy for one to make an escape if/when reduced to 
half hit points. They do not respond to the sounds 
of combat in Room A89 or Room A90, but should 
they retreat into Room A89, they join the fiendish 
forces there.
If the PCs retreat, the fiendish ax beaks do 
not follow.
If the PCs attempt to close the doors in this 
Room, the fiendish ax beaks are quite capable of 
opening them again. 
Treasure: A DC 17 Intelligence (Investigation) check 
reveals a tattered sack wedged into a corner of 
the Room and covered with dirt. It is filled with 23

each. They are the treasure of a kobold who hid

Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add two fiendish darkmantles waiting to drop on 
wounded PCs. To decrease the challenge of this 
encounter, remove one fiendish ax beak.
A89 . ANCILLARY LAIR 
Both doors to this Room are open.
The floor of this large room is covered with dust 
and debris. Dead flying octopi litter the floor. A 
trio of wild boars feed on the carcass, treating it 
like a toy. Other large pieces of meat are scattered 
around the room. Two large rats feed on something 
in the corner.
Initial Attitude: Hostile 
Encounter: Three fiendish wild boars and two 
fiendish dire rats make their home here. They have 
made their way down from Room A103, killing and 
replacing darkmantles as they go, and now feed 
on the dead.

91
Rotting, dismembered orc corpses and dead 
fiendish darkmantles indicate there was a fight 
here. And either the boars were in on the fight, or 
they are enjoying the leftovers.
Encounter Condition: Concealment, Cover
Tactics: No one is looking for a fight. They have 
plenty to eat, but all of the fiendish wild boars take 
a defensive stance when the PCs enter. The plans of 
the dire rats are not immediately known. They wait 
to respond to the PC‚Äôs actions. Anything overtly ag-
gressive sends the fiendish dire rats to the opposite 
doorway, joining forces with whoever is in Room 
A88 or Room A89.
The wild boars charge on the first round of com-
bat, gaining an advantage on their attack and 
damage rolls.
Treasure: Searching through the decaying orc corps-
es, the PCs find 15 sp, a whetstone, four hatchets, 
and a preserved plum in a dirty sack. It is unclear

Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add one additional fiendish wild boar and have 
them fight aggressively. To decrease the challenge 
of this encounter, remove the dire rats.
A90 . LARGER HORRORS 
Both doors to this Room are open. 
Debris and dust cover this abandoned room. Some 
furniture or crates were here once. It is unclear. All 
of the wood has been smashed beyond recognition. 
Four wolves with black fur tug and pull at the 
remains of a recently deceased kobold. 
Initial Attitude: Hostile 
Encounter: In addition to the wolves, include any 
creatures that may have retreated from Rooms 
A88 and A89. 
Three fiendish darkmantles and dire rats are 
dead on the ground, obviously killed a while ago. 
But the kobold‚Äôs body is fresh, and the wolves 
want that.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: Though playing tug of war with the kobold 
corpse, these fiendish wolves work as a team in 
battle, circling around a single enemy if they can. 
They are not timid and are unlikely to run. They 
gain advantage on any fear-based saving throw 
and work with any creatures that retreated into 
this Room.
The largest wolf performs a special trip attack on

If the trip attempt fails, the wolf does not 
try it again.
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add two additional fiendish wolves who perform 
the special trip attack on round one at advantage. 
To reduce the challenge of this encounter, remove 
one wolf and/or have retreating creatures continue

 92
A91 . THE STRONG SURVIVE 
All of the doors to this Room are open.
This is a complicated encounter with numerous 
creatures. Some retreating creatures may have made 
it here. GMs may want to scale this encounter back, 
regardless, or suffer numerous character deaths.
This is an extremely large chamber. Although debris 
covers the floor, several areas of higher traffic are 
visible from the numerous doors that lead in and 
out of this room. Numerous shapes can be seen 
through the haze of the room, the smell unmistak-
able and fiendish.
Initial Attitude: Hostile 
Encounter: This is the largest and most centrally 
located Room in this part of the dungeon. Accord-
ingly, numerous fiendish creatures are here, trying 
to get their bearings, having just come through the 
gateway in Room A103.
Orc and kobold bodies litter the floor, along with 
numerous darkmantles, rats, stirges, and an out-of-
place goblin who stumbled in here from Region B.
Slightly bewildered, several fiendish creatures 
are here. One fiendish owl bear, two fiendish ax 
beaks, three fiendish wild boars, three fiendish 
darkmantles, three fiendish stirges, and four 
fiendish dire rats present, in addition to any re-
treating creatures.
The darkmantles and stirges hide in the ceiling 
rafters above, waiting for their opportunity. A DC 15 
Wisdom check is required to spot them.
Encounter Condition: Concealment
Tactics: The PCs cannot possibly surprise the crea-
tures in this Room if they fought in Room A90 
beforehand. Retreating monsters will alert them of 
combat. However, they are still confused and fight 
at disadvantage on the first round.
The fiendish owl bear is already wounded and 
covered in blood. It stands in the center of the 
Room, surveying who or what to attack first/next. 
The fiendish ax beaks keep their distance from the 
owlbear, keeping their eyes on the entering PCs. 
The two fiendish wild boars are already feeding on 
carcasses alongside the fiendish dire rats.
The fiendish darkmantles are wounded from 
a previous fight and wait on the ceiling for an 
opportunity to feed. The fiendish stirges, while not 
wounded, are hungry and waiting for their moment 
to strike. These two creatures are the most likely to 
retreat north or west if things get too hairy.
Because of the scale of this encounter, it is 
broken down round by round, assuming specific 
creatures are alive that long. All creature types roll 
initiative separately.
On round one, the owl bear attacks a nearby 
wild boar. The ax beaks close the gap with the PCs 
but do not attack. The boars charge the first PC, 
attempting to take them down. The dire rats retreat 
to a safe corner and wait.
On round two, the owl bear turns its attention 
to the PCs, charging into the fray as if someone has 
used magic on it. The ax beaks attack whoever is 
closest while the wild boars push through the party. 
If a PC has been separated and exposed, one of the 
darkmantles and two of the stirges attack. At the 
end of the round, one of the darkmantles bathes 
the room in darkness, regardless.
In round three, the owl bear fights the closest 
thing it can find. The same goes for the ax beaks 
and boars. All of the darkmantles descend on who-
ever is weakest. The stirges do not hesitate to mob 
a single PC.
On round four, whoever is left standing contin-
ues to fight.
On round five, monsters start to retreat. Anyone 
with less than half hit points makes a run for it. 
They most likely head west, but the dire rats know 
of the food in Room A92 and retreat there. If any 
PCs have fallen, the boars and rats are the first to 
feed on their bodies. The stirges want fresh blood.
Treasure: There is likely to be some coinage among 
the dead bodies but little else of value. The gob-
lin wears a necklace with a key-shaped pendant 
on it. It is unclear what it goes to, but nothing in 
this Region.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add two more fiendish dire rats. To decrease the 
challenge of this encounter, remove all of the fiend-
ish stirges.

93
A92 . NOWHERE TO HIDE
The door to this Room is open. 
The floor of this L-shaped room is covered with 
the usual debris, including bone, blood, and broken 
weapons. The number of dead bodies indicates this 
was a final holdout for the orcs, who took many 
creatures with them.
Initial Attitude: N/A

 94

A96 . LIGHT AND LIZARDFOLK 
The door to this Room is closed and warded with 
a fire trap. It was placed on the door by Slissth, the

lizardfolk and give them time to prepare for intruders

 '
Fire Trap Deals 3d6 fire damage in a 5-foot radius. 
Creatures take half damage on a successful DC 10 
Dexterity saving throw. DC 17 Wisdom (Perception) 
check to find, DC 16 Intelligence (Arcana) check 
to disarm.
Read the following text once the PCs open the door.
Something scrapes across the ground as you push 
open the door. To your surprise, you see light within 
this room, not the flickering light of a torch but 
a solid, steady light. And the ominous sound of 
something moving...
If the lizardfolk have had time to prepare, read the 
following.
A hot, fiery green sphere lights up in front of you, 
catching some of you ablaze.
Initial Attitude: Indifferent 
Encounter: The reason for the scraping noise is a 
couple of rocks that have been wedged against the 
door for precisely this purpose. The rocks slow the 
opening of the door (it takes one full round to open 
the door after the discharge of the fire trap), and 
they also provide a warning to the room‚Äôs occupants 
in case the fire trap is somehow bypassed. 
The two lizardfolk are the guides that led Long-
tail‚Äôs expedition to this dungeon. They rest here 
while weighing their options. Although they resist-
ed entering the dungeon, they were forced to do so 
when the fiendish wererat refused payment. Once 
inside, they were trapped like all the rest.
The duo initially kept to themselves, living on 
the fringe of the reptilian settlement as the other 
humanoids explored the place. When the conflict 
broke out between the troglodytes and orcs, the 
lizardfolk sided with the troglodytes out of necessi-
ty. However, they were of limited use given their re-
liance on light and were fortunate not to be killed. 
With the appearance of the beasts, the duo sought 
their escape from this Region as quickly as possible 
and recently made their way here.
Both lizardfolk wear continual flame pendants, 
which are the lizardfolk‚Äôs most vital possession. 

95
Without them, they would be unable to navigate 
their way through the dungeon.
Encounter Condition: Soft Cover
Tactics: Both Kalhiss and Slissth are sitting across 
from the doorway, and as soon as they hear sounds 
in the hall, they prepare themselves. The odds of 
hearing anything beyond the closed door are slim 
(disadvantage to the lizardfolks‚Äô Perception checks 
due to the door and distance), but they definitely 
hear the discharge of the fire trap (unless it was 
disarmed).
If time permits, Kalhiss readies his bow and 
holds an action triggered by the first creature that 
comes through the door while Slissth casts flaming 
sphere (green-colored) and rolls it toward the door-
way. Slissth stops the flaming sphere in the doorway, 
forcing any creature trying to move into the Room 
to get past it while Kalhiss fires arrows at any crea-
ture that tries.
After, Slissth prepares to cast green flame blade 
and moves to deal with any creatures that survive 
the flames and Kalhiss‚Äô arrows, leaving the flaming 
sphere in the doorway. Slissth‚Äôs animal companion, 
a medium viper (T‚Äôlakiss), coils around Slissth‚Äôs 
shoulders. It defends the druid by biting any crea-
ture that engages in melee with the druid.
Once the lizardfolk recognize that it is the PCs 
and not some humanoids or obviously bestial 
denizen of the dungeon that opened the door, 
they hesitate a moment in their attacks. They call 
out to stop, but the PCs may not hear them over 
the clamor.
If the PCs attack, the lizardfolk defend them-
selves to the death if need be. If the PCs also 
halt their actions and request a parley or other-
wise stand down, the lizardfolk are willing to talk 
(Slissth keeps the flaming sphere in the doorway, 
just in case).
The lizardfolk know that their chances of sur-
viving in a dungeon environment are slim at best, 
and the appearance of the PCs gives them greater 
hope. They are willing to forge an alliance, assum-
ing that the PCs prove themselves trustworthy. You 
can use a Charisma (Persuasion) check based on 
the lizardfolk attitude of indifferent (DC 13) if you 
don‚Äôt want to roleplay the exchange. Give the check 
disadvantage if there are other humanoids with the 
PCs. Even if the result of the check is a failure, the 
lizardfolk still ally themselves with the PCs, though 
cautiously. 
The lizardfolk are the most reliable allies the PCs 
can find in this Region. They kept themselves out 
of the fray and thus have made no enemies among 
any of the humanoids. Furthermore, they judge 
their allies on what they do, not what they say or 
who they are. The more the PCs help the lizardfolk, 
the more they help the PCs.
The lizardfolk are intelligent enough to realize 
that if the PCs are traveling with orcs or kobolds, it 
is out of necessity and not because they share the 
same outlook on life. Thus, it is quite possible that 
if and when the other humanoids turn on the PCs, 
the lizardfolk will stand by their new allies.
Because these two kept their distance from the 
other humanoids, they know little about the in-
ner workings of the other humanoid groups. They 
can tell about the journey to the dungeon but are 
unaware of the exact purpose that Longtail had in 
coming to the dungeon. They both suspect that it 
was he who released the extraplanar beasts. They 
cannot pinpoint the wererat‚Äôs location because they 
have not seen him, but Kalhiss knows that all the 
creatures have come from the northeast.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase Kalhiss‚Äô and Slissth‚Äòs levels by one or two. 
To decrease the challenge of this encounter, de-
crease Kalhiss‚Äô and Slissth‚Äòs levels by one or two.

 96
 '

A99 . EMPTY VAULT 
The door to this Room is closed.

97
wrapped in an old blanket. His eyes slowly open as

A human (Nylinn) hides from the creatures

He was unable to lock the door behind himself,

 
Option 1) Nylinn is a friendly NPC with the

acter class until a player takes him on. He doesn‚Äôt 
know much about the dungeon and only came 
following rumors of treasure, though the fact

 
Option 2) Nylinn is a 4th-level rogue and a rival

Unless the GM chooses for Nylinn to be Long-

A100-A104 . THE CHAPEL 
Rooms A100 to A104 contain the long-forgotten 
chapel as well as some ancillary Rooms. The chap-
el was abandoned ages ago, and because this area 
is effectively isolated, the humanoids never both-
ered with it.
All of these encounters are fights. The GM should 
plan these encounters ahead and not just open the 
book the day the PCs encounter these Rooms.
Currently, Longtail and Achsyyx make the chapel 
their home. The wererat has isolated himself from 
the other factions, now a victim of his own ambi-
tions. The PCs most likely encounter them separately, 
though merciless GMs may have them fight the PCs 
together or, at the very least, come to the other‚Äôs aid 
(Rooms A101 and A103).
In addition, a fiendish owlbear is rampaging 
through the area completely out of control.
Random encounters do not occur in this Section.
A100 . PRISONER HOLDING CELL
The door to this Room has been smashed open. Be-
fore the PCs get too close, they can hear the sounds 
of combat and bestial shrieks from inside.
Note: This is a difficult and complicated encounter.
The door has been smashed open, lying broken and 
off its hinges. A mixture of splintered wood and 
twisted metal bands lie scattered in the doorway. 
Despite the gloom, it is possible to discern the 
carnage within.
A huge, feathered monstrosity with a raptor‚Äôs head 
utters horrid shrieks as it rampages through the 
room. Fresh blood sticks to its coat, and it carries a 
flying octopus clutched in one claw, entrails hang-
ing from its beak. At least half a dozen more flying 
octopi lie dead around it, their bodies torn open. 
Another, obviously heavily wounded, flies about the 
room in panic. Small empty force cages line the walls.
Initial Attitude: Hostile 
Encounter: This is the latest creature to step through 
the ‚Äòdoorway‚Äô opened by Longtail. Enraged beyond 
reason, the fiendish owlbear kills anything in its 
path. The darkmantles had the misfortune to be 
resting here when the fiendish owlbear emerged.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: The fiendish owlbear is enraptured by its 
bloodlust and is enjoying the destruction of the 
much weaker fiendish creatures, much as it enjoyed 
the killing of the humanoids in Rooms A101 and 
A102. It is momentarily distracted by its quest for 
the last remaining fiendish creatures and does not 
immediately notice the PCs. This is compounded 
by the low light within the room. At the start of the 
encounter, the fiendish owlbear has disadvantage 
on all Perception checks related to sight, unless the 
PCs possess a light source.
Once it spots the PCs, it attacks the nearest, 
swatting with its claws and biting with its beak. Due 
to its damage reduction, it has not been seriously 
hurt or challenged and thinks nothing of the insig-
nificant creatures that come into its field of vision.
Despite its evident rage, the fiendish owlbear 
is not stupid. If an opponent manages to deal 10 
or more damage in a single turn (after applying 
resistances), the fiendish owlbear turns its atten-
tion solely toward that individual and can pursue it 
without drawing attacks of opportunity. In any case, 
once hurt, it focuses its efforts solely on those who 
have hurt it and ignores those who haven‚Äôt. Fur-
thermore, if reduced to one-half of its hit points or 
fewer, it attempts to escape, bull-rushing and oth-
erwise fighting its way out of the Room and down 
the hall; it only fights to the death as a last resort.
The moment the fiendish owlbear is distract-
ed, the remaining fiendish darkmantle flees as 
best it can.  
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase the fiendish owlbear‚Äôs hp to 92. To decrease 

99
the challenge of this encounter, have the fiendish 
owlbear already injured at the hands of Longtail 
(see Room A104). It starts instead with 57 hit points.
A101 . HIDEOUT 
As the PCs approach this Room, from either direc-
tion, read the following.
Nearly a dozen orc and kobold bodies lie strewn 
across the hallway, vicious slash marks on their 
bodies. Three dead orcs are pressed against the 
iron-bound door as if trying to get in.
The door to this Room is locked and barred from 
the inside. Longtail has sealed himself inside and 
left the others to deal with the owlbear. A DC 20 
Strength check is required to bash it in. Unlocking 
it requires a DC10 Dexterity (Sleight-of-Hand) check 
but does nothing.
The PCs may bypass this Room because they cannot 
get in. There is nothing wrong with this. Longtail can 
be a long-term problem for Region B and Region 
E. But as the PCs advance in level, the GM needs to 
advance Longtail‚Äôs stats as well.
A large, surprisingly clean chamber confronts you. 
A pile of empty crates and barrels are clumsily 
stacked in the center of the room, swaying slightly. 
The room‚Äôs only occupant stands behind the tower 
‚Äî a single wererat staring you down in a defensive 
posture. He looks angry, like someone having a very 
bad day. You suddenly feel sleepy...
Initial Attitude: N/A 
Encounter: The orcs and kobolds were part of the 
small expedition that Longtail led to search for the 
chapel. They were killed by the owlbear when told to 
hold the door. Longtail is desperate now, not know-
ing who the PCs are or why they‚Äôve come, but being 
generally paranoid, he initially assumes they‚Äôre here 
to assassinate him.
Longtail has stacked some empty barrels and 
some broken-down crates in the center of the Room 
to use as cover. It is haphazard and makeshift, but it‚Äôll 
do the trick in a pinch.
A number of things are about to happen as the 
PCs enter the Room. 
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: There is virtually no way for Longtail to 
be surprised by the PCs. He moves to confront 
them as soon as he is properly prepared. Either 
he heard them coming in, or Achsyyx has already 
warned him.
The wererat is already in hybrid form and stays 
that way throughout the encounter. If Longtail is 
disguised as Nylinn and traveling with the PCs, this 
is his opportunity to escape to Room A104.
The moment he hears the PCs bashing on the 
door, Longtail dons his goggles of night before 
casting expeditious retreat and guidance on himself, 
then moving to either the left or right hall doorway, 
depending on which one the PCs are furthest from.
Once the door opens, Longtail casts sleep and 
attempts to snipe at the remaining PCs using magic 
missile or his wand. If there are too many enemies 
closing in on him, he uses his superior speed to 
evade or retreat to Room A102. If things get too 
tight, he can use fly and invisibility to buy himself 
some space.
Although Longtail opened the gateway, the dis-
appointing results have left him less than eager to 
fight for its possession. As long as things go his way 
in a fight, he is happy to duke it out. But if he is 
reduced to one-half or fewer hit points, he retreats.
He hides from the PCs within the dungeon, 
waiting for them to leave. If Achsyyx is still alive, he 
may join Longtail after the fight begins. However, If 
Longtail must, he leaves Achsyyx to make his own 
way. Only if escape is impossible, or he is about to 
die, does Longtail offer a truce, hoping to leave on 
his own terms. If even this prospect is dim, then he 
will beg for surrender.
If allowed to live and/or escape, Longtail heads 
north to Region E. He doesn‚Äôt know what is there. 
It‚Äôs just a random direction he‚Äôs headed in. Howev-
er, the parlay between Longtail and the PCs is likely 
to be lengthy and involve some negotiation.
Treasure: N/A 
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
give Longtail haste instead of fly and have invisibil-
ity already cast before the PCs arrive. In addition, 
add a fiendish rat swarm under his command. To 
decrease the challenge of this encounter, allow 
Longtail only two unused spell slots per level and 
reduce his hit point total by 20 (he has already had a 
run-in with the owlbear).

 100

Large basins and tubs fill the room. Ritual glyphs

tail has retreated.

rification are etched carefully into the walls. They

A shelf in the southeast corner has rusted ritual

Along the southern wall are holy, non-magical
