B130. GOBLIN PILGRIMS
Allow the PCs Wisdom (Perception) checks to over-
hear the talking going on inside this room.
A ragtag group of goblins takes refuge in this 
expanded hall. Their chanting is unnatural 
sounding and highly disconcerting.
If the PCs succeed at a DC¬†20 Dexterity (Stealth) 
check as they open the door, read the following.
They don‚Äôt seem to notice you as they are 
completely enraptured by the tokens and trinkets 
they‚Äôve collected into a pile on the floor.
Otherwise, read the following.
Cackling and shrieking, they rise in unison. With 
one mind the goblins gather their weapons.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: Six goblin warriors have made the long 
journey from the goblin empire to the shrine of 
their deity. They have collected about 20 gp worth of 
‚Äújunk‚Äù that they intend to offer to the goblin shrine 
(Room B134). Having traveled a great distance to 
get here and having fought off numerous creatures 
along the way, they are not about to back down 
from the ‚Äúheathen‚Äù PCs. Seeing the PCs as defilers, 
the goblin pilgrims viciously assault the PCs, not 
offering them a chance to ‚Äútalk.‚Äù
Encounter Condition: Echoes 4, Fearless
Tactics: If the goblins are not surprised, they attack 
the PCs in a massive swarm, concentrating their at-
tacks on whomever is closest. The goblins continue 
fighting even when an opponent falls. Zealous, they

Treasure: There are about 5 lbs. of trinkets that collec-
tively equal about 20 gp in value.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter,

201
B131 HIDDEN PRISON
The door is locked and requires a DC¬†24 Dexterity 
(Sleight of Hand) check to open. It relocks automati-
cally, so the PCs must unlock and push it open in one 
swift motion, lest the door locks again immediately.
As you enter the room a chill runs down your back 
and your arms. The room, simple and bare, seems 
devoid of life. The smooth floor, the high ceiling, 
and the darkness make you feel like you‚Äôve stepped 
into a tower belfry. An ominous moan fills the air, 
followed by a chill wind.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: Before the PCs can think, flip a coin to 
see if their torches are blown out by the draft. After 
that check to see if the PCs are surprised by the four 
vargouilles‚Äô descent upon them. The ceiling, over 
60¬†ft. high, hides the vargouilles from sight until 
they are ready to ambush the PCs, which happens as 
soon as one of them tampers with the lock. They are 
merciless and attack the PCs like shrieking bombers.
Encounter Condition: Ambush (darkness), 
Concealment, Desecration 4, Drafty, Extreme Cold, 
Negative Energy
Tactics: Immediately upon descending on the PCs, 
the first two vargouilles Shriek, and the next two 
(their initiative 2 lower), drop down to Kiss any PCs 
paralyzed with fear. The vargouilles continue attack-
ing with diving attacks, flying up and back around. 
Due to the darkness, ranged attacks fired up into 
the chamber suffer from concealment penalties.
They alternate between Kiss and Bite attacks, 
allowing their venom to slowly weaken PCs. Unlike 
the vargouilles in Room B114, these put up a fight.
Treasure: Should the PCs find adequate light, they 
can climb the walls of this room, to reach many of 
the shelves at the higher levels. Along the north wall 
at the 40¬†ft mark is a ledge 4¬†ft wide and 4¬†ft long. 
On the ledge is a small nest, with nothing in it. If 
the PC succeeds at a DC¬†20 Intelligence (Investiga-
tion) check, they find a cache in the north wall just 
above the ledge. The cache is trapped but hides a 
small strongbox.
Inside the strongbox‚Äîstrapped down with silk 
ties‚Äîare six potions of healing and a ring of swim-
ming. In addition, the felt bottom of the strongbox 
is magical (faint abjuration), helping to protect 
potions and other items from shattering. If a saving 
throw is ever called for glass items stored inside 
this box, they gain advantage on that save.
Along the north wall at the 15¬†ft. mark is a ledge, 
4¬†ft. wide and 5¬†ft. long. It is sturdy and a perfect 
place from which to view the entire room. Offal on 
the ledge makes moving on it difficult, however 
(Hazardous Footing 14).
Along the south wall at the 40¬†ft. mark is a ledge, 
3¬†ft. wide and 4¬†ft. long. Along the south wall at the 
40¬†ft. mark is a ledge, 4¬†ft. wide and 2¬†ft. long. A 
Small or smaller creature can crouch on this ledge, 
allowing them a DC¬†25 Intelligence (Investigation) 
check to find a loose stone in the wall, revealing 
a small cache with a small pile of gleaming bolts. 
There are five screaming bolts with continual flame 
cast on them. While not trapped, they are warm 
to the touch, which may or may not shock the PC. 
Screaming bolts frighten enemies within 15¬†ft, of 
them as they fly towards their target if they fail a 
DC¬†14 Wisdom save.
Along the east wall at the 35¬†ft. mark is a broken 
stone, 1¬†ft. wide and 2¬†ft. long. Along the east wall at 
the 45¬†ft. mark is a ledge, 2¬†ft. wide and 3¬†ft. long.
Along the west wall at the 25¬†ft. mark is a stone, 
2¬†ft. wide and 1¬†ft. long. Along the west wall at the 
50¬†ft. mark is a ledge, 4¬†ft. wide and 1¬†ft. long. It 
is nearly impossible to stand on. But tall PCs may 
use this ledge to reach a hidden shelf 6¬†ft. above 
the ledge. While it cannot be seen from here, it can 
be seen from the highest ledge on the north wall 
(DC¬†25 Wisdom (Perception) check). The shelf is 3¬†ft. 
wide and 1¬†ft deep, being cut into the shape of the 
room. Resting on the shelf is a small urn, painted 
red and black and making it difficult to spot.
The urn is trapped with purple worm poison that 
has been smeared on the lid and a fire trap (Room 
B18) that ignites when the lid is removed. However, 
the urn weighs no more than 2 lbs. and easily fits in 
the PC‚Äôs pouch for the long climb back down.
Inside the urn are black ashes‚Äîactually ten 
doses of dust of disappearance that hide an amulet of 
barkskin (once per short rest cast of barkskin requir-
ing no material components). The GM should keep 
this hidden as long as possible. The amulet remains 
invisible until all the dust is used, but begins clang-
ing in the urn as the dust level drops.
The GM may allow PCs to leap from ledge to 
ledge, but the width of the room may prohibit this.
Scaling: To increase the challenge, add one vargouille. 
To decrease the challenge, remove one vargouille.

202
B132. THE WAY STATION
As the PCs near the entranceway to Room B132, read 
the following.
The sounds of a large group of creatures echoes 
from behind the door. Goblin-like grunts and barks 
intermingle with the yips of wolves. It sounds like 
the room is pretty active.
If the PCs enter Room B132 without making a 
Dexterity (Stealth) check, read the following.
All activities cease and the room falls silent as 
you open the door. Two dozen goblins and a few 
hobgoblins stare at you, their arms filled with 
barrels and crossbows. A group of worgs in the 
corner growl and tension mounts.
If the PCs enter Room B132 and succeed a Dexterity 
(Stealth) check, read the following.
Nearly a dozen goblins and a pair of hobgoblins 
move about the room, obviously setting up defenses 
of some kind. The goblins carry equipment that is 
too big for them and the hobgoblins yell over the 
sounds of the barking worgs.
The door to this room can be locked, but at present 
is unlocked. A successful DC¬†25 Dexterity (Sleight of 
Hand) check unlocks it without a key.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: The PCs have entered a secret hideout for 
the goblin king‚Äôs soldiers. Having moved defensive 
equipment in quietly over the past few weeks, the 
excited goblins and hobgoblins are now working 
louder than they should. A perfect place to mount 
an ambush, the PCs have stumbled upon the goblin 
king‚Äôs secret plans.
There are ten goblins warriors, two hobgoblin 
guards, and three worgs in this room. The goblins 
are armed with shortswords and light crossbows, 
much different from those who trained with Ham-
merfist. The hobgoblins wear scale mail and carry 
masterwork shortbows and arrows. The worgs wear 
studded leather barding.
If the PCs have not made an alliance with the 
goblin king, Argliss, then they have a fight on 
their hands. Even if they have, the hobgoblins are 
Unfriendly, not wanting the PCs to know their 
business. A single spark is all that is needed for this 
powder keg of tension to erupt in combat.
If the PCs have allied themselves with the goblin 
king, the initial attitude of the goblins in this room 
is Indifferent. The goblins return to their business 
and ignore the PCs.
If the PCs attempt to speak with the goblins, 
they are met with short, gruff answers. As long as 
the PCs do not insult the goblins‚Äô god, they will not 
attack the PCs.
The hobgoblins provide information regard-
ing bugbear attacks and the wild monsters in the 
region but are also gruff and barely tolerate the 
PCs. The worgs are only being held back by their 
hobgoblin handlers, and constantly growl and snap 
at the PCs.
Encounter Condition: Fearless
Tactics: These goblins are zealots. They have under-
taken a long and tough (for them) pilgrimage to 
their god‚Äôs shrine. They attack the PCs in a massive 
swarm, concentrating their attacks on whoever is 
closest. The goblins will not stop attacking even 
when they are down. They jump on and gnash at 
their victim continuously until there is nothing left.
The hobgoblins fight with better tactics. They 
are armed not with short swords, but with short 
bows. The hobgoblins let the worgs loose on the 
first round of combat. The worgs dive into the PCs, 
striking randomly. The hobgoblins stay in the back 
corner of the room and unleash volleys of arrows at 
whoever they perceive to be the most powerful PCs. 
Once the target is down they concentrate their fire 
on the next most powerful, and so on.
Treasure: The barrels contain stones, whetstones, oil, 
and enough arrows, bolts, and javelins to last two 
campaigns. If the PCs need to refill their ammu-
nition, now is the time. A small pony keg contains 
ale, apparently smuggled in and a small strongbox 
(DC¬†24 Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check to open) 
contains six vials of acid, six vials of alchemical fire, 
six vials of oil, and four tindertwigs.
The lead hobgoblin carries the key to the door.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encoun-
ter, add four goblins and one hobgoblin. To de-
crease the challenge, remove four goblins and one 
hobgoblin.

203
B133-B136 . THE SHRINE TO 
NORENDITHAS STONESHAPER  
THE QUICKTHINKING, SMITER OF FOES
What was once the final resting place of a wayward 
goblin hunter who ran afoul of a cockatrice, has 
become the true mecca for the goblin culture. The re-
moteness of their empire coupled with a location that 
is virtually on the other side of the maze, heightens 
the importance of this place; only those truly devoted 
to Norendithas Stoneshaper dare to make the trek.
The shrine is hidden behind a secret door. That a 
simple goblin passed through the door in the first 
place is astonishing, that another group of goblins 
followed the first perfectly is a true miracle. When Ar-
gliss first visited the would-be shrine, he was able to 
understand the nature of the door and gave the gob-
lin keepers of the shrine specific instructions on how 
to open and close it. It wouldn‚Äôt do if the keepers and 
so-called priests could not locate their own shrine.
The shrine is well guarded by Argliss‚Äô elite hob-
goblins. The goblin god is the source of the doppel-
ganger‚Äôs power over the goblins, and he will not allow 
anything to jeopardize it. At any given time, the PCs 
may encounter one of the heavily armed patrols. By 
now, they should be used to the tactics of the goblins, 
and it is possible they have allied themselves with Ar-
gliss and are permitted to pay homage at the shrine.
If the PCs have allied themselves with the rebel 
goblins, the devout guards and keepers swarm the 
PCs until they are driven back or dead. The goblins do 
not tolerate heathens in their most holy of places.
B133. THE ANTECHAMBER
As the PCs near the secret door on the north wall 
read the following.
A section of the wall has been turned inward. It is 
quite obvious looking at it now that it was meant 
as a secret passage into the room beyond. Someone, 
however, has left it open. You hear strange chanting 
coming from inside the room. The high-pitched  
near wails grate on your ears as you enter.
When the PCs enter Room B133, read the following.
The goblins have hung impressive, but crude, 
tapestries along the walls. Each depicts a ferocious-
looking goblin, scowling with its hands raised above 
its head. A few goblins kneel in supplication before a 
heavy stone door set into the southern wall.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: If the PCs quietly enter the room, the 
goblins and hobgoblins do not notice them, as they 
are too involved in prayer.
Regardless of whether the PCs have made an 
alliance with the goblin king, the PCs are not wel-
come here. Three goblin warriors, unarmed, do not 
pose a threat in and of themselves, but 6d6 seconds 
after the PCs enter this room, the Hobgoblin Holy 
Guard of Stoneshaper‚Äîmade up of four hobgob-
lins wielding masterwork longswords‚Äîarrive to 
drive them off.
Encounter Condition: Fearless, Hallowed 2
Tactics: If the PCs are known by the goblin empire 
as allies, they merely guide them out of the room, 
rather forcefully, but as diplomatically as possi-
ble. The goblins yell obscenities as the PCs are

If the PCs are enemies of the goblins, the 
hobgoblins are outright aggressive and the goblin 
zealots grab anything they can find to use as weap-
ons. The goblins lash out, almost hysterical, while 
the hobgoblins concentrate on the PCs‚Äô front rank, 
using brute strength to push the PCs out of the 
room, fighting them in the hall, if possible.
Treasure: The goblins consider the tapestries of their 
god priceless, though they hold no value outside 
this room. The rebel goblins might be interested 
in taking them, however, so they can defile their 
enemies‚Äô religious icons.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add two hobgoblins. To decrease the challenge, 
remove one goblin.

204
B134. THE STATUE OF NORENDITHAS STONESHAPER  
THE QUICKTHINKING, SMITER OF FOES
The room is dominated by religious iconography;

of what the room was originally designed for, 
the faith of the goblins has transformed it into

Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: PCs curious about the statue can inspect

terity (Sleight of Hand) check allows the PC to slide

Treasure: The offerings the goblins have left behind

Scaling: N/A

4-15Nothing.
16

B135 . THE KEEPER'S  
CLOISTER
As you enter the room you see an ornately dressed 
goblin cowering in the corner. He is wielding a 
small dagger in a shaky fist. The goblin hisses and 
sputters curses at you, spittle flying off its lips. It 
makes no move to advance or attack you, however.
The room is decorated in the same imagery as the 
antechamber and is finished simply. A small desk, 
covered in deep red stains, stands against the 
western wall. Against the southern wall is a simple 
cot, covered in rags.
Initial Attitude: Unfriendly
Encounter: The PCs have entered the personal 
quarters of the Keeper of the Shrine (5 hp goblin 
warrior). The keeper is a devout goblin, but not very 
brave. As long as the PCs do not attack him, the 
Keeper does not attack them. He curses in Goblin, 
gesturing in a vulgar manner that the PCs must 
leave the shrine. He does not speak Common.
The Hobgoblin Holy Guard (Rooms B134 and 
B136) does not enter the room unless they hear the 
sounds of combat. They have been trained not to 
disturb the Keeper‚Äôs meditation.
Encounter Condition: Hallowed 1
Tactics: While he babbles he casts sanctuary to defend 
himself. If attacked the Keeper lunges at the closest 
PC. He knows he does not stand a chance against 
the PCs, but he cannot dishonor himself further 
by fleeing.
If the hobgoblins come to his rescue, they attack 
the PCs and attempt to break them off into two 
groups. They pin spellcasters and clerics into cor-
ners and fight fervently for their religious beliefs. 
If the Keeper is killed, they fight as though always 
enraged (see barbarian Rage class feature, their 
level is equal to their challenge rating).
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: N/A
B136 . BARRACKS OF  
THE HOLY GUARD
These cramped quarters house four hobgoblin 
guards who sit on the floor or on the bunks, their 
weapons at their sides. The bunks are stacked 
four high and the room reeks of sweat. Along the 
southern wall is a weapons rack, now empty.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: The barracks of the Hobgoblin Holy 
Guard of the Stoneshaper is just as volatile a room 
as any located in the confines of the shrine. With 
most of the guardsmen patrolling, hobgoblin 
guards in this room do not pose a huge threat to 
the PCs. The guardsmen are relentless in their at-
tacks however hopeless their situation may seem.
Encounter Condition: Fearless
Tactics: Like the other hobgoblin patrol and guard 
units, these hobgoblins single out the most pow-
erful PC and attack them en masse. They flank the 
PCs as often as possible, moving on to the next PC

goblin king unless they are known enemies of the 
holy empire, in which case they are put to death.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encoun-
ter, add one hobgoblin. To decrease the challenge,

Region C . 
The Final Option
This entire region was designed specifically to hold 
a powerful demon, Falortuligo (Room C21). Though 
this cell was of primordial importance, several groups 
of minor demons and lesser undead were also held 
prisoner here. When the cataclysm that shook the 
entire dungeon struck, most of these foul minions 
escaped, but the special cell in which the mighty 
demon lord was imprisoned remained completely 
intact. Over the years, several groups of explorers and 
settlers came to the region, but the great demon‚Äôs cell 
remained undisturbed and undiscovered.
Approximately 50 years ago, the last remnants of 
the Order of Myruun (an ancient minor goddess of 
the oceans, travel, and vigilance) were summoned 
here for mysterious reasons then only known to 
Myruun. It is still possible to piece together much of 
what happened during their stay, for the remnants 
and records of the forgotten Paladins of Myruun can 
be found buried here. Most of these fragments of 
information are well hidden, but clues are scattered 
throughout the region.
Perhaps sensing the weakening of the prison wards, 
Myruun instructed her remaining worshippers and 
servants to assemble in this region of the dungeon. 
No one knew why they were brought together in the 
bowels of this forgotten place, save the fact that they 
would be instrumental in turning the tide at some 
undetermined moment. Most were paladins and 
priests of some acclaim. Only the wizard Arum ar-
rived without being summoned, claiming he dreamt 
of his ‚Äúdestiny‚Äù and had to come here. When the final 
pilgrim arrived, 41 men and women occupied the 
garrison established in Rooms C1-C19. It was widely 
believed by those 41 inhabitants that they were the 
last in the line of the tradition of worshiping Myruun, 
and so they waited without further explanation.
When the prison vault of Falortuligo (Room C21) 
was broken open, Myruun revealed her plans to her 
minions. With the exception of Arum, they were 
asked to give their lives to fight the powerful demon 
that had escaped. Arum‚Äôs perspective of the battle is 
recorded in only one place. It is the sole account of 
the last battle and subsequent demise of the servants 
of Myruun, as Arum was its only living witness. The 

207
207
wizard‚Äôs account can be found in Room C64 (see the 
Path of the Righteous section for further details).
It is important to note that ethereal travel is pos-
sible in the area surrounding Room C4, due to a 
powerful experiment performed by the wizard Arum 
a few months after he arrived. The boundaries of this 
ethereal pocket are roughly 100 ft. in every direction 
from the altar in Room C4 and are clearly visible if 
the subject can see objects in the ethereal plane.
C1-C19 . FORGOTTEN PALADIN GARRISON
When the knights, paladins, and priests of Myruun 
were summoned to the dungeon, they established 
a base of operation for their garrison in Rooms C1 
though C19. Evidence of their passage is obvious 
throughout the area.
Myruun (a minor goddess of the oceans, travel, and 
vigilance) had summoned her last worshippers to this 
region of the vast dungeon prison. At the time, those 
who answered the goddess‚Äô call did not know what 
was expected of them. They lived here for more than 
three years, until one day their purpose was finally 
revealed to them, just moments before the vile de-
mon imprisoned in Room C21 broke free. To the last, 
the servants of the goddess Myruun willingly gave up 
their lives to aid an angel in destroying the demon 
called Falortuligo. None but the wizard Arum (who 
was with the devout, but was not one of them) knew 
of their sacrifice: were it not for the brave men and 
women of the Order of Myruun, the demon would 
have unleashed its wrath upon the world.

Initial Attitude: N/A

C3. ETHEREAL FILCHER'S LAIR
PCs succeeding at a DC 20 Wisdom (Perception) 
check notice the floor in front of the secret door is 
worn. The solid stone door itself is otherwise indistin-
guishable from the wall. The massive door spins on a 
vertical, central spindle so pushing the left side of the 
door, for example, causes the right side of it to swing 
outward. To open the door, characters must make a 
DC 20 Strength check while pushing on only the left 
or right side of it. The broken pieces of a spent gas 
trap are the primary reason the door is so difficult to

the door to swing freely on its axis.
As the door of this chamber opens, a fetid stench 
is released. Within the darkness, tiny flecks of 
reflected light sparkle and shine. A closer look 
reveals a dark shape moving slowly, as more 
twinkling lights appear.
Initial Attitude: Unfriendly
Encounter: This is the home of a Large ethereal 
filcher. The creature arrived at the prison sometime 
after the wizard Arum‚Äôs successful experiment. It 
has gathered quite a collection of coins, gems, bau-
bles, and other shiny objects over the years. Though 
it can travel outside the ethereal pocket, its survival 
instincts prevent it from leaving for extended peri-
ods. When the PCs enter its lair, it stands quietly in 
the corner of the room in ethereal form, waiting for 
them to leave.
Encounter Condition: Ambush (darkness), 
Concealment
Tactics: Though not particularly intelligent, this crea-
ture learned to use its jaunt ability very effectively. It 
remains hidden unless attacked or angered. If the 
PCs take more than a few baubles from the room, 
its attitude changes to hostile and it charges them.
Its favorite tactic is to use its jaunt to surprise its 
opponents. Between attacks, it positions itself for 
the best chance at surprise. If combat starts for any 
reason, the filcher fights until its hit points total 
drops below half. When this happens, it jaunts to 
another room and remains there until it feels safe 
enough to return to its lair.
Treasure: Though it is impressive to see this much 
treasure displayed in such a small space, it quick-
ly becomes apparent that the total value of this 
amassed fortune is less than it appears. A DC 12 

209
209
Intelligence (Intelligence) check estimates most 
items are colored glass or quartz, which brings

Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter,

C5 . MAIN TEMPLE
An intolerable stench escapes when the door to

There is a horribly decayed giant bat corpse in the

PCs entering the room must make a DC 12 Con-
stitution save or become infected by Slimy Doom:

covered in gooey gel.
 '
Slimy Doom. Immediately and at the end of each 
hour, an infected PC‚Äôs maximum hit points are re-
duced by 2d6. After each reduction, the infected PC 
may reattempt the saving throw, ending the disease 
on a success. Maximum hit points are restored only

Long Rest.
PCs succeeding at a DC 14 Wisdom (Medicine)

Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: The surviving giant bat immediately attacks

210

C6 . FORMER ARMORY
The door to this room is locked and trapped. PCs

contact with the surface must make a DC 10 Consti-

requires a DC 16 Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Tools) check. Any-
one picking the lock without touching the surface, or

C7 . FORMER ASSISTANT'S OFFICE
Though it is easy to determine this chamber

Encounter: This was the office of the second in com-

Tactics: N/A

neath this floor tile is a space with a small diary

The diary has writing on nearly every surface of

‚Äú The Diary of Thomas Corsek, Paladin of Myruun 
the Vigilant, Lady of Travel, Queen of the Oceans. 
Being a diary pertaining to personal events of life 
and service as squire to my brother, Geoff Corsek, 
and my Queen.‚Äù Next to Geoff Corsek, the words 
‚ÄúThe Gold General‚Äô were written and circled, as if 
added at a much later date. Written in much small-
er text at the bottom of the page is the additional 
subtitle, ‚ÄúAnd being a record of the Calling as we 
travel to a post my Lady has given us, to turn the 
tide as my Queen instructed.‚Äù
PCs spending at least one hour reading through 
the pages of the diary find many entries character-
istic of a young man who idolizes his older brother 

211
211
yet doubts his own abilities. The diary tends to be 
vague in reference to details about locations or 
dates, but rather specific about personal goals,

eral‚Äù refers both to the narrator‚Äôs brother‚Äôs uncanny 
ability to find chests of gold lost as sea and his

tries or so, there is a sentence written in a different

PCs reading the diary completely and who make

ning from the first entry written inside the garrison

DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check discover that 
both stone doors are heavily detailed. The creators of 
the doors even added stone rivets and a simulated 
locking mechanism, nearly identical to other doors 
found throughout the dungeon. Even the stone bars 
fastened across the eastern door have a peculiar 
wooden grain to them. PCs succeeding at a DC 17 
Intelligence (Arcana) check realize the doors were 
changed into stone, underscoring the extraordinary 
measures taken to keep something from getting out 
of the next room.
Anyone attempting to open the eastern door must 
first lift the 600 Ib. stone bars from their slots. The 
top bar is set 4 ft. from the floor and the lower bar 
rests 2 ft. below the first. Once the bars are laid to the 
side, the door still requires a DC 18 Strength check to 
pull open.
The heavy stone door leading into this room 
scrapes along the floor until it gets stuck after 
three feet. The room‚Äôs interior is more barren than 
normal. Stains and scuff marks are visible along 
the ground and walls though someone wiped the 
dirt and dust clean. Another large stone door is 
found on the east wall, locked with two heavy 
stone bars.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: If the PCs spend 2 hours in this room, roll 
for a random encounter. It is otherwise safe.
Encounter Condition: [Safe]
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: N/A
C15 . FORMER BARRACKS
There are three more doorways leading out of this 
room, but the doors and frames are gone. The 
openings lead to other chambers, which appear 
to be the same size as the main room. Oozing 
through the doorway of the easternmost chamber 
is a glob of black goo. It is impossible to determine 
how vast it is because it completely covers the 
doorway as it slowly squeezes into the main room.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: About 20 years ago, Arum the Wizard 
trapped a black pudding inside this room after 
narrowly escaping its grasp. Guptu the Pale, an 
ogre mage who was a thorn in Arum‚Äôs side for years 
after the paladin‚Äôs last battle, had set an ambush for 
Arum with the pudding. Guptu and Arum faced off 
many times before the ogre mage was killed, but 
this pudding was his most deadly trap.

214
214
To contain the black pudding, Arum polymor-
phed the iron door and wooden bars into stone, 
hoping to seal the creature inside. He knew the 
pudding would continue to grow until it devoured 
everything in the barracks, but he also knew it 
would never escape on its own. In the event some-
one did manage to set it free, he cleaned the 
meeting room of everything the pudding could 
consume and sealed this chamber with another 
stone door.
The pudding is now so big that it fills whichev-
er room it occupies in the former barracks. It has 
consumed everything inside the chamber, includ-
ing the missing doors and hinges. But because it 
must force its way through the small doorways to 
move from room to room, it is slower than normal. 
It has a speed of 5-ft. and a 10-ft. reach. However, 
any pieces splitting from the host body move and 
attack normally.
PCs succeeding at DC 20 Wisdom (Percep-
tion) checks hear the odd sound of the pudding‚Äôs 
motion, like a gelatinous liquid piling up, or a slow 
scraping waterfall. The sound is coming from the 
central eastern cubicles.
Encounter Condition: Cursed 4
Tactics: By the time the PCs find the black pudding, it 
has already sensed the PCs and is moving to attack. 
It moves directly toward the closest PC, switching 
direction if the PCs run to another room. The pud-
ding cannot split itself on its own and only attacks 
in one direction at a time.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase the speed and reach of the pudding by 10 
ft. and 5 ft. respectively. To decrease the challenge, 
reduce the black pudding‚Äôs hit points by 60.
C16 . COCKATRICE MAZE
The walls here are worn. Corridors turn sharply 
at random intervals or end abruptly. In addition, 
sound seems to soak right into the walls, muffling 
footsteps and speech.
Initial Attitude: Unfriendly
Encounter: There are signs that someone attempted 
to dig further into the rock and stone near several 
of the dead-end passages. No tools can be found, 
but there are piles of dirt and gravel in the area.
About six years ago, a goblin from Region B got sepa-
rated from his raiding party and stumbled upon the 
secret door leading west. After going through the 
room, he found the cockatrice‚Äôs lair, was bitten, and 
turned to stone. The cockatrice entered the secret 
passage to ward off any other trespassers, but the 
door closed behind it. Since then, the cockatrice has 
wandered throughout the maze trying to find its 
way back to its lair.
Many wanderers have found their way into the 
maze since then, only to be turned to stone by the 
crazed beast that attacks everything coming across 
its path (see Room C19 for more cockatrice victims). 
The PCs should stumble upon the cockatrice when 
rounding a corner, as the cockatrice is most often 
found wandering this region.
Encounter Condition: Ambush
Tactics: When encountered, the cockatrice attacks, 
turning weaker PCs to stone. If wounded, it flees to 
Room C19, unless it is cornered. If given no chance 

215
215
to escape, it fiercely attacks the closest PC, until it 
has a chance to flee. The gargoyle in Room C19 has 
helped it fight off attackers in the past.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
allow the cockatrice to surprise the PCs or attack 
from darkness. To decrease the challenge, have 
the cockatrice flee to Room C19 at the sound of 
footsteps.
C17 . FORMER GUARD POST
The moment the door latch is turned, it swings 
inward as a giant guillotine-like pendulum attached 
to the ceiling descends. Inside, along the north wall, 
there are six nail holes some six feet off the ground. 
Resting on its side in the southeastern corner is an 
old wooden chair with three legs.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: PCs who make a DC 13 Wisdom (Per-
ception) check notice that the door is unlocked, 
but that there is constant tension upon it. Anyone 
making a DC 18 Intelligence (Investigation) check 
discovers there is no way to bypass or disarm this 
trap but realizes that it can be triggered at a safe 
distance. The trap was poorly designed, as the pen-
dulum is fastened to the ceiling directly above the 
doorway. This causes it to slam against the frame, 
stopping its progress at the bottom of its arc of 
motion. The trap can only hit someone standing 
directly in front of the door.
 '
Ceiling Pendulum Trap. Detect: DC 15 Wisdom (Per-
ception); Disable: DC 15 Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Tools); A 
character standing in front of the bladed pendulum 
must make a DC 15 Dexterity save or take 3d12 + 8 
slashing damage.
A DC 27 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals the 
secret door on the north wall. This door is extreme-
ly difficult to find because it has not been opened 
in centuries. Anyone finding the secret door needs 
to make a DC 20 Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Tools) check 
to determine how to unlock it. The locking mech-
anism must be triggered each time the door is 
opened, but no special tools are required. Anyone 
making a DC 10 Dexterity check can open the hid-
den portal once they understand how to manipulate 
the opening device. No check is required to open 
the door from inside the secret passageway.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: Except for the broken chair, trap, and the 
secret passageway, this room holds nothing else 
of interest.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter,

C18 . FORMER SPARRING ROOM
Two great stone chairs face each other across this 
wide room, as if waiting for opposing generals to 
sit and watch their champions compete. The chair 
to the west resembles a sailing vessel, the back 
support being a large mast with two cross beams 
and the armrests tapering into the semblance of 
a prow. The chair to the east is shaped to look like 
a tsunami, curled back upon itself and preparing 
to douse whoever sits in its path. Both chairs are 
about 10 ft. in front of their respective walls.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This was the Paladins‚Äô exercise room, 
as well as a place to hold contests for sport, and 
settling disputes. PCs who make DC 15 Wisdom 
(Perception) check notice a faint 20-ft.-wide square 
painted on the ground in the center of the room. 
They also see the ground near the western chair is 
scraped and marred, as if the chair had been moved 
and left slightly askew.
The western chair releases a cloud of insanity 
mist if it is moved in any direction. Anyone stand-
ing between a 10 ft. radius to a 20 ft. radius from 
the chair is allowed a DC 15 Dexterity save to jump 
outside the poisonous cloud and avoid its effect, 
but anyone closer is automatically caught in the 
mist. This trap cannot be bypassed, but it is only ac-
tivated when the chair is moved. The eastern chair 
is not trapped.
Insanity Mist Vapor Trap. Detect: DC 15 Wisdom 
(Perception); Disable: DC 15 Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô 
Tools); Characters in a 10-ft.-square area suffer 
confusion for 3 rounds.

216
216
Anyone succeeding at a DC 13 Intelligence 
(Investigation) check values the chairs at well 
over 1,000 gp each, because of the unique 
craftsmanship.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
inflict a short-term madness on each character hit 
with the insanity mist. To decrease the challenge, 
allow each character caught by the mist a DC 13 
Constitution saving throw to negate the effects.
C19 . LARGE MURAL ROOM
Both doors to this room are open.
The rows of goblin and gnoll statues arranged 
in this room contrast with most of the stark and 
empty rooms found so far. There are also several 
murals painted on the walls, looking as clean and 
bright as the day they were painted. The art on 
the north wall shows a knight in shining golden 
armor, standing at the prow of a ship and looking 
out at an endless ocean. The west wall depicts a 
battle between a battered ship and a coiled sea 
serpent, as a bolt of lightning comes down from 
the sky to strike the serpent. The east wall shows a 
breathtaking picture of a beautiful woman looking 
out over a calm sea at sunset, as if awaiting the 
return of her beloved.
Initial Attitude: Unfriendly
Encounter: The murals painted on the walls are mag-
ically protected, so it is impossible to erase them or 
dilute their colors. If the PCs study the murals, they 
notice titles written in Common painted at the bot-
toms of the pictures. The western mural is entitled 
‚ÄúThe Oceans,‚Äù the northern is called ‚ÄúThe Journey,‚Äù 
and the eastern is simply labeled ‚ÄúVigilance.‚Äù In 
addition to the titles, further inspection reveals the 
incredible detail in each mural. It is clear to every-
one that these paintings would be priceless if they 
had been painted on a portable canvas.
The statues in the room are arranged into four 
rows. There are seven gnoll, seven goblin, and three 
human statues in addition to the gargoyle that 
haunts the place. None of the statues in the room 
are on bases except for the gargoyle standing on 
a square stone block in the second row from the 
west. Anyone examining the statues can make a DC 
20 Wisdom (Perception) check to realize the gar-
goyle is alive. The three human statues are in the 
second row from the east. The statue at the north 
end of the row is of a man dressed in hides who 
just finished a powerful, two-handed swing with 
his warhammer. The second statue from the south 
is of a woman in studded leather armor with an 
empty bow, reaching behind her back for another 
arrow. The last statue in that row shows a small, 
wiry man in leather armor standing on one leg, 
as if dodging something. All the goblin and gnoll 
statues have similar poses, but most of them show 
horrified faces.
Anyone making a DC 14 Intelligence (Investi-
gation) check while studying the statues discovers 
hairline cracks and chips in all of them. In addition, 
several of them have heads that were broken off 
and placed back upon the neck. All the statues were 
once humanoids petrified by the cockatrice before 
being dragged here by the gargoyle. None of them 
would survive the transformation back to flesh.
This room is the home of a gargoyle, but the 
creature does not move until discovered or com-
bat begins with the PCs. Unless the PCs killed the 
cockatrice in Room C16, it is also hiding here. Allow 
a DC 14 Wisdom (Perception) check to see the cock-
atrice as it moves away from them, trying to hide 
behind the statues.
Encounter Condition: Ambush, Conceal-
ment, Echoes 4
Tactics: The gargoyle attacks if it is discovered, if the 
cockatrice enters combat, or if a PC turns his back 
on it while within close range. In any of these cir-
cumstances, the gargoyle attempts to gain surprise 
on the closest PC. If none are within range, it ma-
neuvers to attack unarmored opponents first. The 
gargoyle performs a full attack whenever possible. 
If present, the cockatrice avoids the PCs and does 
not attack unless it is cornered or they attack the 
gargoyle. If the gargoyle is destroyed, or it has less 
than 10 hit points remaining, the cockatrice flees 
back to Room C16.
Treasure: Except for the murals, which cannot be 
removed, the room is empty.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encoun-
ter, add an additional damage die to each of the 
gargoyle‚Äôs attacks. To decrease the challenge, the 

217
217
gargoyle begins the encounter wounded 
(-40 hit points).
C20-C21 . PATH OF 
DESTRUCTION
The demon imprisoned in room C21 has 
many names. His true name is still unknown, 
and this is perhaps the main reason he has 
been so consistently elusive. He is most often 
referred to as Falortuligo, which translates 
into Common as ‚Äúthe clever ash,‚Äù or ‚ÄúAsh, the 
Trickster.‚Äù In addition to his ability to escape impris-
onment of any kind, Ash is renowned for being a 
malicious tormentor.
That reputation was the primary reason he earned 
a special place in this prison. His cell was designed 
with no exit and its entrance is a specially constructed 
gateway, set inside two archways to create a one-way 
portal into the cell. The cell was flooded with water 
and eight massive cold iron chains were designed to 
seek and clamp down on any heat source entering 
the place. When the chains found purchase on the 
demon that was transported here, the runes on the 
walls of the cell activated and froze everything solid.
Ash was discovered by a group of angels and 
captured. He was then transported to the cell‚Äôs entry 
chamber after construction was completed (room 
C110). The demon offered little resistance until the 
last moment, when he pushed a solar angel named 
Amarantiel into the prison portal. Right before he 
was forced inside himself, Amarantiel (which means 
‚ÄúUnfading Vigilance‚Äù in the Celestial tongue) knew 
there would be no escape from the cell. He accepted 
his imprisonment, fighting to subdue Ash in order 
to hasten the freezing process. Though unable to 
prevent one chain from attaching itself to his body, 
Amarantiel directed the other seven chains to Ash. 
The magical walls then froze them both in solid ice 
for millennia.
If Amarantiel thought his unjust interment would 
be spent in quiet contemplation, he was quickly 
corrected by Ash. From the first hour of their con-
finement, Falortuligo initiated a telepathic dialog 
with Amarantiel. Over the centuries, Ash embedded 
thoughts and voices into Amarantiel‚Äôs mind, convinc-
ing him that the angel had been falsely imprisoned. 
During the last hundred years of their imprisonment, 
the demon twisted his soothing words until Amaran-
tiel believed Ash was another solar angel.
The final key to unlocking Ash‚Äôs prison came when 
the wizard Arum arrived. A decade or so ago, Arum 
built a laboratory (in room C20) and Ash took the 
opportunity to speak telepathically with the wizard. 
Arum believed Ash was a falsely imprisoned angel, 
caught when the demon Falortuligo was placed in his 
cell within the prison complex. The demon told Arum 
it was impossible for him to gain freedom with-
out also setting the demon free. Arum was warned 
against telling anyone they had spoken, to prevent 
the possibility of someone freeing the angel, because 
it would also release the demon. Ash‚Äôs steadfast re-
fusal of all offers of assistance, lest the demon be set 
free, convinced Arum that the voice in his head was 
that of the angel Amarantiel.
Posing as Amarantiel, Ash asked nothing of the wiz-
ard, but occasionally conversed with Arum during his 
studies. These conversations became more frequent 
as Arum asked ‚ÄúAsh‚Äù for advice on magical theories 
and practices while working in his lab. It was during 
one such discussion about the creation of magical 
weaponry that Ash set in motion a plan that would 
lead to his inevitable release.
Arum complained about spending too much time 
maintaining his forge to generate sufficient heat, 
and that his research was suffering as a result. Ash 
suggested placing wards on the front of the forge to 
reflect the heat back into the walls. A higher level of 
heat would then be maintained. Not coincidentally, 
this would also focus a great amount of heat on the 
stone wall surrounding the prison. Arum, however, 
did not know how close he was to Ash‚Äòs icy prison cell. 

218
218
It was this mixture of intense cold from the prison 
and constant heat from the forge that eventually 
cracked the wall separating Rooms C20 and C21 and 
melted the ice to water, which boiled away into the 
forge. Once the wall was weakened, Falortuligo and 
Amarantiel broke free.
When they broke through the wall of the prison, 
the members of the Order of Merunda confronted 
them. At first, Amarantiel believed Ash was another 
angel, and he did not understand why the Paladins of 
Merunda fought him. For millennia, the demon de-
ceived Amarantiel, who now believed Ash was his kin.
While the brave followers of Merunda fought the 
demon, Arum used several illusions to trick Amaran-
tiel into activating his true sight. It was then that the 
veil was lifted from the angel‚Äôs eyes and he under-
stood the nature of Ash‚Äôs treachery. The Paladins of 
Merunda gave their lives to allow Amarantiel to see 
through the demon‚Äôs lies. Their sacrifice allowed the 
angel to regain his senses and slay the demon.
The events leading up to the final confrontation 
between the demon and Amarantiel is recorded in 
Arum‚Äôs account of the battle in Room C64.
This Section has no random encounters.
C20 . ARUM'S FORMER LABORATORY
Piles of rubble and cracked stone blocks along the 
walls take up most of the floor of this chamber. 
Inside the room, an immense mound of debris is 
splayed out upon the ground in front of a gaping 
hole in the eastern wall. The rest of the chamber 
is a jumble of crushed timber and broken glass 
strewn about the larger pieces of stone. The west 
wall is scorched, especially around the entrance to 
the room where an overturned forge lays cold and 
broken against the wall.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room is the former laboratory and 
living quarters of the wizard Arum. Judging by the 
ground and dispersal pattern of the explosion, 
the hole in the eastern wall is where the forge 
was located before the wall broke. There is a faint 
residue of abjuration magic coming from the 
crushed forge. If PCs examine the forge closer, they 
can attempt a DC 23 Intelligence (Arcana) check to 
decipher the magical runes written inside as wards 
that reflect the heat and energy of the forge back 
into itself.
PCs succeeding at DC 19 Wisdom (Perception) 
checks find several books wedged under the mass 
of stones and boulders. It is clear the books are 
damaged, but they may be of some use, if the 
PCs can find a way to move the massive blocks to 
retrieve them. Most of the blocks of stone in the 
room weigh more than 500 lbs. each, and many 
smaller boulders must be removed before the larg-
er ones can be pushed aside. Anyone attempting 
to clear the rubble must make three separate DC 
17 Strength checks. For each Strength check made, 
one book can be recovered. No more than one 
Strength check can be made every 15 minutes. PCs 
failing to rest after each check suffer cumulative 
points of Exhaustion every half hour.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: There is no treasure here unless the PCs 
remove at least three of the undamaged books from 
under the stones. Anyone proficient with Intelli-
gence (Arcana) gains a permanent +2 with the skill 
after spending one month reading the fragments 
of these three books. No further advantages are 
gained for reading more books, but a total of seven 
can be recovered.
Scaling: N/A
C21 . BROKEN PRISON OF FALORTULIGO
This enormous, one hundred ft. tall room is 
noticeably colder than other rooms in the area. 
Four massive chains hang like pillars from the 
ceiling at even intervals in the center of the 
chamber. Coiled upon the ground amid the last 
few links hanging from the ceiling are four more 
impossibly huge chains. The shackles at the end of 
each chain are twisted and warped, as if something 
of immense strength broke its way free. The rest 
of the vast room is surprisingly empty, save for 
the large blue runes encircling the chamber and 
an ornate archway on the north wall. The runes 
emit a faint, steady, and oscillating glow, as if 
imitating the breathing patterns of an enormous 
sleeping beast.
Initial Attitude: Friendly

219
219
Encounter: PCs succeeding at a DC 17 Intelligence 
(Investigation) check realize the chains have prop-
erties of cold iron and adamantine. The PCs who 
make such checks also know it should not be 
possible to combine those two metals, since one is 
forged at low temperature and the other at ex-
tremely high temperatures.
The ornate archway on the north wall has intri-
cate designs surrounding a curtain-like interior. 
The surface of the archway is solid, but has a fluid 
sensation to it. There is no way to pass through the

A few minutes after the PCs enter the room, 
Zrino (a lantern archon) arrives through the arch-
way from Room C110. PCs succeeding at a DC 15 
Wisdom (Perception) check see the creature pass 
through the magical entrance. The archon gives 
the PCs information regarding the prison and its 
current state , as well as providing background 
information about this room (including what little it 
knows about its former occupants).
Zrino‚Äôs primary task is to inform the PCs that a 
special key (in Room C105) lends access to anoth-
er door in the dungeon. The archon describes the 
key and indicates it lies to the southeast, but to get 
there, the PCs need to deal with danger along the 
way. The PCs also need the Mark of the Righteous, 
for only those who are blessed with this mark can 
open the door leading into the room where the 
key lies. The archon is able and willing to give the 
mark to those who want it, except for evil-aligned

The Mark of the Righteous endows a permanent 
+1 bonus on all saving throws for good characters. 
Neutral characters are unaffected by its effect. If a 
character with the mark ever becomes evil, he loses 
the bonus and suffers a -2 luck penalty on all saving 
throws for as long as they remain evil or until the

by shining a light on the palm of any non-evil char-
acter wishing to receive it. Close examination of 
a marked hand shows a faintly glowing sigil upon

reveals this sigil as an ancient symbol denoting

Righteous also grants the bearer the ability to read 
and understand Celestial, but not speak it.
If the PCs ask for aid, the archon replies in a 
musical voice, ‚ÄúI can give you light for your eyes 
and illumination for your mind, but our paths do 
not cross.‚Äù Zrino casts continual flame (up to twice 
per PC) on any item the PCs want enchanted. Aside 
from the information regarding the prison and the 
special key, he knows little about the inhabitants 
of the region or the current state of affairs in any 
region other than C and G.
If questioned about Arum, Zrino simply says, 
‚ÄúThe wizard is long gone.‚Äù Zrino is one of the 
few inhabitants of the region who knows this. If 
asked about a cure for petrification, the archon 
states, ‚ÄúGahrr‚Äôk has what you seek, but does not 
help others.‚Äù
Encounter Condition: [Fear 15], Fearless, Hallowed 3, 
Positive Energy
Tactics: If anyone attacks Zrino, he activates Aura 
of Menace and then flies out of range. If the PCs 
pursue, he attacks with a scorching ray each round

In the event the PCs halt their attack, a DC 20 
Charisma (Persuasion) check convinces the archon 
to cease fighting as well. Evil PCs receive Disadvan-
tage to that check.
Treasure: PCs searching the room for at least 1 hour

Under the tile is a long strongbox, large enough to

of warding (Explosive Runes) on it and requires a DC

C22-C28 . NEUTRAL ZONE .
Originally, the section comprising Rooms C22-C28 
was a processing station for the smaller prison cells 
to the east and west. When an enormous earthquake 
tore a jagged chasm into the foundation of the dun-
geon prison hundreds of years ago, this region was 
all but abandoned.
For the last ten years, the rooms in this section 
were claimed by different inhabitants, including gob-
lins (from Region B) and gnolls from the Gnashing 
Fang Tribe (Rooms C29-C42). Before then, it was 
patrolled and monitored by the Paladins of Merun-
da, though they lived elsewhere in the region. To-
day, however, the section is primarily a buffer zone 
between the goblin and gnoll factions.
The rooms in this area are spattered with long-
dried blood and gore, showing signs of many battles. 
Though the halls are much cleaner than the rooms, 
most doors have crude markings upon them.

The walls of this room are black, but the floor is

C23 . KILLER TRAP
The stench of decaying flesh lingers here. The

This door seems normal at first, but it‚Äôs locking

Encounter Condition: Haunted, Stagnant Air
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: The necklace is a simple silver medallion

The door to this small room squeaks open.

C29-C42 . GNASHING FANG TRIBAL GROUNDS .
Nine years ago, a hunting party from the Howling 
Fang Tribe stumbled upon the entrance to the prison. 
The tribal Chieftain, Hag-grt, decided the tribe need-
ed an additional lair and sent one-third of his tribe 
into the dungeon to pave the way for the rest of his 
people. Hag-grt, however, never intended to enter 
the underground prison.
The Howling Fang Tribe was now too large to 
control, and Hag-grt too old to fight off younger and 
stronger gnoll challengers. Wise as he was, he sent 
the toughest gnolls into the dungeon and remained 
with a smaller tribe; one he could control without 
competition.
So it was, that a band of 85 gnolls entered the dun-
geon. They had great success at first, scaring off or 
killing many humanoid races and fiendish beasts sur-
rounding the entrance. But over time, they 
found the dungeon‚Äôs massive, sprawling 
tunnels too difficult to navigate and 
soon became lost. Discord broke out 
among the gnolls and a demand for 
leadership reared its head. Two vile 
gnoll brothers, Gahrr‚Äôk and Yie-ar‚Äôk, 
barked challenges, each claiming 
leadership of the group.
After some discussion, Gahrr‚Äôk 
agreed to support his brother, Yie-
ar‚Äôk. But the gnolls did not all agree 
that he should lead, and one by one, 
the gnolls stepped forth to contest 
his leadership. After six challeng-
ers, a young hot-headed gnoll 
named Attuk‚Äôk stepped forward 
and, in a ferocious battle, crippled 
Yier-ar‚Äôk. Although Attuk‚Äôk was de-
feated, Gahrr‚Äôk stepped forward and 
decapitated both of them, assuring 
his place as leader of the tribe. After that, no one 
challenged Gahrr‚Äôk‚Äôs right to lead.
Gahrr‚Äôk (Room C37) took the remaining gnolls 
and formed what became the Gnashing Fang Tribe. 
Gahrr‚Äôk then led his tribe further into the dungeon 
prison. By the time the gnolls realized that he never 
intended to leave the vast underground complex, they 
had little choice but to follow their chieftain.
Sometime after 
entering the 

225

dungeon, Gahrr‚Äôk met the Goblin King, Argliss. 
Though unafraid of the goblin, he worked out an 
immediate agreement with Argliss rather than fight 
(especially without a lair of their own yet). Gahrr‚Äôk dis-
covered Argliss was fearful of the wizard Arum (to the 
east), and volunteered to kill the wizard in exchange 
for a vague alliance between their two tribes. Thinking 
either the wizard or the gnolls would be destroyed

ing along 20 of his own warriors to assist. Gahrr‚Äôk 
left the Goblin King‚Äôs domain and paused in Room 
C29 to inspect his new forces. He charged forward to

Gahrr‚Äôk then took 14 goblins as slaves and killed 
the other six as an example. In the next few months, 
Gahrr‚Äôk sent several reports to the Goblin King. These 
reports described deadly battles fought against the

the wizard.

C29 . WESTERN GNOLL MUSTERING 
ROOM
This large room has a door in each corner and one

used. Many of the weapons are in excellent con-

C31 . HAUNTED ROOM
The floor of this large chamber is scattered with

C32 . WESTERN GNOLL MUSTERING 
ROOM
This large hall contains three mounds of crushed 
rock. This refuse is lined upon the southern wall, 
forming six-ft-high piles. It is obvious by the state 
of disrepair of the ceiling as well as the east and 
south walls that the rubble was once part of the 
walls and ceilings of this room. The door in the 
middle of the north wall is wide open, revealing the

Initial Attitude: Unfriendly
Encounter: It is obvious that this room suffered some 
sort of damage, but whether it was caused by a 
minor cave-in or a great battle is difficult to say. 
Though the southern wall, eastern wall, and ceil-
ing are uneven, the stone of these surfaces looks 
identical to that of the other walls and floor, which 
is relatively smooth and worn.
Before the wights took over Room C31, this area 
was used as a mustering place for the gnolls of the 
Gnashing Fang Tribe and, with the exception of the 
regular patrol passing through the chamber, it re-
mained mostly empty the rest of the time. Current-
ly, a cunning gnoll ranger guards the place.
Verk‚Äônek, a respected gnoll ranger and loyal 
lieutenant, took it upon himself to set up a per-
manent vigil in this hall. Fearing the wights in 
Room C31 might come deeper into Gnashing Fang 
territory, Verk‚Äônek hides behind broken stones 
in the southeast corner. He remains hidden and 
silent when patrols of Gnashing Fang warriors pass 
through the hall or if his compatriots escort the 
PCs to Gahrr‚Äôk.
If the PCs enter unescorted, Verk‚Äônek remains 
hidden but demands in a clear voice that the PCs 
identify themselves and their business in Gnashing 
Fang territory. Verk‚Äônek‚Äôs voice is loud and clear, 
alerting gnolls in Room C31 that succeed at a DC 
16 Wisdom (Perception) check. Four gnolls enter 
the hall 1d3 rounds later, while the other warns the 
gnolls in Room C35, who arrive 1d3 rounds after the 
group from Room C31 arrives.
Unless provoked, Verk‚Äônek does not engage the 
PCs. Like most members of his tribe, he prefers 
diplomacy. Verk‚Äônek‚Äôs most immediate concerns are 
the wights. If he knows the PCs destroyed the crea-
tures, his attitude shifts to friendly and he reveals

for his tribemates to join him.
Encounter Condition: Ambush, Cover, Hazardous 
Footing 16
Tactics: In battle, Verk‚Äônek remains mostly hidden

PCs must maneuver around the rubble in the east-
ern portion of the southern wall.
Treasure: The large quiver Verk‚Äônek carries holds 40 
arrows and is made of boiled leather and decorated

cate than the next. Because of its artistic value, it is

Both doors to this room are open.

PCs wishing to trade information or goods. If the 
PCs wish to pass through Gnashing Fang tribal 
grounds, the gnolls insist that they speak to their 
chieftain Gahr‚Äôr‚Äôk (and escort them to Room C37).
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: If fighting ensues, the gnolls will charge the 
PCs. They target the warriors of the party first and 
flank them whenever they can.

229
229
The gnolls in Room C35 are automatically aware of a 
fight, and join 1d3 rounds later. Allow the sleeping 
gnolls in Room C36 a DC 25 Wisdom (Perception) 
check. If they hear trouble, these warriors aid their 
fellow tribesmen in 1d4+2 rounds.
Treasure: In addition to the weapons they carry, each 
of these gnolls have 1d4 gp worth of small, uncut 
semi-precious gemstones and silver coins. Addi-
tionally, one wears a decorative bronze armband. 
Carved upon its surface in simple lines is a mighty 
bear. This trinket is worth upwards of 15 gp. The 
weapons racks near the doors holds two clubs, a 
great club, and three battle axes; all average quality. 
A successful DC 14 Wisdom (Search) check in this 
room also reveals a dagger with a jewel-embedded 
hilt worth 100 gp tucked under a crude mattress of 
a bunk, as well as a pouch containing 41 cp.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add two gnolls. To decrease the challenge, remove 
two gnolls.
C34 . SECOND GUARDROOM
This wide room contains the wooden frames of 
twelve bunk beds. A thin layer of dust covers the 
frames and floor of this chamber, suggesting that 
the place has not been used in a while.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room used to house gnolls from the 
Gnashing Fang Tribe, but none have used it in over 
two years.
Encounter Condition: Safe
Tactics: While this room is safe to rest in, the con-
stant traffic of gnolls just outside the doors is 
nerve-racking.
Treasure: A successful DC 17 Wisdom (Perception) 
check spots a silver coin tucked under the leg of 
one of the bunk beds.
Scaling: N/A
C35 . THIRD GUARDROOM
A stone slab dominates the southeast corner of this 
chamber. The slab is cracked in many places and its 
surface is covered with crude but colorful graffiti. 
Several wooden stools have been placed around the 
painted flat stone ‚Äútable,‚Äù and a number of empty 
jars rest upon it. There are a dozen bunk beds lining 
the north and west walls, as well as a simple iron 
rack holding several weapons beside the southern 
door, which is wide open.
Three gnolls sit in a circle in the middle of the 
room: one is holding a handful of bones while the 
others are eagerly looking on. In front of each of 
the canine-faced humanoids, stacked upon the floor 
before them, are piles of copper coins.
Initial Attitude: Neutral
Encounter: Three gnoll warriors are sitting in a 
circle in the middle of the room, playing a game 
of chance. Though their attention is focused on 
their game, they keep their ears open to any noise 
coming from Room C29. They suffer Disadvantage 
to any checks made to notice the PCs.
Encounter Condition: Echoes 4
Tactics: These gnolls are more interested in acquir-
ing copper (or silver!) for use in gambling, rather 
than fighting. But, if the PCs pose any threat to 
them, or if they learn that they have harmed any 
member of their tribe, they grab their weapons and 
attack them.
In combat, two gnolls stand in the middle of 
the room, preventing the PCs from reaching their 
companion, whose task it is to alert the warriors 
in Rooms C33 and C36, as well as their chieftain in 
Room C37. This gnoll stays behind his companions 
and barks loudly. He continues to bark until he is 
either forced into melee or reinforcements arrive, at 
which point he joins the fighting.
The gnolls in Room C33 are instantly alerted and 
arrive 1d3 rounds later. Allow the sleeping warriors 
in Room C36 a DC 26 Wisdom (Perception) check 
to notice the ruckus. If they are awakened, these 
gnolls enter this guardroom 1d3 rounds later. 
Gahrr‚Äôk (Room C37) will notice the fighting if he (or 
anyone else in his throne room) succeeds at a DC 
18 Wisdom (Perception) check. They then rouse the 
warriors in Room C36 and arrive within 1d3 rounds.

230
230
Treasure: There is a total of 151 cp lying upon the 
ground of this chamber. The tokens the gnolls 
are using for their game are six elaborately carved 
bones with several designs printed upon them. 
Though these are mostly useless, a gnoll might pay 
upwards of 5 gp for them.
The stone tablet is used as both a table and canvas 
for painting. The jars lying upon it are empty save 
for a thick layer of dried paint. Most of the images 
represent animals and magical beasts hunted by 
bands of gnolls. They are crude and worthless to all 
but gnolls.
The weapons rack near the southern entrance holds 
a great-axe, two battle-axes, a warhammer, and a 
masterwork great club.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
give each gnoll the Second Wind Bonus Action (1/
rest: recover 1d10 + 2 hit points). To decrease the 
challenge, remove one gnoll.
C36. Fourth Guardroom
There are four humanoids in this chamber. These 
creatures are tall, with their furry bodies and 
canine-like faces exposed as they slumber upon 
large bunk beds. Though there are more bunks 
here than there are inhabitants, twelve beds in all, 
only nine of these have mattresses and woolen 
blankets upon them. There is a pair of well-polished 
great axes resting upon the wall close to the 
northwestern door.
Initial Attitude: Unfriendly
Encounter: This guardroom normally houses nine 
gnolls, but some are out on patrol. There are four 
gnoll warriors currently sleeping here. If intrud-
ing PCs rouse them, they rush out of their beds 
and ready for battle. Unlike most other members 
of their tribe, they are prone to attack PCs enter-
ing their private chamber uninvited, but PCs who 
successfully change their initial attitude through the 
use of a Charisma (Persuasion) check might avoid 
any combat.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: In battle, these warriors will fight savagely, 
and flank the more heavily armed and armored foes 
as often as they can manage.
While in combat, these gnolls utter loud barks 
to alert the rest of their tribe. Allow the gnolls in 
Room C35 and the chieftain in Room C37 a DC 15 
Wisdom (Perception) check to notice the ruckus. If 
they do, these gnolls join the fight in 1d3 rounds. 
Similarly, allow the gnolls in Room C33 a DC 18 
Wisdom (Perception) check to hear the commotion. 
These warriors join the battle 1d4+2 rounds after 
they are made aware of it.
Treasure: Each gnoll in this chamber carries 1d4 gp 
worth of gemstones and assorted coins. One of 
them also has a masterwork warhammer, which 
he keeps at the foot of his bed. The two great axes 
lying upon the north wall near the western door are 
sound weapons of ordinary quality.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
give each gnoll the Second Wind Bonus Action (1/
rest: recover 1d10 + 2 hit points). To decrease the 
challenge, remove one gnoll.
C37. Gahrr'k's Chamber
A wide black pelt covers a good portion of the floor 
in the middle of this large chamber. A bed and an 
iron chest lie in the northeast corner of the room, 
while a narrow wooden desk takes up most of the 
northwest corner. A stone chair that resembles a 
kingly throne sits upon the floor. ln the middle of 
the northern wall, the flames from several torches 
set amidst this wall burn, bathing the room in a 
warm golden light.
Upon the throne-like chair is a large figure with 
the features of a wild dog, with one ear missing, 
replaced by scar tissue. The fur of the humanoid, 
dark and disheveled, is visible where its burgundy 
clothing and polished scale mail armor do not 
cover it. The fiery eyes of the inhuman face burn 
brightly. Another male humanoid bearing similar 
features stands near the creature on the throne. 
Three other gnoll warriors are standing by the 
southern door, as if awaiting orders.

231
231
Initial Attitude: Neutral
Encounter: Gahrr‚Äôk One-Ear, the powerful, savage 
gnoll chieftain of the Gnashing Fang Tribe, lives in 
this room. Gahrr‚Äôk is a fierce and proven warrior 
who won the respect of his peers long ago. He rules 
the Gnashing Fang Tribe and his ambitions include 
the invasion of the goblin tribe to the west, for the 
war he waged against the Goblin King caused his 
tribe to suffer terrible losses. Though Gahrr‚Äôk real-
izes this is a long-term endeavor, he continues to 
dream of the day when the territory of Argliss‚Äô the 
Goblin King falls under his control.
If members of his tribe escorted the PCs to 
Gahrr‚Äôk‚Äôs chamber and they offered no resistance 
or threat to his people, the chieftain is eager to talk 
and negotiate with them. Gahrr‚Äôk is more than will-
ing to trade information and safe passage through 
the territory controlled by the Gnashing Fang Tribe 
in exchange for weapons and other valuables. He 
is most interested in hearing what the PCs have 
learned about the other regions of the dungeon, 
especially if they have news of Argliss or his lowly 
goblins. If the PCs inform Gahrr‚Äôk that they dis-
posed of the goblin king, the chieftain is much 
more willing to help the PCs.
A cunning gnoll, Gahrr‚Äôk negotiates with the 
PCs, hoping to gain their assistance in getting rid 
of the hill giant family to the east, as well as the 
goblins to the west (should they still remain). If 
the PCs show no interest in any of these endeav-
ors but are respectful of Gahrr‚Äôk and his people, 
the chieftain will agree to grant them safe passage 
through his domain. If the PCs are interested in 
slaughtering the goblins or routing out the giants, 
Gahrr‚Äôk offers all the gold he possesses (kept in his 
chest) in exchange for the head of the three giants 
or the goblin king. The gnolls do not actively help 
the PCs in such a mission, but they offer them aid 
with menial tasks and a safe haven.
When questioned on the wizard Arum, Gahrr‚Äôk 
reveals he has never seen him and suspects he is ei-
ther dead or long ago left the dungeon. He has ex-
plored most of the wizard‚Äôs domain, and even used 
portions of it in the past to house the warriors of 
his tribe. Though he abandoned any claims he had 
on the wizards territory long ago (because of the 
many traps found therein, but also because of the 
diminished number of warriors under his control), 
Gahrr‚Äôk occasionally sends scouts to investigate. As 
far as he knows, no one lives there.
If asked about the goblin king, Gahrr‚Äôk explains 
that the goblins have long been a thorn in his 
side, but that in recent years the fighting between 
Argliss‚Äô people and the Gnashing Fang Tribe almost 
ceased mainly because Gahrr‚Äôk does not have the 
manpower to wage a constant war against the 
little vermin.
If the PCs barter with Gahrr‚Äôk, he offers any of 
the weapons stored in Room C30 in exchange for 
axes, clubs, hammers, bows and arrows, crossbows 
and bolts, ropes, or oil flasks. Gahrr‚Äôk One-Ear has 
a small jar of stone 
salve with 
two appli-
cations left, 
enough to 
restore two 
people 
back to 
flesh. 
He is willing 
to trade it for weap-
ons or various other goods 
valued at 8,000 gp or more. Gold 
coins alone cannot account for more than half of 
this deal, however, as coins are nearly worthless 
down here. The chieftain has little else to offer, but 
listens to any offers of diplomacy the PCs make.
If the PCs barge into his chamber unescorted, 
or if the chieftain learns they killed members of 
his tribe, he picks up his enchanted great club and 
attacks. His lieutenant and three bodyguards react 
instantly.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: In combat, Gahrr‚Äôk lets his men handle the 
PCs while he drinks a draught of his potion of speed. 
The following round, he attacks heavily armored 
PCs first. Meanwhile, the bodyguards engage 
the PCs in melee and the lieutenant attacks the 
spellcasters.
These warriors bark loudly in combat, and their 
cries alarm the gnolls in Room C33 if they make a 
DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check, as well as those 
in Rooms C33 and C36 if they succeed at a DC 20 
Wisdom (Perception) check. These warriors come 
to aid their chieftain 1d4+2 rounds after they have 
been made aware of the ruckus.
Treasure: In addition to the weapons they carry, the 
three gnolls have 1d4 gp worth of small jewels and 

232
232
coins. The pelts upon the chieftain‚Äôs bed are in good 
condition and could be sold for upwards of 30 gp. 
Gahrr‚Äôk carries a variety of magical items and a 
small silvery key hangs from a golden chain (worth 
35 gp) at his neck. This key unlocks the chest at the 
foot of the bed.
Gahrr‚Äôk‚Äôs chest is made of iron. It is locked and 
requires a DC 22 Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Tools) check 
or the chieftain‚Äôs key to unlock. Inside, there is a 
total of 754 gp and 1,312 sp. On top of the coins 
there is a green velvet pouch containing three 
small diamonds (each worth 750 gp), a tarnished 
silvered dagger, and an empty ivory scroll case. 
When closed, this scroll case can be submerged in 
water without risk of damaging any parchment held 
inside. This object is worth 20 times the value of

Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add a fiendish darkmantle (Region A), that Gahrr‚Äôk 
befriended with wild empathy. To decrease the 
challenge, remove two gnolls or the lieutenant from

C38 . CELLBLOCK
The door on the eastern wall is locked and requires 
the jailer‚Äôs key (see below) or a successful DC 22 
Dexterity check. It can be unlocked from either side, 
but PCs coming from the east automatically alert the 
inhabitants.
This wide hallway contains four wooden doors with 
small windows and iron bars upon both the north 
and south walls. These eight doors open into what 
appears to be eight small cells, but only one of 
them is closed. There are two double doors made of 
wood and reinforced with iron plates in the center 
of the north wall. Similar doors appear in the 
middle of the south wall.
In the center of the room is a long table made 
out of wood with six comfortable-looking wooden 
chairs set around it. There are four gnolls in this 
room. Three of them hold great axes and shields 
while a third is armed with an axe and a whip.
Initial Attitude: Neutral
Encounter: Five of the cell doors have no locks and 
there is no obvious way to lock them. The other 
cells have workable locking mechanisms, but only 
the door to the southeastern cell is closed and 
locked. Inside this cell is the recently expired body 
of a goblin. The creature‚Äôs skin is taut and scarred 
with countless whip marks. It probably died from 
both malnutrition and abuse.
Ramk‚Äômva, the gnoll jailer, and three gnolls are 
in charge of securing the prison, as well as pro-
tecting the borders of the Gnashing Fang Tribe. 
Ramk‚Äômva is an old and cunning gnoll who earned 
the trust of his chieftain long ago. He is content 
with his position within the tribe and happy to 
oversee the prisons, especially since so little needs 
to be done.
To help control their territory, the gnolls keep 
the eastern door locked at all times. Ramk‚Äômva 
holds the key, but does not let anyone through, 
unless Gahrr‚Äôk orders it.
If the PCs enter this room from the east, they 
must first pick the lock of the door. The gnolls 
stand ready to face them in battle when they enter, 
but Ramk‚Äòmva is willing to talk. He informs them 
that this marks the boundary of the Gnashing Fang 
tribal grounds and has his warriors escort the PCs 
to Gahrr‚Äôk (in Room C37). If the PCs refuse, but 
agree not to disturb the tribe, Ramk‚Äômva is happy 
to bid them goodbye. If the PCs threaten or attack 
the gnolls, combat ensues.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: If combat is inevitable, Ramk‚Äômva lets the 
three warriors handle the PCs while he makes his 
way to Rooms C36, C35, and C37 to alert the other 
gnolls of intruders. Though he does not wish to 
fight, if cornered or unable to escape, Ramk‚Äômva 
fights until defeated. In combat, he uses both his 
battle-axe and whip to disarm the PCs every chance 
he gets. Meanwhile, the three warriors engage in 
melee, targeting the strongest first, using gang 
tactics whenever possible.
If fighting breaks out in the cellblock, allow 
the gnolls in Rooms C33, C34, C36, and C37 a DC 
22 Wisdom (Perception) check to hear the sound 
of battle. If they do, they come to aid their fellow 
tribesmen 1d4+2 rounds thereafter.
Treasure: The cells hold nothing valuable, but each 
of the warriors in this room carries a pouch with 
1d4 gp worth of small gemstones, silver coins, and 
copper pieces. Ramk‚Äômva the Jailer has a ring of 
keys that unlocks the eastern door as well as each 
of the three cells that still have a working locking 
mechanism upon their doors. One of the keys 

233
233
he carries also unlocks the doors of Rooms C40, 
C41, and C42, as well as the double doors south 
of Room C40.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
double the number of gnoll warriors present and 
give Ramk‚Äômva Sneak Attack (4d6). To decrease the 
challenge, remove three gnolls.
C39 . LIEUTENANT'S QUARTERS
The doors opening into this chamber are unlocked. 
Inside the small room, cast in the heavy shadows, 
are two narrow but comfortable-looking beds. The 
beds are covered with thick animal pelts.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room is the quarters of two power-
ful members of the Gnashing Fang Tribe. Verk‚Äônek 
holds the title of lieutenant and guards‚Äô Room C32, 
and Nirk‚Äôna is the chieftain‚Äôs right-hand man (in 
Room C37). Both are feared by the warriors of the 
tribe and trust Ramk‚Äômva (Room C38) to protect 
their private chamber.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: A successful DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) 
check made in this room uncovers a small wooden 
chest hidden under one of the beds. This chest is 
unlocked and holds 37 sp, a large chunk of golden 
amber (worth 95 gp), and a bronze bracelet large 
enough to cover the entire forearm of a medium 
sized creature (worth 50 gp).
Scaling: N/A
C40 . SECURED AREA
All the doors to this room are locked. Ramk‚Äômva 
(Room C38) possesses the only key. A DC 23 Dexterity 
check is required to unlock any of the doors.
This hallway is cast in total darkness. Upon closer 
examination, the floor here has several scuff marks 
imprinted on the cold stone. The floor, however, is 
covered with a thick blanket of dust, suggesting 
that although there once was heavy traffic in this 
area, this hall has not been entered in years.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room and the locked double doors 
leading into it serve as a safety buffer between the
