gerous creatures to the south (Rooms C41 and C42).
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: N/A
C41 . RUST MONSTER'S PRISON CELL
The doors of this cell are made of heavy oak and 
several wooden beams nailed into the stone wall 
block it. Anyone wishing to enter this room must 
first remove the wooden planks that block the en-
trance. Each of the five beams can be pulled with a 
successful DC 20 Strength check. This action reveals a 
rusted-but-functional iron lock mechanism. A DC 19 
Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Tools) check is required to unlock 
the door unless the PCs have acquired its key from 
Room C38. The PC opening this door must succeed 
at a DC 20 Dexterity check. Failing this check results 
in the door falling off its hinges, which are completely 
eaten by rust.
Inside this large, shadowy chamber is an insect-like 
creature with four squat legs, long antennae, and 
a squat body protected by an odd hide. The walls 
of this chamber are made of stone, and, like most 
of the dungeon, seem to have been carved out 
from the sheer bedrock. These walls, however, have 
turned into a deep rust-colored shade, as if every 
speck of metal within them had rusted.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: A Large rust monster is locked in this 
room. The creature has been feeding on the tiny 
residues of iron found within the walls of its prison. 
It is maddened and hateful, standing ready to 
charge anyone fool enough to unlock its cell.
While the room itself is not haunted, remaining in it 
for more than 24 hours can have damaging effects. 
Soft, almost imperceptible echoes bounce from the 
walls of the room. As time goes on, these echoes 
become harder and harder to block out, until the 
creature inside begins to think the sounds are part 
of their own mind. Anyone failing a Wisdom save 
(DC 15 + 1 per previous save) suffers 1 point of Wis-
dom damage, which takes twice as long to heal as 

234
234
normal. This save must be repeated every two hours 
beyond the first 24.
Encounter Condition: Echoes 4, Fearless, [Safe]
Tactics: The monster has become mindless as a result 
of being trapped in the cell too long. It attacks the 
closest PC in metal armor and fights ferociously. It 
continues to attack the PC until his armor is beyond 
repair, then targets weapons, before moving on to 
the next PC. While rust monsters themselves do 
not normally act like trapped animals, this one has 
suffered too much from its lengthy imprisonment.
Treasure: Anything of value is now a pile of rust, 
although there is a masterwork cudgel on the floor 
in the corner of the room. Allow the PCs to dig 
through the piles all they like, however.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add one rust monster. To decrease the challenge, 
have the rust monster wounded (-30 hit points).
C42 . IMPRISONED OCHRE JELLY
The doors leading into this cell are locked. The key to 
unlock them can be found in Room C38. Otherwise, a 
DC 15 Dexterity check is enough to bypass the lock.
This chamber contains a mass of yellowish 
ooze. The strange entity is oddly shaped and, 
in the darkness, moves slowly. Its slick surface 
undulates, reflecting light against the black of the 
dungeon walls.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: An ochre jelly is trapped in this cell. The 
creature has been imprisoned here for decades, and 
not even the gnolls could say who is responsible for 
imprisoning it here. Its corrosive jelly eats away at 
the stonework, turning it black.
Encounter Condition: Ambush (darkness), Fear-
less, [Safe]
Tactics: As soon as anyone opens the door, the ochre 
jelly strikes the first target that gets in its way. In 
combat, it grapples and constricts its prey. If a PC 
is stunned, it moves on to the next, so it can escape 
without fear of reprisal. If the PCs leave it a way out, 
it moves into the corridor outside the door. It does 
not fight unless it has to.
Treasure: Any treasure that may have existed 
is slag now.

C43-C59 . THE WIZARD'S DOMAIN
Following the brutal deaths of the knights and pala-
dins of Merunda, and the destruction of his former 
laboratory (see Rooms C20 and C21), the wizard 
Arum established a home for himself in this section 
of the dungeon. The wizard is responsible for the 
accidental liberation of the demon Falortuligo (Room 
C21). Though Arum left long ago, this section is still 
considered his, as few creatures dare venture here 
and most inhabitants assume he is still around.
GMs wishing to complete the saga of Arum can 
place his corpse in one of the rooms where he com-
mitted suicide, somewhere in Region O. Alternatively, 
place a wraith, ghost, lich, or wight somewhere in this 
region to represent his remorse and eternal damna-
tion manifested into evil.

C43 . EMPTY STOREROOM
As the PCs approach this door, allow them each a DC 
19 Wisdom (Perception) check to hear moaning from 
inside the room.
Most of the stone floor of this room is hidden 
under thick wooden crates. Though these crates 
are sturdy, and their wood is mostly undamaged, 
many of them are opened and empty. The walls 
are blackened by age and magic. In the darkness 
of a nearby comer, the spiny silhouette of a beast 
hunkers down behind a crate.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: Like many rooms in this section, this 
area was once claimed as part of the Gnashing 
Fang Tribe‚Äôs territory. Over the last decade, the tribe 
gradually relinquished control of this section, which 
was once used to store goods. Now millipedes 
and other bugs hunt through the cracks of the 
stonework.
However, before the gnolls left, they mercilessly 
chained a howler to the wall, leaving it for dead. It 
has refused to go quietly and moans pitifully. How-
ever, the room‚Äôs magical nature absorbs a great 
deal of the sound and muffles it into white noise.
The room absorbs light and sound and reduces 
their effective range to half.
Encounter Condition: Cover, Echoes 5, Fearless
Tactics: Allow the howler a Wisdom (Perception) 
check to notice the PCs enter the room. If suc-
cessful, it barks loudly, targeting everyone with its 
Mind-Breaking Howl. The howler cannot move, but 
pitifully yanks at its own chain in an attempt to free 
itself. It has no choice, but to fight to the death.
If the PCs try to befriend the creature rather than 
kill it, allow Wisdom (Animal Handling), but since 
the beast is unnatural they suffer Disadvantage.
Treasure: Though most of the crates are empty, 
some contain gear that could be helpful. The PCs 
find three tinder-twigs, a flask of antitoxin, seven 
empty glass vials, a large clay jug, a bullseye lantern, 
three pints of oil, two rusty miner‚Äôs picks, 200 ft. of 
hempen rope, and a heavy sledge.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this trap, add 
two vargouille which torment the howler, but turn 
their attention to the PCs when they enter. To 
reduce the challenge, have the howler asleep when 
they arrive.
C44 . MODIFIED CHAMBER
This oddly shaped chamber is vacant. The walls 
here are smooth and undamaged. A closer look at 
the floor reveals that its surface is spotless, save for 
a narrow space, some 10-ft. square, linking the only 
door with the southern wall. The skeletal remains 
of two goblins and one gnoll rest in one corner.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room was once a tiny cell, but the 
wizard Arum changed the layout with powerful 
magic after settling in. Though no one knows what 
he intended, those with expertise with stone or ma-
sonry, as well as those accustomed to the geogra-
phy of the dungeon, can tell that something is not 
quite right with the walls of this room.
Aside from the 10-ft.-wide portion of the south 
wall directly in front of the doorway and a narrow 
frame surrounding the door on the north wall, the 
walls of this room have a different texture than the 
other walls in the dungeon. Though most of the 
walls in this region have the same stone surface, 
these are smoother, paler, and (most importantly) 
show no sign of wear. A successful DC 16 Intelli-
gence check confirms that the stone used here is 
not only different, but also that it is strange to find 
it in the dungeon. A successful DC 22 Intelligence 
(Arcana) check reveals the entire room was shaped 
with magic.
Encounter Condition: Echoes 1, Hallowed 1, [Positive 
Energy], Safe
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: Buried within the walls are several wands of 
sleep, that Arum built into this chamber. The wands 
were corrupted by the chaotic magic of the region, 
and constantly target the occupants with a desire 
for restful sleep. The walls radiate strong Abjuration 
and Enchantment.
PCs spending more than 5 hours in this room, 
feel a calming peace come over them. The energy 
is soothing and beckons the PCs to stay a while. 
After 5 hours, however, they lose the will to leave. 
PCs trying to leave, must succeed at DC 16 Wisdom 
saves, or rest in a quiet corner for another 8 hours. 
This is a very good rest for the PC but it is hard to 
resist. While they heal at twice the normal rate in 
this room, a DC 16 Wisdom save is required every 
morning to summon the will to leave.

237
237
The key to escaping this perpetual trap is for 
PCs that can leave, to either carry out the ones 
who won‚Äôt leave or sleep in another room, until the 
‚Äútrapped‚Äù PCs gain the will to escape. PCs sleeping 
in the hall (waiting for their comrades) are subject 
to random encounters (once every two hours), while 
the occupants of the room are not.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
have the slumber take effect in 2 hours rather than 
5 hours. To decrease the challenge, the PCs only 
need to sleep one day here and can leave freely 
the next day.
C45 . FALSE TREASURE ROOM
The floor of this small room is littered with gold 
pieces, though these fail to hide the dusty floor 
beneath. In the center of the chamber is a simple 
stone altar upon which a long double-edged sword 
lies. The sword is fashioned from a silver alloy that 
shines brilliantly when light is cast upon it.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room was converted into a false 
treasure chamber by the wizard Arum. A successful 
DC 17 Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Tools) check is required to 
unlock the only door leading into this room, and 
the key that once served that purpose was de-
stroyed long ago.
Anyone touching the sword or the altar triggers 
the trap, which was created by Arum years ago.
 '
Magic Missile Trap. Detect: DC 15 Intelligence 
(Arcana); Disable: DC 15 Intelligence (Arcana); 
Characters in a 120-ft. range suffer 4d4+1 force 
damage each.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: The longsword is endowed with a perma-
nent magic aura, making it appear as a +3 vorpal 
longsword. In truth, it‚Äôs a -2 cursed longsword. The 
gold scattered upon the floor is real and to-
tals 327 gp.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase the damage by 2d4. To decrease the chal-
lenge, the trap triggers only once.
C46 . TRAPPED DOORWAYS
The corridor leading south ends in a strange 
intersection. Upon the eastern wall is a wide 
doorway opening into a dark room. To the west and 
south, short hallways lead to closed doors, each 
with a locking mechanism set above their knob.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: The two doors on the southern end of 
this corridor are traps. The first of these doors is 
real, but the second is fake. It is stuck inside the 
stone wall and cannot be opened by any means. 
Both doors have a complex locking mechanism set 
upon them. A successful DC 18 Dexterity check is 
required to unlock either of them.
The first door is rigged with a crushing despair trap, 
which is triggered as soon as any creature passes 
through the doorway.
 '
Crushing Despair Trap. Detect: DC 14 Intelligence 
(Arcana); Disable: DC 14 Intelligence (Arcana); Char-
acters in a 20-ft. square area must make a DC 15 
Charisma save or suffer from bane for 1 hour.
The second door, which is impossible to open ‚Äì 
though its lock can be picked normally ‚Äì is trapped 
as well and triggers when anyone touches it.
 '
Acid Fog Trap. Detect: DC 14 Intelligence (Arcana); 
Disable: DC 14 Intelligence (Arcana); Characters in a 
20-ft. square area must make a DC 15 Dexterity save 
for half damage or suffer 3d6 acid damage.
Though no creatures live in this room, the vargouilles 
in Room C47 are alerted when the trap is sprung.
Encounter Condition: Stagnant Air, [Smoke]
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encoun-
ter, add cloudkill to the crushing despair trap and 
have the vargouilles (room C47) ambush the PCs 
as they exit. To decrease the challenge, remove the

238
238
C47 . ROGUE VARGOUILLES
Both doorways leading into this chamber are wide 
open. Though these once held doors, they were taken 
out long ago. A closer inspection of these archways 
reveals the rusted remains of strong iron hinges.
If the PCs fought the chained howler (Room C43), 
the vargouilles cannot be surprised.
Beyond the empty archway is a large chamber. 
The room is dark and an undisturbed blanket of 
dust covers the floor. The stone floor is scuffed and 
marked under the dust, suggesting that traffic was 
once common here.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: Four vargouilles hide in this chamber. 
These creatures recently ventured into the wiz-
ard‚Äôs domain and decided to turn this room into 
their new home. They are content to remain in the 
darkness, but attack anyone entering what they now 
consider their lair.
If the PCs use a light source, the vargouilles 
automatically notice them. Otherwise, allow the 
vargouilles the appropriate Wisdom (Perception) 
checks. They remain hidden, waiting for the PCs to 
enter. If it takes more than 10 rounds for the PCs to 
reach their lair after they were spotted, the var-
gouilles come after them instead.
Encounter Condition: Ambush (darkness), Conceal-
ment, Fear 14, Fearless, Unhallowed
Tactics: The vargouilles use shriek as soon as they 
reveal themselves (or the moment they are spotted). 
They close in melee, biting their foes. Though they 
do not necessarily fight in unison, these creatures 
are savage and fight to the death. They target the 
weakest opponents first, and do not hesitate to 
attack the wounded.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase the vargouilles‚Äô hit points by 6.
C48 . FORMER GREAT HALL
Torches set amidst heavy bronze sconces are 
ablaze, their light revealing a massive stone table 
that dominates the center of this large hall. Broken 
wooden stools and a rotten tapestry (now piled 
in the corner of the room) complete the collection 
of furniture, which is covered with dust. Three 
corridors lead into this place, but the one opening 
in the middle of the eastern wall is blocked.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: The Gnashing Fang Tribe previously used 
this room as a meeting hall. Though they have long 
abandoned the place, it remains unchanged.
This great hall is empty and has not seen use 
in years. Only the vargouilles in Room C47 have 
passed through it in recent months. The stone table 
in the center of the place is solid and its surface is 
scarred with various claw marks. These were de-
signed by the gnolls that once lived here, but mean

The corridor leading east ends abruptly. When 
Arum defeated the hill giant in Room C97, he creat-
ed a permanent stone wall here to block the access. 
A successful DC 16 Intelligence (Arcana) check 
made here reveals that this portion of the wall is 
indeed a wall of stone. It is next to impossible to

There is a barely noticeable irregularity in the 
center of the western wall. PCs succeeding at a 
DC 22 Wisdom (Perception) check notices narrow 
grooves upon the stone surface, suggesting that 
a portion of the wall is actually a hidden panel. A 
close examination of this panel reveals a tiny hole 
in its center. The device is clearly some sort of 
keyhole, but its key is yet undiscovered (by the PCs). 
A successful DC 17 Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Tools) check 
is enough to unlock the mechanism. Upon success, 
the panel sinks into the floor, revealing Room C51 
beyond. The secret door closes itself one minute 
after it is opened.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: PCs observing the degraded tapestry dis-
cern faded colors, but no particular image comes to 
mind based on the design. The item is worthless. 
The torches have continual flame cast on them.
Scaling: N/A

239
239
C49 . FORMER BARRACKS
Both doors to this room are locked and require a 
successful DC 24 Dexterity check to open.
Eerie lights and dancing shadows project upon the 
walls, distracting you. The room beyond the door 
is in disarray, as if ransacked. Splintered wooden 
bunk-bed frames line the southern and eastern 
walls. Though no mattresses or bed sheets cover 
them now, they could once sleep twelve, and if 
suitable bedding could be acquired, they could 
still be used.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: This room once housed warriors of the 
Gnashing Fang Tribe. Over the years, the tribe 
suffered great losses and eventually abandoned the 
place. Before fleeing, they used this place to trap a 
feral ghoul they were unable to kill. The beast has 
been captive for many months and seeks to destroy 
anyone who enters (including the PCs).
Encounter Condition: Ambush, Fearless, [Safe]
Tactics: The ghoul is fearless and stronger than most 
of its kind. It waits above the door and descends 
on the last person to enter. The PCs need a DC 25 
Wisdom (Perception) check to notice it as they enter 
and gain Advantage only if they are looking straight 
up as they enter (the monster knows exactly where 
to hide in the room‚Äôs shadow).
During the first round, the ghoul takes full 
advantage of its abilities, attacking its victim with 
two claws, one bite, and its special rake attack. The 
ghoul‚Äôs claws are razor-sharp from many years 
of scratching and sharpening upon the dungeon 
walls, and its critical threat range is increased 
accordingly.
Treasure: A torch imbued with continual flame was left 
behind, perhaps to torment the nocturnal ghoul. 
The torch was broken into many pieces, but the con-
tinual flame still casts light from a single 3-in. piece 
of wood. A successful DC 16 Wisdom (Perception) 
check discovers a gold earring (worth 25 gp) tucked 
between one of the bunks and the wall.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
allow the ghoul to sneak attack the first PC for +3d6 
damage. In addition, at the end of the first round, 
have the PCs make a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw 
or be Frightened. To decrease the challenge, have 
the ghoul be surprised by the PCs.
C50 . THE TOMB OF NARR'KRR
Both doors leading into this chamber were sealed 
with thick wax, applied to the inside of the door

17 Strength check is required to open each door.
The doors opening into this chamber are extremely 
hard to push open, but once done, a stench 
emanates from within. Inside this large room is a 
simple wooden desk, a large stool, an iron chest, 
and a wide bed. Upon the bed is the source of the 
powerful smell: a tall humanoid skeleton with bits 
of rotted flesh sticking to the yellowed bones. The 
corpse is dressed in rotten clothing, but a large gold 
torc hangs from a chain upon its neck.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Narr‚Äôkrr, a powerful gnoll warrior, used 
this chamber as his private abode and office. 
Narr‚Äôkrr suffered a crippling injury six years ago 
and, shortly after his death, was laid to rest in this 
chamber, and both doors were sealed.
With a successful DC 13 Wisdom (Medicine) 
check or DC 11 Intelligence (Nature) check, PCs ob-
serving the corpse can determine this creature was 
a particularly large gnoll.
Encounter Condition: N/A

240
240
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: Upon the desk are a handful of blank scroll 
pages, which are dried and yellowed but still usable, 
and an empty vial of ink. The chest here contains 
rotted clothing and a +1 hand axe. Lastly, Narr‚Äôkrr 
spent his last few months studying some arcane 
notes and while he never understood them, he hid 
them away in a cache under the table. A successful 
DC 22 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals a small

PCs searching the body automatically find a gold 
torc set upon a heavy chain. The chain is made of

ple tribal designs. It is worth 250 gp in civilization, 
but at least twice as much to a gnoll. Members of 
the Howling Fang Tribe (that never ventured into 
the dungeon), and most Gnashing Fang gnolls 
would pay up to 1,000 gp for such a treasure, as it 
is an heirloom of their people.
If the PCs attempt a trade with Gahrr‚Äôk (Room 
C37), a DC 30 Charisma (Persuasion) check is nec-
essary to get both stone salves for the heirloom. He 
easily trades one for it.
Scaling: N/A
C51 . WIZARD'S LABORATORY
To enter this room, the PCs must find the secret pan-
el in Room C48. This panel resets itself one minute 
after being opened. PCs caught on this side instantly 
notice the irregularity in the center of the eastern 
wall, provided they know where to look. From this

as well as the tiny keyhole in the middle of the panel. 
A successful DC 20 Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô Tools) check is 
still required to unlock the mechanism, but the prop-
er key rests on the table in this chamber.
A low table lies in the middle of this chamber, 
which is illuminated by the flames of four torches,

Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Shortly after the escape of the demon in 
room C21 and the terrible deaths of the knights of 
Merunda, Arum discovered this hidden chamber 
and built another laboratory here. Judging by the 
dust covering everything in this room, it‚Äôs clear it 
hasn‚Äôt been used in some time.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: The narrow rod upon the table is the key 
that unlocks the secret panel leading into this

Scaling: N/A
C52 . WIZARD'S STUDY
Like the laboratory, the burning flames of torches 
set into each corner illuminate this room. A 
comfortable-looking chair rests at the foot of the 
southern wall, facing the chamber‚Äôs only door. 
Beside the chair is a small wooden table, on which

Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Arum used this chamber to meditate and

entered this place in years.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: The most significant treasure in this

conic (the first half ) and scrawled in Common (the

While trying to gain insight into his future, 
Arum was contacted by a divine entity known as

el, and vigilance. The deity told him to come to

241
241
Shortly after Arum arrived, he performed exper-
iments to discover why extraplanar travel was 
impossible here. After successfully opening a tiny

ly), forbidding him from ever attempting such an

After several blank pages, the writing contin-
ues, only the handwriting is more chaotic and the

Arum (now referring to himself in the third per-
son) communicated with what he believed was an 
angel trapped within the dungeon to learn how to 
make his forge more efficient. Following the angel‚Äôs 
advice, the wizard placed powerful wards to reflect 
the heat generated by his forge back to it. What 
the wizard had not realized, however, was that the 
wards he placed upon the wall would facilitate Ash‚Äòs 
freedom. It was indeed the cunning demon that 
had communicated with him, not an angel. The de-
tails of the account are vague, but the text is filled 
with remorse. The author blames himself for Ash‚Äòs 
escape, which ultimately led to the Paladins‚Äô fall.
The two vials contain dried and unusable ink, 
but the ink pen is still in good shape. The four 
torches have continual flame cast on them.
Scaling: N/A
C53 . ARUM'S PRIVATE SANCTUM
A wide bed covered with dusty blankets lies at 
the foot of the southern wall of this chamber. 
Beside the bed is a wooden table with a lantern

Initial Attitude: N/A

room. When the wizard left the dungeon, he

The doorway leading to Arum‚Äôs chamber is rigged

remember doing). Anyone entering the room

 '
Bestow Curse Trap. Detect: DC 19 Intelligence (Ar-
cana); Disable: DC 19 Intelligence (Arcana); Charac-
ters entering the room must make a DC 13 Wisdom

Encounter Condition: Cursed 5, Haunted
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: The chest at the foot of the bed is locked

Half a dozen gnoll carcasses lie in the middle

Treasure: PCs searching the corpses find three rusty

242
large steel shields. One of these shields is a mas-
terwork item. The gnolls also carry a total of 21 gp

C55 . RIGGED FALSE DOOR
Four doors open into this dark intersection. Though

Encounter: The door at the end of the western cor-

 '
Cloudkill Trap. Detect: DC 21 Intelligence (Arcana);

Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter,

C56 . FLOODING ROOM
The floor of this intersecting corridor is surprisingly

Encounter: This intersection is rigged with a potent

Treasure: N/A

C57. Hazardous Tunnel

243

244
C60-C68 . PATH OF THE RIGHTEOUS .
This section was originally designed as a deadly path 
preventing demonic and devilish creatures from 
venturing too far. The angel and archon wardens of 
the region could safely walk from Rooms C60 though 
Room C68 and even used some of these chambers 
to rest. However, non-lawful good creatures found it 
more difficult to make the journey.
When Arum discovered this area, he essentially kept 
it as it was. However, he used Room C64 to honor 
the brave men and women who sacrificed their lives 
in the service of their god and who died fighting the 
powerful demon of the dungeon. Arum‚Äôs testimony 
of the paladin‚Äôs battle is engraved upon the walls of 
this chamber in a maddeningly random combination 
of Common, Draconic, and Abyssal.
PCs will notice that the stone surfaces of the walls,

dition, the material from which they had been hewn 
is different than in other parts of the vast complex 
and no dust has accumulated anywhere. Lastly, the

minated by an unknown light source, as if under the

C60 . SECRET ENTRANCE
The door leading to Room C61 is actually a secret 
stone panel that is very difficult to notice (DC 30 Wis-
dom (Perception) check). The secret panel upon the 
eastern wall is a 10-ft.-by-10-ft. section of stone that 
sinks into the floor when opened. The secret door 
opens instantly if a PC with the Mark of the Righ-
teous (see Room C21 and C103) walks within 5 ft. of 
it, revealing bright light on the other side. The panel 
remains open for 1 minute before rising back into 
place. A PC with the Mark of the Righteous caught on 
the other side of this doorway needs only to touch the 
secret wall panel to open it.
The corridor widens here but leads to a bare wall. 
There is no dust here, but the place is undisturbed, 
suggesting that no one has ventured into this 
hallway for years.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: If no one has the Mark of the Righteous, 
the PCs cannot gain access to this chamber, and 
thus they cannot reach the eastern rooms of this 
region. Most importantly, the special key in Room 
C103 is unavailable to them. If the PCs never met

the Righteous, Zrino arrives, offering the Mark. If

Encounter Condition: Hallowed 4
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A

C61 . GOLDEN WEAPON RACK
The western wall of this chamber contains an 
empty weapon rack. The structure of this fixture 
is composed of four long bars that curve slightly. 
Each of these bars are made of pure gold, 
decorated with a feather pattern. The golden 
feathers are linked to one another and form an 
intricate design. Upon the northern door, written 
in golden Celestial runes are the words: ‚ÄúLeave all 
weapons behind.‚Äù
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room was designed so that anyone 
entering Room C62 would do so unharmed. The 
weapon rack is enchanted and all those leaving 
their arms behind find the journey through Rooms 
C67 and beyond more pleasant than it has been. 
The rack is also the key to unlock the door leading 
to Room C62. Once a weapon is placed, it cannot 
be removed from the rack, but an exact duplicate 
awaits in Room C67. If the PC returns to this room, 

245
245
the weapon is gone (unless the weapon was placed 
again in Room C67).
A PC with the Mark of the Righteous (see Room

Only those with the Mark of the Righteous can 
open it in this fashion, however. When opened, the

The secret panel upon the eastern wall of this 
chamber is 5-ft.-by-5-ft. It is made from the same

sunk inside the floor for 1 full minute before rising

teous cannot open this door.
The door upon the north wall is locked. There 
are no obvious locking mechanisms, and it cannot 
be unlocked with normal means. The only way to 
unlock this door, and gain access to Room C62, is

western wall. A minimum of 1 weapon per PC must

ons disappear and the door opens by itself, allowing 
the PCs access to Room C62.

Tactics: N/A

ful DC 25 Strength check. Doing so not only cancels

Scaling: N/A
C62 . ANTECHAMBER OF LAW
This square room is empty, but upon the perfectly 
smooth white stone floor is an intricate carving of 
an angel with outspread wings. The angelic figure 
sculpted into the floor holds a wide shield with a 
scale and sword design in its center.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: A successful DC 13 Intelligence (Religion) 
or DC 18 Intelligence (Arcana) check reveals that the 
symbol on the shield represents Order. This sym-
bol is used by angels and archons, as well as many 
religious orders that uphold the law.
This room contains a powerful device that affects 
all non-lawful beings. Any non-lawful creatures en-
tering this room must make a DC 23 Wisdom save 
or be poisoned for 4d6 minutes. Lawful-aligned 
characters are not affected by this and unarmed 
non-lawful characters who placed all their weapons 
in the rack in Room C61 or Room C67 gain advan-
tage on their save.
Encounter Condition: Hallowed 6, Positive 
Energy, Safe
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter,

C63 . THE HALL OF LAW
Silken sheets are piled up all along the floor of 
this large hall. There are eight silk blankets on 
either side of the room, placed near the eastern 
and western wall. Though there are no beds under 
them, the blankets look rather inviting. Their deep 
blue shades dramatically contrast the clean white 
walls of the Hall.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room was a meditation hall. The 
silken sheets are surprisingly comfortable and lying 
on them feels like lying on a soft feathery mattress. 
Anyone stealing a blanket receives a deadly elec-
trical blast upon exiting through either door. The 
discharge deals 12d6 points of lightning damage, 
but a DC 22 Constitution save reduces it by half.

246
246
Lawful PCs resting here will rejuvenate lost hit 
points at a rate of 5 per hour. In addition, resting

ability score damage they suffered. Upon awaken-
ing, they are under the effects of bless for 24 hours. 
Non-lawful PCs do not benefit from these effects.
Chaotic PCs find no respite here. No matter 
how long they sleep, they gain none of the bene-
fits normally bestowed by rest. Furthermore, upon 
entering this room, chaotic-aligned PCs must make

of exhaustion. Chaotic PCs who left all their weap-
ons in the rack in Room C61 or C67 gain advantage 
on the save.

ergy], Safe
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A

ter, have all chaotic creatures entering this room

C64 . AN ACCOUNT OF THE LAST BATTLE
Gouges scar the pure white walls of this hall. The 
markings are letters of exquisite quality carved 
into the stone. The writing is in Celestial, but 
under each phrase are Common runes translating 
the language.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Arum used this room to record the 
account of the brave, final stand of the Paladins of 
Merunda. The account was made by Arum, who 
used both languages to make sure any good soul 
traveling into this chamber would know the truth. 
PCs succeeding at a DC 22 Wisdom (Insight) check, 
can sense sadness in the words and the style of 
writing, as if the writer had given up hope.
PCs reading the inscriptions on the walls learn 
that Merunda (a minor goddess of the ocean, trav-
el, and vigilance) summoned the last of her follow-
ers to this dungeon. At first they did not know why 
the deity had called them to the forgotten place, 
but the servants of the goddess eventually learned 
they were expected to fight the great demon held 
within the confines of a special prison cell. They 
were also expected to die in their efforts. That is, all 
except Arum, whose signature can be found at the 
end of the account.
Moments before the tragic event, the paladins 
of Merunda were told the demon would escape 
its prison and that a mighty angel would slay the 
fiend, provided they sacrificed their lives to help 
it. When the time came, and the demon broke 
through the wall of its prison cell, the servants of 
Merunda stood ready to face the creature. They 
sacrificed their lives to allow the angel to kill the 
demon. Only Arum survived the onslaught, and the 
wizard saw the angel dissolve into thin air once the 
demon was dead.
Though the narrator does not explain the events 
leading to the demon‚Äôs escape, he does insist that 
without the efforts of the followers of Merunda, this 
evil would not have been destroyed. And he notes 
that he wrote the account upon the walls to honor 
the memory, valor, and sacrifice of the deceased.
Encounter Condition: Hallowed 12, Positive 
Energy, Safe
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: N/A
C65 . THE HALL OF GOODNESS
Large sofas of deep blue velvet dominate the 
eastern and western walls of this large hall. In the 
center is a low blue marble table. The furniture is 
elegant and, like the white stone surfaces of the 
hall, surprisingly clean.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Good-aligned PCs entering this hall 
immediately feel relaxed. Those suffering from ail-
ments such as poison, disease, or a curse also feel 
that they could get better if they stay here a while 
longer. Every hour a good-aligned PC remains, they 
are cured of one of the following effects: poison, 
disease, blindness, deafness, curse, or paralysis. 
Non-good PCs do not gain any of these benefits.
For evil characters: this place is beyond unnerv-
ing, if not hostile. Upon entering the hall, they 

247
247
must succeed at a DC 30 Wisdom save or become 
blind and deaf. They also reduce their maximum 
HP by 4d8 for as long as they remain here. Remov-
ing blindness/deafness restores their sight and

on the save.
Encounter Condition: Hallowed 8, Positive 
Energy, Safe
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add a bestow curse effect to each evil PC traveling 
in this hall. To decrease the challenge, have evil 
PCs either blind or deaf, not both, and reduce the

C66 . ANTECHAMBER OF GOODNESS
An intricate pattern is carved into the center of 
this room. The design represents a handsome male 
angel with powerful wings protruding from its 
back. The angel upon the floor has one hand above

Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: A successful DC 12 Intelligence (Religion)

depict their greatest heroes in this position.
This room is imbued with strong magic that 
affects all non-good creatures. Non-good PCs en-
tering this room must make a DC 22 Wisdom save 
or become frightened for 4d6 minutes and have 
their maximum hit points reduced by 3d6 until the

not affected and non-good characters who placed

Encounter Condition: [Fear 22], Hallowed 6, Positive 
Energy, Safe
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A

C67 . SILVERY WEAPON RACK
The southern door is locked, but has no locking 
mechanism upon it. It cannot be unlocked through 
normal means and the only way to open it is by plac-

An empty silver weapon rack is placed upon the

‚ÄúLeave all weapons behind‚Äù are written in silver 
Celestial runes in the center of the southern door.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Like Room C61, this chamber was de-
signed to allow everyone entering Rooms C62-C66

tions as the one in Room C61. It is also the key to

PCs who left their weapons behind in Room 
C61, and vice versa, find their weapons here. When

The magical rack does not enhance the weapons 
of non-lawful or non-good PCs. The weapons of

Encounter Condition: Hallowed 4
Tactics: N/A

248

The secret stone panel sinks into the floor, revealing

ically learn of its existence. The secret door is a 5-ft.-

If no one has the Mark of the Righteous, the PCs

teous, Zrino appears her now to offer the Mark,

C69-C79 . BLACK DRAGON TERRITORY .
Before Arum fled the dungeon, his scattered mind 
created several monstrosities in this section, bring-
ing to life inanimate objects (like the furniture) and 
turning mindless mold into powerful, destructive 
oozes. Months and years passed as Arum hid under 
the shadow of the dragon, before fleeing the region 
in search of clarity and to ease his worried mind.
Over the years this section became home to a 
number of creatures, including hill giants (too stupid 
to stay away), and a number of gnoll patrols who 
eventually learned to leave well enough alone. Now, 
uncontested, a mighty black dragon named Nardarik 
controls Rooms C69-C79. This cunning dragon is 
aware of every secret door and hidden passage in his 
territory. Nardarik is smart and agile, and frequently 
patrols his lair to ensure no other inhabitants enter 
it. While journeying through Nardarik‚Äòs territory, the 
PCs notice several scuff marks upon the floor and 
walls. Nardarik‚Äôs claws and scaly body created these 
marks. They are especially obvious in narrow corridors 
and chambers.
When Nardarik encounters the PCs, he is hostile. 
Unless they offer great treasures, the dragon attacks. 
He wants nothing to do with the PCs. However, if 
they buy their way out, Nardarik will honor the bar-
gain and show them to the exit.

C69 . FIRST MARKED ROOM
The surface of the stone floor and walls here is 
heavily pitted and scarred. A closer examination 
suggests that part of the rock face was burned. 
There are also several marks upon the floor, 
suggesting frequent traffic.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: The walls and floor of this room are dam-
aged. Their stone surfaces are melted and uneven, 
as though a potent acid had eaten through the rock. 
Nardarik (Room C77), the black dragon that makes 
his lair in this area, is responsible for the markings.
There is nothing special in this room aside from 
the acid-damaged floor and walls. A successful 
DC 12 Intelligence check made here confirms the 
walls and floor were damaged with a strong acid. 

250
250
Another check (DC 15) suggests the acid was thrown 
or projected against the stone surfaces, as though 
through a jet or thrown flask. A third check (DC 
18) reveals the acid‚Äôs source was monstrous and 
unnatural.
A successful DC 20 Wisdom (Perception) check 
uncovers a simple secret panel at the end of the 
western corridor. This panel is made from the same 
stone as the walls and is just as damaged. It tilts 
precariously upon hidden hinges towards the inside 
of this room when opened. A narrow groove into 
the stone surface allows PCs to pull it open, but a 
successful DC 15 Strength check is required.
Encounter Condition: [Fog 10 or Smoke]
Tactics: After the PCs spend 30 minutes in this room, 
roll for a random encounter.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: N/A
C70 . DEVASTATED CHAMBER
The three secret doors leading into this room are 
simple stone panels that can be noticed with DC 20 
Wisdom (Perception) checks. When pushed with a 
successful DC 15 Strength check, they swing open, 
revealing strong iron hinges hidden within the 
archway. PCs opening the panels from the outside 
must use a narrow groove that grips the panel (also 
requiring a Strength check).
The two secret doors in the corridor to the north-
west are identical to those from this room.
This room is filled with broken furniture, crushed 
boulders, and bone fragments. The debris is piled 
at the foot of the western wall, and a simple 
looking door separates them in two mounds. 
Within the debris are bits of rusty iron, thorns, and 
rotted clothing.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: When Nardarik took control of the sec-
tion, he fought powerful hill giant stragglers. The 
dragon wasted no time hunting down his enemies, 
and the giants made a brave, but futile last stand. 
Casting the room in darkness, Nardarik killed each 
giant, slowly, in turn. Now, only their bony car-
casses remain, along with the devastation wrought 
by Nardarik.
Searching the debris thoroughly takes 2 hours, 
but PCs succeeding at a DC 18 Wisdom (Perception) 
check can determine that the bone fragments from 
the detritus resulted from the decay of a number of 
giant-sized creatures. Portions of these bones are 
pitted, twisted, or melted, as though acid had been 
thrown upon them. PCs studying the bones must 
succeed at a DC 16 Intelligence (Nature) check to 
ascertain they come from seven different hill giants.
A DC 21 Wisdom (Perception) check made 
here also reveals that behind the debris, portions 
of the western wall are scarred and damaged, as 
though by acid.
Encounter Condition: [Deep Darkness], 
Echoes 4, Fog
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: There is nothing of value in this hall, as 
Nardarik stripped the giants of any treasure they 
carried, including their weapons. PCs taking at 
least 20 minutes to search this room uncover large 
pieces of wood, broken iron nails, the dried remains 
of pine branches, and large-but-rotted animal pelts. 
These broken and useless materials framed at least 
ten very wide bunk beds.
Scaling: N/A
C71 . SECOND MARKED ROOM
The westernmost secret door is discovered with a suc-
cessful DC 20 Wisdom (Perception) check. The panel 
is simple and made from the same damaged stone as 
the walls. A narrow groove allows the PCs to grip the 
panel and pull it open. This action requires a DC 15 
Strength check.
The floor and walls of this chamber are heavily 
damaged. The stone surfaces are uneven and 
marked with unfamiliar patterns.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Like Room C69, a strong acid heavily 
damaged the walls and floor of this chamber. These 
cryptic marks are a warning to trespassers. A suc-
cessful DC 12 Intelligence check confirms the sub-
stance used to burn and melt the stone was acid.
Encounter Condition: Fog 10, Stagnant Air
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: N/A

C72 . HALL OF RUBBLE
A massive pile of stone rubble dominates this great 
hall. Boulders and chunks of broken rocks, all 
neatly put together in the center of the area, form a 
mound almost as tall as the 50-ft high ceiling.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Though the PCs can step into this room,

the stone rubble scattered everywhere. PCs staying 
close to the walls can make their way around the 
hall, circling the mound, the summit of which is

Encounter Condition: [Fog 10], Hazardous Footing 
16, Tremors 19
Tactics: N/A

After 3 hours, allow the PCs a DC 21 Wisdom (Per-

C73 . TRAPPED HALLWAY
The secret door on the northern end of the corridor 
is easy to spot. The grooves surrounding the stone 
panel are larger than most and there are obvious

The westernmost part of the south wall of this

way. This lock can be picked with a DC 21 Dexterity

When triggered, the trap remains active for 7

ing. Creatures take 6d6 falling damage when they

Reverse Gravity Trap. DC 20 Intelligence (Arcana)

It attacks the PCs when someone steps within 5

C75 . FALSE DRAGON'S HOARD
This cross-shaped hall is filled with coins of all

253
grown to enormous strength. It guards the hall-
way running around the Nardarik‚Äôs nests (Room

mimic‚Äôs acid immunity renders it invulnerable to 
the cube‚Äôs touch.
These creatures were already here when Nardar-
ik took control of the section and, seeing no need 
to destroy them, the dragon kept them alive for use 
as sentries. The gelatinous cube and mimic remain 
close to the door in the northern stretch of the 
corridor, but can appear anywhere in the room the 
GM wishes.
Encounter Condition: Ambush, [Fear 14], Fearless
Tactics: Should the cube suffer 50 or more points 
of damage, the mimic springs to life and attacks 
the PCs, surprising them (even if they are already 
engaged in combat) unless they succeed at a DC 25 
Wisdom (Perception) check.
The cube attacks mindlessly, engulfing the first 
PC it can. If the cube is successful, the mimic at-
tacks the PC from inside the cube, rather than wait-
ing for an opening. PCs witnessing such an attack 
must succeed at a DC 12 Wisdom save or become 
stunned for 2d4 rounds.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
have there be two mimics inside the cube, each 
shaped like treasure chests or desks. To decrease 
the challenge, have the mimic surprise the PCs only 
after the cube suffers 60 points of damage.
C77. Nardarik's Nest
If Nardarik hears the PCs coming (highly likely), the 
room is already cast in darkness. Otherwise, read the 
following.
A great mound of copper, silver, and gold coins take 
up most of the floor space of this vast chamber. 
Among the coins are multiple pieces of jewelry, 
such as necklaces, rings, and bracelets, as well as 
a handful of tapestries, goblets, and utensils. What 
truly catches the eye, however, is the large dragon 
sitting atop his treasure. The creature‚Äôs scales 
are deep black, bearing several scars, and shaped 
like jagged diamonds. Fire burns within the pits 
of its eyes.
Initial Attitude: Hostile
Encounter: Nardarik lives here. Though he frequently 
patrols his own territory, he is found here most of 
the time. Like most of his peers, Nardarik is clever, 
cruel, and malevolent. He sees the PCs‚Äô presence 
in his private realm as an affront to his power and 
does not hesitate to attack anyone entering its nest.
In order to negotiate with Nardarik, the PCs 
must first be able to change his initial attitude 
through the use of Charisma (Persuasion) or Cha-
risma (Deception) checks. Unless the PCs tempt 
Nardarik by promising great riches to the black 
dragon, they suffer from a -4 penalty to all Charis-
ma (Persuasion) checks made to change its attitude. 
If the PCs successfully change the dragon‚Äôs mind, it 
listens to what they have to offer hoping to acquire 
treasure from them. If the PCs fail to pay at least 
2,000 gp worth of treasure to Nardarik, com-
bat ensues.
Encounter Condition: Ambush (darkness), [Deep 
Darkness], Fearless, Fog 10, Smoke
Tactics: In battle, Nardarik is merciless. If he hasn‚Äôt 
already done so, he casts the room into darkness, 
unless the PCs surprise him, in which case he starts 
fighting immediately. Before engaging in melee, 
he uses his line of acid breath (60 ft.), targeting 
spellcasters. Due to his ferocious nature, he does 
not breathe acid as often as he can, repeating this 
action every 1d4+1 rounds.
Once engaged in melee, Nardarik tears into the 
PCs with claw and bite attacks. If too many PCs 
surround him, he tail slaps the largest, reducing his 
opponent‚Äôs numbers before returning to his breath 
weapon and claw attacks.
Due to the size of the room, Nardarik keeps his 
distance when necessary and jumps about for a 
better position whenever possible. In the darkness, 
he attacks like a cat, attacking powerful PCs before 
slinking away to stalk them again.
If the PCs are too strong for Nardarik, he uses 
darkness and his powerful breath weapon to escape 
to Room C72.
Treasure: Nardarik‚Äòs treasure hoard includes 8,500 gp 
worth of small gemstones, assorted coins, and var-
ious pieces of jewelry. In a locked (DC 22 Dexterity 
(Thieves‚Äô Tools) check) wooden chest are a number 

254
254
of unmarked vials. A potion of bless and three po-
tions of healing can be found.
In another locked (DC 22 Dexterity (Thieves‚Äô 
Tools) check) chest, strapped closed with bands of 
cold iron, the PCs find one large delicate jade Bowl 
of Commanding Water Elementals, a small lacquer 
box (wrapped in silk) containing brushes and Mar-
velous Pigments, a dark blue Ioun stone, a clear Ioun 
stone, a plain-looking ring of evasion, a ring of three 
wishes (with 0 wishes remaining), a ring of resistance 
( fire) (with a faceted fire opal set in a three-part 
crown), and an amulet of health that only fits small 
or smaller creatures.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
give Nardarik an additional Legendary Action. To 
decrease the challenge, allow the PCs two rounds 
before Nardarik notices them.
C78 . CONVERTED HALL
This oddly shaped hall was probably two rooms 
once, but there are now wide gaps in the east and 
south walls, which open into the second part of it. 
Though there is nothing special here, the walls and 
floor bear many scars. The horizontal scarring of 
the walls suggests that something was dragged up 
them, and it is obvious that the floor was scarred 
with claws or sharp tools.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This hall was once two separate cham-
bers, but the doors, and indeed the entire doorways 
that separated them were destroyed long ago. The 
oversized archways are scorched and a good portion 
of the stone walls surrounding them has melted 
under the effect of an acidic substance.
The secret door in the southernmost portion of 
the east wall is a simple stone panel that has seen 
much use in recent years. Because of this, it is easy 
to discern its discolored shade and the large marks 
around it. A successful DC 11 Wisdom (Perception) 
check is enough to notice it. When pushed, the 
panel opens into the narrow corridor and wide 
chamber beyond.
Encounter Condition: Stagnant Air
Tactics: After the PCs spend 30 minutes in this room, 
roll for a random encounter. On a 6-14, a gray ooze 
or ochre jelly shuffles into the room.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
a gray ooze is already here, dissolving the stone. To 
decrease the challenge, remove the possibility of a 
Random Encounter.
C79 . GRAY OOZE PRISON
The narrow hallway opens into a wide room. This 
dark chamber is empty except for a puddle of water 
in the northeastern corner.
Initial Attitude: Unfriendly
Encounter: Nardarik keeps a gray ooze prisoner in 
this room. This creature unwittingly ventured into 
the black dragon‚Äôs lair over a year ago and now 
Nardarik frequently visits the ooze to torment it. 
The ooze remains motionless and does not attack 
unless the PCs move within 5 ft., striking the clos-
est target.
Encounter Condition: Ambush, Cover
Tactics: The gray ooze does its best to conceal itself, 
hiding under cover when possible and generally 
avoiding outright confrontation. While mindless, 
months of torture have taught it to lie still and not 
attract unwanted attention.
If combat is inevitable, unarmored PCs are per-
fect targets, suffering the gray ooze‚Äôs acidic touch.
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encoun-
ter, add one gray ooze. To decrease the challenge, 
have the ooze recently tortured by Nardarik (-20 
hit points).

C80-C85 . TRICKS AND TRAPS .
Once serving as powerful prisons for demons and the 
like, these rooms fell out of favor when the celestials 
were forced into Regions E and G. Each room in this 
section is trapped with powerful magic, capable of 
bringing the strongest PC to his knees. For thousands 
of years, these rooms have stood as cells, holding 
pens, and ‚Äútorture‚Äù chambers to remind evil creatures 
of the price of disobedience.
Since the area is devoid of inhabitants, and filled 
with traps that discourage travel, Nardarik (Room 
C77) makes no challenge to annex this territory. Most 
inhabitants of the region know about this section and 
avoid it at all costs, leaving the dragon to focus his 
energies elsewhere. The stone floor is covered with 
a thick layer of undisturbed dust, suggesting that 
nothing has entered here in some time. There are no 
random encounters in this section.
C80 . THE WEARINESS OF THE TRAVELER
This room would be perfectly square if it were not 
for a thin wall separating it into two sections. 
Though this wall seems out of place, its surface is 
exactly like the other stone walls in the area. The 
only difference is that it is narrower than what 
would be expected.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room is rigged with a potent magi-
cal device that causes a level of exhaustion to those 
journeying through it. Anyone traveling through 
this room, in either direction, falls under its effect. 
Merely entering the room through one door is not 
enough to trigger the enchantment, but PCs enter-
ing the room from one door and exiting through 
the other instantly become Exhausted. This effect 
takes place regardless of the amount of time spent 
inside the room. There is no save and the condition 
persists for 24 hours.
Encounter Condition: [Fear 16], Haunted, Nega-
tive Energy
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add fear to the exhaustion effect. To decrease the 
challenge, allow each PC a DC 16 Wisdom save to 
avoid exhaustion.
C81 . THE BURDEN OF THE WEAK
The floor in this room is covered in a layer of thick 
dust and dirt. With the exception of the seven 
burning torches set upon the eastern wall, the place 
is completely empty. A beautiful sigil crisscrosses 
the stone pattern of the floor, forming an ellipse 
with intersecting circles.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room is trapped with a permanent 
symbol (stunning) spell that affects anyone who steps 
on or reads the symbol printed on the center of 
the floor.
If the symbol is touched or read, everyone in 
the room must make a DC 16 Wisdom save or be 
stunned for 1 minute. Anyone who exits the room 
must save again upon re-entering the chamber and 
viewing the symbol.
 '
Symbol of Stunning Trap. Detect: DC 22 Intelligence 
(Arcana); Disable: DC 22 Intelligence (Arcana)
Encounter Condition: [Fear 18]
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add a symbol (pain) to the symbol of stunning. To 
decrease the challenge, replace the symbol (stunning) 
with symbol (sleep).

256
C82 . THE STAGGERING STRENGTH
The floor of this room is covered with dust, but 
this substance is darker than most of the dust 
blanketing the other chambers and hallways of 
this region.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: 1 round after the PCs enter this room, a 
powerful gust of wind erupts from tiny cracks in the 
floor. The gust of wind affects everyone in the room 
and sends poisonous ungol dust into the air. Living 
creatures inhaling the dust begin choking immedi-
ately and must succeed at a DC 14 Wisdom save or 
become frightened for 2d6 rounds.
 '
Gust of Wind and Ungol Dust Trap. Detect: DC 18 
Intelligence (Arcana); Disable: DC 18 Dexterity 
(Thieves‚Äô Tools).
Encounter Condition: [Drafty], [Fear 16], Stagnant Air
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add chain lightning to the gust of wind and ungol 
dust trap. To decrease the challenge, remove the 
ungol dust and instead have the PCs pelted with 
pebbles and debris (2d6 bludgeoning damage to 
each player).
C83 . THE MIRROR OF TRUTH
This small room is empty except for a large mirror 
mounted on the diagonal northwest wall. The 
mirror is framed in an orange copper alloy that 
reflects light nicely. It is a large but otherwise 
simple piece of furniture.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This tiny chamber is actually a portal to 
Room C84. To pass through the secret door (or even 
discover it), the PCs must face the mirror in the 
northwest corner.
Anyone entering this room must make a DC 17 
Wisdom save to resist the Zone of Truth coming 
from the mirror. Those standing directly in front of 
the mirror, so as to see their reflections, trigger a 
magic mouth. Everyone in the room hears ‚ÄúShelter 
and comfort await friends who wish it. What is your 
name?‚Äù To everyone else, the mirror is empty, but 
those who answer, the mirror see through to the 
other side.
On the other side of the mirror is a lush, yet 
confined room filled with two three-tiered bunk 
beds, a modest table, two chairs, and a wash- basin. 
The mirror is a doorway to Room C84.
Encounter Condition: Distracting Visions
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: N/A
C84 . RESTFUL NIGHTMARE
A pair of three-level bunk beds dominates this 
small room. The beds can easily accommodate 
six medium-sized creatures and thick sheets rest 
upon them. In addition to the bunks, there are 
two small chairs, an ivory wash basin, and a large 
wooden chest.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: The basin in this room is filled with cool 
fresh water. When water is taken out of it, the basin 
magically refills itself. Regardless of the quantity of 
liquid taken out of it, the basin constantly refills. 
The basin is mounted to the floor and cannot be 
moved or tipped over.
This room was designed to attract demons to 
safety, instead targeting them with a powerful 
nightmare. Any PC trying to rest here is subjected 
to the nightmare.
 '
Nightmare Trap. Detect: DC 21 Intelligence (Arcana); 
Disable: DC 21 Intelligence (Arcana); Characters 
resting in the room must make a DC 17 Wisdom 
save or suffer from the nightmare. Those who ut-
tered their true names in Room C83 receive person-
alized nightmares, based on events from their past. 
Those who lied (as demons are apt to, lest they give 
away their true name) suffer Disadvantage to Wis-
dom checks and saving throws for 24 hours due to 
visions of a future that is horrific and inexplicable.
Encounter Condition: [Distracting Vi-
sions], [Haunted]
Tactics: N/A

257
257
Treasure: The wooden chest contains extra blankets 
and pillows for six beds.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encoun-
ter, add phantasmal killer to the nightmare trap. To 
decrease the challenge, replace the nightmare trap 
with a crushing despair trap.
C85 . ANGELIC STATUE
The door to this room is locked. A DC 21 Dexterity 
(Thieves‚Äô Tools) check is required to open it.
A beautiful statue representing a large female 
humanoid with mighty wings issuing from her 
back stands in the middle of this room. Though the 
statue is cloaked with dust, it is clear her eyes are 
made of the purest emerald stones.
PCs who did not steal the emeralds are blessed when 
they leave the room and may rest here as long as 
they like (so long as the emeralds are untouched).
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room is anachronistic in relation to 
the rest of the section. It looks and feels alien to 
anything else the PCs have seen so far. Evil-aligned 
PCs must succeed at a DC 14 Wisdom save or 
become frightened for 2d4 rounds after entering 
the room. While this effect is not devastating, it is 
intimidating.
The celestial angel statue in this room is made 
of the same stone as the rest of the dungeon. 
Despite the obvious valueless nature of its material, 
it is a truly impressive work of art. The emeralds 
that make its eyes are priceless and foreign to 
this world. A successful DC 21 Intelligence check 
confirms these gems are entirely unique and alien, 
fetching upwards of 10,000 gp each.
The PCs can remove the emeralds from the 
statue by prying them out with a successful DC 15 
Strength check. Three rounds after the precious 
stones are taken out, they turn into a dull black 
shape and crumble to dust. Soon after, the real 
terror begins.
First, when the gems turn to dust, the bearer 
must succeed at a DC 18 Dexterity save or swallow 
some of the dust, losing 1d8 maximum hp for 1 
week. Second, everyone in the room suffers bane 
for 2d8 days (no saving throw). Third, a beastly howl 
fills the room, chilling the PCs to the bone (eyebite). 
They are allowed a DC 18 Constitution save to 
negate the effect. Fourth, a wave of exhaustion (no 
saving throw) strikes everyone in the room.
Each trap effect triggers one after the other in 
successive rounds.
Encounter Condition: [Fear 18], Fearless, Hallowed or 
Unhallowed, Haunted or Safe, Negative Energy or 
Positive Energy
Tactics:
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase the hit point reduction to 2d8. To decrease 
the challenge, reduce the duration of all effects 
to 24 hours.

C86-C94 . NARROW MAZE .
A multitude of narrow corridors make up most of this 
section. Because the outlying territory is so danger-
ous, inhabitants of the region usually avoid this area. 
Two years ago, a group of adventurers found their 
way into the dungeon and entered this region, estab-
lishing a base of operations in Rooms C86-C91. They 
passed away soon after. Signs of their passage can be 
found throughout these isolated chambers.
PCs venturing into the narrow hallways of this area 
must walk single file.
While Room C94 is technically part of Arnuk‚Äôs 
(Room C96) section, she avoids it and commands her 
sons to do the same. There are no random encoun-
ters in this section.
C86 . FORMER ADVENTURERS' CHAMBER
Though this small room was originally designed to 
hold a prisoner, the lock was destroyed long ago.
The stench of decay prevails in this room and a 
glance inside instantly reveals the source of the 
foul smell. The body of a dwarf, curled up in the 
fetal position, lies in the southwest corner. Almost 
no meat remains upon the skeletal corpse, but the 
odor of rotted flesh lingers.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Long after its original captive was gone, 
the room was used as a bed chamber. A dwarven 
male lies on a rotted blanket in this bed chamber, 
his cancerous form so diseased it doesn‚Äôt even 
attract flies.
Anyone touching or examining the dwarf ‚Äôs 
body must succeed at a DC 14 Constitution save 
or contract demon fever. Normally demon fever is 
spread through injury, but this strain is deadly even 
centuries after the demon‚Äôs fled the dungeon.
 '
Demon Fever. Incubation period of 24 hours, reduces 
the infected character‚Äôs maximum hit points by 2d6 
until the disease is cured.
Encounter Condition: Diseased (demon fever) 14, 
Stagnant Air
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: There are three old bedrolls in the cor-
ner, plus a diseased and rotted blanket on which 
the dwarf is sleeping. A successful DC 16 Wisdom 
(Perception) check reveals a leather scroll case and a 
small copper holy symbol (worth 5 gp) hidden in the 
closed skeletal fist of the dwarven corpse. The case 
contains three divine scrolls: calm emotions, freedom 
of movement, and protection from evil.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
increase the hit point damage to 3d6. To decrease 
the challenge, return lost maximum hit points 
after 1 hour.
C87 . OLD HEARTH
A circle of blackened stone lies at the heart of this 
room, with a small pile of gray ashes in its center. 
It is obvious that this was used as a hearth where 
fire once burned, but there is no trace of wood 
anywhere in the chamber.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: The adventuring band who lived here 
used this chamber as a common hall.
Encounter Condition: Diseased (demon fever) 14
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: A successful DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) 
check uncovers a half-burnt piece of parchment 
among the ashes. The last words of what must have 
been a long paragraph remains intact: ‚ÄúNo one 
knew why they were brought together in the bowels 
of this forgotten place, except that they would 
be needed to turn the tide at some forthcoming 
event. Yet the priests and paladins serving Merunda 
obeyed the will of their deity.‚Äù
This parchment is part of Arum‚Äôs notes and 
anyone reading ‚ÄúArum‚Äôs Journal‚Äù and succeeding at 
a DC 13 Intelligence check notices that the writing 
on the parchment is identical to that of the wizard‚Äôs 
journal in Room C52. This is another fragment of 
the accounts of the servants of Merunda who lost 
their lives fighting Ash (Room C21).
Scaling: N/A

C88 . ANCIENT STOREROOM
Five small crates and two large sacks crowd 
this chamber. Though the wood from the 
crates is rotted, some of the items they contain

Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Before their demise, the adventurers 
dwelling here stored extra gear in this room.
The door on the west wall is hidden by an illu-
sion, making it appear like the wall. Anyone touch-
ing the ‚Äúdoor‚Äù must succeed at a DC 16 Wisdom

Those succeeding the save realize the stone wall 
is an illusion. The illusionary wall never disappears,

Encounter Condition: Diseased (demon fever) 14
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: The large sacks contain several long cords

Scaling: N/A
C89 . FORMER TREASURE ROOM
In order to enter this room, PCs must first bypass the 
illusory wall in Room C88.
The rotted remains of shelving line the walls of this 
small room. Some of the shelves have fallen atop 
others, crushing whatever items were displayed on 
them in their wake. Others remain in place, but it is 
obvious that they are extremely fragile.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: This room was once used to store the

surviving members of the band abandoned their 
base of operations, they took most of what was 
valuable in this room.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: There are several broken glass vials, clay

shelves and at first glance there is nothing of value

Scaling: N/A
C90 . FUNERAL CHAMBER
The only door leading to this chamber is locked but

Two stone altars are lined up on the eastern and

Closer inspection reveals two man-sized corpses

Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: Inside are the bony remains of two

Anyone touching or examining the bodies must

 '
Demon Fever. Incubation period of 24 hours, reduces

Encounter Condition: Diseased (demon fever) 14
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: PCs searching the corpses find a master-

260
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter,

C91 . EMPTY CELL
There is a lock upon the door, but it is busted and

The door leading to this room has a barred window

C92 . CRUSHING WALL TRAP
This room is devoid of light or furniture, but a

Compacting Room Trap: Detect: DC 20 Wisdom (Per-

aged. It fits any medium creature and is worth

ters in the room must make a DC 15 Wisdom save

until they save. The effect can be ended by greater 
restoration, heal, or wish.
Opening the doors from inside this room requires 
the PCs to unlock only the last two locks, but the 
wards protecting these two are still present.
Five massive columns carved from bedrock support 
the fifty-foot-high ceiling of this great hall. Like 
most chambers in the dungeon, the area is bathed 
in shadows, but the disquieting murmurs of some 
hidden menace echoes through the wide place. 
Strange mirrors on the floor, ceiling, and walls 
reflect light in every direction, casting shadows 
into every corner and distorting the apparent size 
of the room.
Initial Attitude: Unfriendly
Encounter: This chamber holds one of the few orig-
inal inhabitants of the dungeon: a mighty specter 
named Aslur‚Äôthyn, whose cell was so secure, he 
never escaped. Magical wards upon the entire stone 
surfaces of the walls, ceiling, and floor keep him 
inside. Powerful magic imbues the walls of this spe-
cial prison cell, trapping all sound inside. This effect 
acts as silence.
Aslur‚Äôthyn has been confined to this cell since 
the dungeon was first built and has lost all hope 
of ever escaping. When the PCs open one of the 
doors leading into its cell, he stares in disbelief for 
one round. Allow him a DC 20 Wisdom save on the 
second round. If successful, he rushes for the door, 
otherwise he waits until the third round to make 
his escape.
Unless the PCs prevent Aslur‚Äôthyn from exiting 
the room, he flies past them. If the PCs stand in his 
way or attack him, Aslur‚Äôthyn fights back, vent-
ing centuries of accumulated anger. If the doors 
close, trapping him once again inside, he becomes 
furious and gains the benefit of barbarian rage for 
3 minutes.
Encounter Condition: Cursed 4, Distracting Noises, 
Distracting Visions
Tactics: Once engaged in battle, Aslur‚Äôthyn is relent-
less and fights until destroyed. He targets the weak-
est PC, drawing him away or sequestering him from 
the rest of the party. He continues to attack a single 
target until either of them is dead. If Aslur‚Äôthyn suc-
cessfully kills a PC (who will return as a spawn 1d3 
rounds later), he flees so the PCs are forced to fight 
one of their own.
If Aslur‚Äôthyn flees into the dungeon, he escapes 
via the fastest route possible, hiding from the PCs if 
they give chase. If the PCs allow him to escape, he 
immediately looks for victims to convert to spawns 
and within 24 hours commands 1d6 specters. This 
pattern continues until everything is converted 
or the specter finds an adversary more powerful 
than himself.
Aslur‚Äôthyn heads north, avoiding the dragon and 
oozes, but attacking any humanoids he finds. If the 
PCs emptied this region, he heads west in search of 
goblins in Region B before heading toward Region 
N. If the PCs chase him to Region F or G, he flies 
across the lava.
Treasure: The specter‚Äôs cloak is a black robe of the 
archmagi. The benefits of wearing this robe are 
bestowed to the wearer against corporeal and 
incorporeal creatures. If the PCs destroy Aslur‚Äôthyn 
they can take the robe, understanding that it is, of 
course, evil. The cloak is semi-incorporeal and part 
of him, but it becomes substantial when Aslur‚Äôthyn 
is destroyed.
The angels hid a powerful tome in this room, 
keeping its secrets from the world. The mirrors 
along the walls are part of the specter‚Äôs torment, 
reminding him of these trappings, no matter where 

262
262
he looks. But they also serve a second purpose. If 
the PCs succeed at a DC 21 Wisdom (Perception) 
check, they see a series of nodes on the four out-
side pillars in the mirrors that they cannot see on 
the pillars themselves. The center pillar is devoid 
of these nodes. Clever PCs should note that this 
means something, but a DC 21 Intelligence reveals 
the nodes are part of a grand puzzle.
It takes a while for the PCs to study the nodes 
and note subtle differences in their shape and 
color. After an hour, allow the PCs a DC 21 Wisdom 
(Perception) check to confirm the four nodes that 
are identical. If the PCs can find a way to touch 
them all at the same time (they are all placed in 
such a way that no two can be touched at once by 
a large or smaller being), the center pillar slowly 
opens from top to bottom like a giant puzzle box. 
As each stone shifts, more and more light from the 
pillar‚Äôs core releases until 5 minutes later the room 
is bathed in daylight.
Once the pillar is completely opened (a process 
that takes 30 minutes), a small pedestal remains, 
with a book resting on it. This process also disables 
the traps on the locks, until the pillars are reset by 
pressing the nodes again (which closes the pillar). 
The book is shielded by great magic and any PC 
touching it sets off a divine word trap which resets 
in 5 rounds.
 '
Divine Word Trap. Detect: DC 17 Intelligence (Ar-
cana); Disable: DC 17 Intelligence (Arcana); Char-
acters touching the book must succeed on a DC 17 
Charisma saving throw. On a failure, the creature 
is deafened for 1 minute. On a 15, the creature is 
deafened and blinded for 10 minutes. On a 10 the 
creature is blinded, deafened, and stunned for 1 
hour. On a 5 or lower, the creature is killed instant-
ly. Celestials, elementals, fey, or fiends that fail are 
forced back to their plane of origin and cannot 
return for 24 hours.
If the PCs find a way to bypass the divine word 
trap, they can take the book, which is in fact, a vile 
tome containing every arcane necromancy spell 
ever written. Every necromancy spell from the 
wizard, sorcerer, or cleric spell lists in the Player‚Äôs 
Handbook is here. It is up to the GM if these spells 
are from other open source material or just so 
powerful and incomprehensible the PCs can never 
learn them. The book radiates strong Necromancy 
and evil. If they do not disable the divine word trap, 
the book can only be removed from the pedestal by 
a lawful good character.
In addition, the surface of the book is protect-
ed by a glyph of warding, which goes off once the 
PCs read the cover. If they open the book to the 
first page, the character must succeed on a DC 17 
Dexterity saving throw, or a magical snake leaps out 
and sinks its teeth into the character, and vanish-
es. The character suffers 6d8 poison damage and 
must make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw. On 
a failure, the damage reduces their maximum hit 
points by an amount equal to the damage taken for 
24 hours. Neither effect can be dispelled or disabled 
and neither harm the book.
Scaling: To increase the challenge of this encounter, 
add a specter or wight, neither of which wants to 
leave but instead intends to convert the PCs into 
the undead. In addition, they can use ‚Äòlife drain‚Äô on 
animals as well as humanoids. To decrease the chal-
lenge, place daylight in the center of the room in a 
20-ft. radius that affects Alsur‚Äôthyn as sunlight.
C94 . CRUSHING GRATE TRAP
The floor of this great hall is arranged with a 
multitude of square tiles. Gray dust covers most of 
the floor, but it fails to hide the dented and chipped 
stone surface. Within each of the cracks separating 
the floor tiles, caked blood can be seen.
Initial Attitude: N/A
Encounter: The floor of this chamber is rigged with 
countless pressure plates. Each 5-ft.-by-5-ft. stone 
square making up the floor of the hall is part of a 
deadly mechanism that sends a heavy stone grate to 
the ground. This grate is made of the same stone as 
the rest of the region, is as large as the room, and 
is supported from the ceiling by massive iron poles. 
When more than 50 lbs. are put upon one of the 
pressure plates, the grate descends to the floor and 
crushes everyone inside.
When not activated, the grate looks like it is part of 
the ceiling. The only differences being that there are 
a multitude of small holes (some six inches in di-
ameter) cutting through its surface and dried blood 
is all over it. It can be spotted with a successful DC 
16 Wisdom (Perception) check, which also alerts 
anyone proficient with Thieves‚Äô Tools of the danger.

Stone Grate Trap. Detect: DC 16 Wisdom (Percep-
tion); Disable: DC 14 Dexterity; 2-round delay. No 
saving throw. All characters suffer 10d6 bludgeon-
ing damage after 1 round.
Encounter Condition: N/A
Tactics: N/A
Treasure: N/A
Scaling: To increase the difficulty of this encoun-
ter, have the stone gate trap deal 14d6 points of 
damage. To decrease the challenge, have it deal 
6d6 damage.
C95-C102 . HILL GIANTS' LAIR
This section is the home of Arnuk, a hill giant cleric, 
and her two sons. Arnuk‚Äôs family was part of a tribe 
that once dominated a large section of this region. 
But when Nardarik (Room C77) came, he killed off 
most of the tribe and drove the survivors away. Arnuk 
and her sons are the only remaining hill giants from 
this once-proud tribe.
To make matters worse, Vernir, one of Arnuk‚Äòs sons, 
once made a deal with the king of the goblins (Room 
B75) to fight the wizard Arum for them. Even in his 
maddened state, Arum was too much for the giant 
and Vernir nearly lost his life. Fortunately, the wizard 
showed mercy and only trapped the giant behind 
several layers of stony walls, rather than kill him. 
Arnuk and her other son now bear a deep grudge, but 
are unaware that Arum is gone. Lastly, the giants no 
longer trust the goblins and seek vengeance, should 
they ever find a way to escape.
Though they are content with their existence, these 
hill giants are trapped in the region and have little 
hope of ever emerging from the dungeon. They do 
not know about the secret door in Room C61, nor 
can they get past the imprisoned specter (Room C93). 
If they ever escape, Arnuk plans to destroy the black 
dragon Nardarik (Rooms C69-C79), the entire goblin 
tribe (Region B), and Arum.
Unless the PCs are Hostile, Arnuk asks them to do 
her bidding by talking about the great riches stolen 
from her people by the evil dragon Nardarik, as well 
as the treachery of the Gnashing Fang Tribe. If the 
PCs agree to help Arnuk get rid of her enemies, they 
are welcome in her lair. If the PCs do not want any-
thing to do with the hill giants, Arnuk and her sons 
insist that they exit their private domain. If the PCs 
know a way out, they handsomely reward them and 
offer an alliance.
Due to the size of the corridors, the giants are rare-
ly found outside Room C97. Their speed is cut in half 
in these tight hallways.
